summary: The writ petitioner, Tapas Kumar Chakraborty, sought to add his past service as a Tahashil Mohurrir to his service as a Group-D employee for pensionary benefits. The court rejected his claim, citing that his appointment as a Group-D employee was conditional upon not considering his past service. The court also distinguished his case from a cited judgment, Sarju, on grounds that the petitioner was not a casual or temporary employee. Consequently, the writ petition was dismissed.

The petitioner, M/s. DSA Plumbing and Construction, sought contempt action against Sri. Giridhari Saha, Chairman of Serampore Municipality, for non-payment of dues despite satisfactory completion of work. The court noted inconsistency in the Chairman's actions and directed him to appear personally to answer queries. The petition was partly allowed in so far as directions were issued.

summary: Petitioner Radhapada Ghosh's application CAN 1 of 2023 was dismissed for default as no accommodation was sought and it appeared the petitioner was no longer interested in proceeding. The writ petition WPA 5 of 2023 had already been disposed of by an earlier order. No costs were awarded.

The petitioner, Subhendu Dhara, filed a contempt application against Sri. Giridhari Saha, alleging non-payment of dues. The court disposed of the application, noting that the contemnor paid the admitted amount, but the disputed amount remains unpaid. The petitioner can approach a competent forum for relief.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petition can be withdrawn in accordance with the settlement between the parties.
summary: The petition was filed by M/S ERA-PATEI-ADVANCE(JV) against RAIL VIKAS NIGAM LIMITED. The disputes between the parties were amicably resolved, and the petition was withdrawn. The court disposed of the petition and all pending miscellaneous applications as infructuous.

primary_legal_issue: The petitioners sought to forbear the respondents from interfering with their residential building pending the final determination of their special revision petition.
summary: The petitioners, who are residents of a building in Chennai, filed a writ petition seeking to prevent the respondents from locking, sealing, or demolishing their building. The petitioners had purchased their flats in 2001 and had been living there since then. However, in 2020, the 3rd respondent issued a stop work notice and later a de-occupation notice, which the petitioners challenged through a special revision petition. The court directed the 1st respondent to entertain the special revision petition and dispose of it within three weeks, and ordered the 3rd respondent to defer further action until then.
facts: The petitioners purchased their flats in 2001 and had been living in the building since then. In 2020, the 3rd respondent issued a stop work notice and later a de-occupation notice, which the petitioners challenged through a special revision petition.
arguments: The petitioners argued that the respondents' actions were unjustified and that they had a right to continue living in their flats. The respondents argued that the petitioners had deviated from the approved plan and that the building was not in compliance with the relevant regulations.
judgment_reasoning: The court directed the 1st respondent to entertain the special revision petition and dispose of it within three weeks, and ordered the 3rd respondent to defer further action until then. The court did not go into the merits of the claim projected by the petitioners, but rather focused on the procedural aspects of the case.
key_legal_points: The court has the power to direct the respondent to entertain a special revision petition and dispose of it within a specified timeframe.
The court can order a respondent to defer further action pending the disposal of a special revision petition.
legal_issues: The validity of the stop work notice and de-occupation notice issued by the 3rd respondent.
The petitioners' right to continue living in their flats pending the disposal of their special revision petition.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the reimbursement of advertising, marketing and promotion expenses (AMP) incurred by the respondent/assessee on behalf of its Associated Enterprise (AE) was at arm's length.
summary: The Delhi High Court allowed the appeal of the respondent/assessee, setting aside the order of the Tribunal. The court held that the respondent/assessee was adequately compensated for expenses incurred for AMP activities carried out in India.
facts: The respondent/assessee, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sony Corporation, Japan, incurred AMP expenses on behalf of its AE. The TPO made an upward adjustment to the taxable income of the respondent/assessee, which was challenged before the Tribunal.
arguments: The appellant/revenue argued that the respondent/assessee was not adequately compensated for AMP expenses, while the respondent/assessee argued that the TPO erred in applying the bright line test (BLT) and that the ALP for AMP expenses could have been arrived at by separately benchmarking AMP services.
judgment_reasoning: The court held that the TPO erred in applying the BLT and that the respondent/assessee was adequately compensated for AMP expenses. The court also noted that the Tribunal's order was based on the decision in Sony Ericsson Mobile Communications India Pvt. Ltd. v. CIT.
key_legal_points: The bright line test (BLT) is not applicable in determining the arm's length price (ALP) for AMP activities.
The ALP for AMP expenses can be arrived at by separately benchmarking AMP services.
legal_issues: Whether the reimbursement of AMP expenses incurred by the respondent/assessee on behalf of its AE was at arm's length.
Whether the TPO erred in applying the BLT in determining the ALP for AMP activities.
precedents_cited: Sony Ericsson Mobile Communications India Pvt. Ltd. v. CIT

summary: The Delhi High Court heard two income tax appeals filed by the Principal Commissioner of Income Tax-18 against M/s Sumitomo Corporation India Pvt. Ltd. arguments: The respondent/assessee argued that the TNMM was the most appropriate method because it took into account the functions performed, assets employed, and risks assumed by the respondent/assessee.  2. On 30.01.2023, we had heard the matter at some length, when we had 
etched out the broad controversy that arose between the parties. For the sak e

“1. These appeals impugn a common order dated 21.05.2019 passed

2. ITA No.22/2023 concerns Assessment Year (AY) 2013-14, while 
ITA No.23/2023 concerns AY 2012-13.  
3. According to Mr Vipul Agarwal, who appears on behalf of the 
appellant/revenue, the impugned order passed by the Tribunal was 
received by the appellant/revenue on 06.06.2019.  
3.1 We may note that the affidavits accompanying the appeals indicate 
that they were sworn on 17.08.2020. Prima facie, there is delay in 
filing the appeals as well.  
3.2. The above-captioned applications [i.e., CM Nos.1876/2023 
& 1880/2023], though, seek condonation of delay, only in re-filing the 
appeals.  
3.3. Interestingly, the re-filling applications are also dated 
17.08.2020 and are accompanied by an affidavit which has been 
sworn on the same date. 
4. According to us, there is complete lack of clarity on the part of the 
appellant/revenue, as to whether they are seeking condonation of 
delay in filing the appeals or re-filing the appeals.  
5.     That being said, there is a considerable delay, even if one were to 
take into account the fact that Covid-19 had kicked in. Insofar as this 
court was concerned, there was disruption in work in and about 
March 2020 and thereafter.  
6. Mr C.S. Aggarwal, learned senior counsel, who appears on behalf 
of the respondent/assessee, points out that the applications for 
condonation of delay in re-filing were filed only on 07.01.2023, 
although, as noticed above, they are dated 17.08.2020. 
6.1 Mr C.S. Aggarwal also asserts that the defects pointed out by the 
Registry have not been cured.  
7.  Insofar as the merits of the case are concerned, the controversy 
which arises concerns the commission earned by the 
respondent/assessee, with respect to certain international transactions 
that it entered into with its Associated Enterprises [hereafter referred 
to as “AEs”]. These transactions are, broadly, referred to as 
“indenting transactions”.  
8. We may note, and qua which there is no dispute, disputes 
concerning AYs 2007-08 to 2010-11, had reached this court.  
8.1.   This court via judgment dated 22.07.2016 had remitted the 
subject appeals to the Tribunal. Via the very same judgment, the

 coordinate bench of this court had given leeway to the Tribunal to 
remand the matter to the Transfer Pricing Officer (TPO)/Assessing

8.2. The said judgment rendered by the coordinate bench was 
passed in the following appeals: 
             “ITA Nos.381/2013, 738/2015, 382/2013 & 702/2014.”

10. We have been taken by Mr C.S. Aggarwal through the order 
passed by the Tribunal. Briefly put, the Tribunal has returned 
the following two significant findings of fact:  
10.1 First, the Transaction Net Margin Method (TNMM) 
would be the  
most suitable method for determining Arm‟s Length Price (ALP) 
for international transactions concerning indenting transactions

10.2 Second, the Berry ratio method for calculating Profit

11. In respect of the aforesaid findings of fact, a detailed 
analysis has been made by the Tribunal in paragraphs 15 to 19 
of its order dated 22.10.2018. For the sake of convenience, the 
relevant paragraphs are extracted hereafter: 
 
“15. We have heard the parties at length and also 
perused the material referred to before us as 
discussed herein above. The approach of 
determining the ALP on the basis of average percent 
of commission reported by the assessee in respect of 
indenting transactions with the non AEs as held by 
the Tribunal has not found judicial favour with the 
Hon'ble High Court and matter has been remanded 
back for further examination of similarity between 
the two transactions and to conduct further in depth 
inquiry to examine the high degree of comparability 
of relevant control and uncontrolled transactions. 
Further, if the average rate of commission on such 
transactions was to be applied to the FOB value of 
goods involved in the indenting transactions with the 
AEs, then this Tribunal has to satisfy itself that there 
is no significant variation in the rate of commission 
between different products. From the perusal of the

 indenting transactions undertaken by the assessee 
with AE and non AE under various product 
segments, it is discerned that, for instance in the 
product segment „Automotive‟, the assessee has 
undertaken 249 transactions with AE and only 4 
with non AE and in the Assessment Year 2007-08 the 
volume of transaction, FOB value wise is „Nil‟ in the 
case of non AE; and the commission earned with the 
AE is Rs. 7,50,43,686/- and with the non AE it is 
only Rs. 9,672/-. Similarly the products dealt with 
AE in automotive segment are entirely different and 
the geographies involved are Switzerland, 
Singapore, Thailand and Japan whereas non AE 
transactions  are with Suzuki Motorcycle India Pvt. 
Ltd. and Bajaj Auto Ltd in India. Likewise under the 
product „chemicals‟ the assessee has undertaken 
1044 transaction with AE and only 112 transaction 
with non AE and the commission with AE is 1.28%, 
whereas non AE it is 2.26%. Similarly, the products 
dealt with AE and non AE under this segment are 
quite different and geography involved with AE are 
Spain, Japan, Italy, Switzerland, Thailand, whereas 
with non AE it is India. Likewise in „electronics‟ 
segment the  transaction undertaken with the AE are 
253, whereas with the non AE it is 5 and again not 
only the products are different but also geographical 
location are different with that of non-AE which are 
mostly with Indian parties and all AE transactions 
are with various foreign countries. Similar 
differences are noted in all across 10 to 11 products 
dealt by the assessee with AEs and non AEs. The 
total number of transactions with the AE during the 
year was 3,145 and with non AE it was only 371. 
Thus, apparently there is a huge difference in 
volume on FOB basis and the geographies dealt are 
also entirely different. The amount of average 
commission earned with the AE, is 1.58% whereas 
in the case of non AE it is 2.26. All these differences 
are permeating in all the Assessment Years as 
highlighted by the assessee in the chart submitted 
before us and on perusal of the same, it is quite 
glaring that under both the transactions, i.e., 
controlled transaction with the AE and uncontrolled 
transaction with the non AEs, there are huge 
dissimilarity between the products, difference in

By:NEELAM SHARMA

 volume, difference in value, markets and 
geographical location. 
16. It is quite settled proposition that while 
applying CUP method, a very high degree of 
similarity has to be seen between the control and 
uncontrolled transactions not only in terms of 
products, contractual terms, volume, value but also 
market and geography locations. The reason being 
under CUP, price charged or paid for the property 
transferred has to be identified and the differences 
between the international transaction and the 
comparable uncontrolled transactions has to be 
seen which could materially affect the price in the 
open market. The price of different products 
cannot be the same as it depends upon the 
negotiation based on volumes, value and other 
contractual terms. Further different market and 
geographical location also affects the pricing 
factors and therefore, if there are differences on 
account of these factors CUP cannot be held to be 
the most appropriate method for bench marking 
the arm's length price. Here in this case, under the 
indenting segment there are various dissimilarities 
in the transaction with the AE and non AE as 
discussed above and for this reason alone the 
average commission earned cannot be the 
benchmarking factor for determining the ALP, and 
therefore, we hold that neither the CUP method 
can be applied nor the transaction with the AE and 
non AE can be taken for the purpose of 
comparability analysis. Thus, we reject the CUP 
method by taking the average commission earned 
in the transaction with the AE and non AE.  
 
17. Now, in these circumstances, we have to see 
whether TNMM can be considered as most 
appropriate method. First of all, it has been 
brought on record before us that right from the 
Assessment Years 2003-04 to 2006-07, TNMM has 
been accepted as the most appropriate method by 
the TPO. However, instead of ‘berry ratio’ as PLI, 
TPO has taken OP/TC as PLI. Further, it has been 
brought to our notice that from the Assessment 
Years 2011-12 to 2018-19 under the MAP 
agreement it has been agreed that TNMM should 
Digitally Signed
By:NEELAM SHARMA
Signing Date:18.07.2023
12:43:43Signature Not Verified
 
ITA 22/2023 & ITA 23/2023       Page 6 of 11 
 be the most appropriate method to determine the 
ALP of the international transaction of the indent 
keeping into the fact that assessee is a low risk 
service provider and there is no change in FAR 
right from Assessment Years 2003-04 to 2018-19. 
Once TNMM has been accepted under the similar 
FAR, we do not find any reason to deviate by 
adopting some other method. Otherwise also we 
have held that CUP method cannot be applied and 
other methods admittedly are incapable of 
capturing the true arm's length result and 
therefore, we hold that TNMM should be taken as 
a most appropriate method for benchmarking the 
said transaction.  
 
18. Now having accepted that TNMM is the most 
appropriate method, the second issue which needs to 
be clarified is what should be the base for computing 
the PLI. As stated above, the Hon'ble High Court 
has approved the permissibility of using all „berry 
ratio‟ as PLI in a situation where the functions 
performed did not entail huge creation of valuable 
intangibles. The nature of the assessee's business is 
a routine business support services and there is no 
creation of any human capital or supply chain 
intangible.  The Hon'ble High Court has held that 
‘berry ratio’ can  only be applied where the value of 
goods is not directly linked to the quantum of 
profits and the profits are mainly determined on 
expenses incurred. Here in this case, the assessee is 
acting as an indenting agent commission service 
provider, i.e., as a facilitator of a trade and has no 
financial risk, because assessee was not required to 
raise any invoice for sale and purchase in its 
financial commitment and risk are insignificant. 
As a service provider, the key business driver for 
the assessee is operating expenses incurred on  
establishment and operation of business, i.e., 
salary, rent and other such expenses and it does 
not employ any significant assets in the business 
except for routine assets like office, furniture and 
fixtures to run its business and also there is no 
intangible creation by the assessee company. 
Besides there is no trading capital employed as 
goods are neither bought nor sold by the assessee 
Digitally Signed
By:NEELAM SHARMA
Signing Date:18.07.2023
12:43:43Signature Not Verified
 
ITA 22/2023 & ITA 23/2023       Page 7 of 11 
 in the indenting segment. Under these facts and 
circumstances, the profit derived by the assessee is 
mainly depended on its operating expenditure as 
the value of goods does not enter in its financial. 
As a low risk service provider, it seeks to obtain 
adequate return on its  operating expenses as the 
operating expenses incurred represents the value 
added carried on by the assessee. In other  words, 
the operating expenses adequately and sufficiently 
represents the functions performed and the risk 
undertaken by the assessee . Thus, we hold that the 
‘berry ratio’ should be accepted as the most 
appropriate PLI for taking as base under TNMM  
while determining the ALP of the Indian 
transaction for all the five years under appeal.  
19. Accordingly, we remand the matter back to the 
file of the TPO to examine and benchmark the 
international transaction by adopting TNMM as 
the most appropriate method by taking ‘berry ratio’ 
as PLI . The assessee has to substantiate its margin

segment is at arm's length; and the TPO shall

to say that TPO shall give due and effective 
opportunity to the assessee to substantiate its ALP

primary_legal_issue: Whether the Tribunal was correct in adopting the Transaction Net Margin Method (TNMM) as the most appropriate method for determining the Arm's Length Price (ALP) of the international transactions entered into by the respondent/assessee with its Associated Enterprises (AEs).
summary: The Delhi High Court heard two income tax appeals filed by the Principal Commissioner of Income Tax-18 against M/s Sumitomo Corporation India Pvt. Ltd. The appeals concerned the assessment years 2012-13 and 2013-14. The Tribunal had adopted the TNMM as the most appropriate method for determining the ALP of the international transactions entered into by the respondent/assessee with its AEs. The High Court upheld the Tribunal's order and remanded the matter back to the Transfer Pricing Officer (TPO) to examine and benchmark the international transaction by adopting TNMM as the most appropriate method by taking 'berry ratio' as Profit Level Indicator (PLI).
facts: The respondent/assessee had entered into indenting transactions with its AEs, which involved the provision of commission services. The TPO had applied the Comparable Uncontrolled Price (CUP) method to determine the ALP of the international transactions. However, the Tribunal held that the CUP method was not the most appropriate method due to the lack of comparability between the controlled and uncontrolled transactions.
arguments: The appellant/revenue argued that the Tribunal was incorrect in adopting the TNMM as the most appropriate method. The respondent/assessee argued that the TNMM was the most appropriate method, as it took into account the functions performed, assets employed, and risks assumed by the respondent/assessee.
judgment_reasoning: The High Court held that the Tribunal was correct in adopting the TNMM as the most appropriate method. The Court noted that the CUP method was not applicable due to the lack of comparability between the controlled and uncontrolled transactions. The Court also held that the 'berry ratio' was the most appropriate PLI for determining the ALP of the international transactions.
key_legal_points: The TNMM is the most appropriate method for determining the ALP of international transactions where the CUP method is not applicable.
The 'berry ratio' is the most appropriate PLI for determining the ALP of international transactions where the respondent/assessee is a low-risk service provider.
legal_issues: Whether the Tribunal was correct in adopting the TNMM as the most appropriate method for determining the ALP of the international transactions.
Whether the 'berry ratio' was the most appropriate PLI for determining the ALP of the international transactions.

 2. On 30.01.2023, we had heard the matter at some length, when we had 
etched out the broad controversy that arose between the parties. For the sak e 
of convenience the said order is extracted hereafter: 
“1. These appeals impugn a common order dated 21.05.2019 passed 
by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal [in short, “Tribunal”].  
2. ITA No.22/2023 concerns Assessment Year (AY) 2013-14, while 
ITA No.23/2023 concerns AY 2012-13.  
3. According to Mr Vipul Agarwal, who appears on behalf of the 
appellant/revenue, the impugned order passed by the Tribunal was 
received by the appellant/revenue on 06.06.2019.  
3.1 We may note that the affidavits accompanying the appeals indicate 
that they were sworn on 17.08.2020. Prima facie, there is delay in 
filing the appeals as well.  
3.2. The above-captioned applications [i.e., CM Nos.1876/2023 
& 1880/2023], though, seek condonation of delay, only in re-filing the 
appeals.  
3.3. Interestingly, the re-filling applications are also dated 
17.08.2020 and are accompanied by an affidavit which has been 
sworn on the same date. 
4. According to us, there is complete lack of clarity on the part of the 
appellant/revenue, as to whether they are seeking condonation of 
delay in filing the appeals or re-filing the appeals.  
5.     That being said, there is a considerable delay, even if one were to 
take into account the fact that Covid-19 had kicked in. Insofar as this 
court was concerned, there was disruption in work in and about 
March 2020 and thereafter.  
6. Mr C.S. Aggarwal, learned senior counsel, who appears on behalf 
of the respondent/assessee, points out that the applications for 
condonation of delay in re-filing were filed only on 07.01.2023, 
although, as noticed above, they are dated 17.08.2020. 
6.1 Mr C.S. Aggarwal also asserts that the defects pointed out by the 
Registry have not been cured.  
7.  Insofar as the merits of the case are concerned, the controversy 
which arises concerns the commission earned by the 
respondent/assessee, with respect to certain international transactions 
that it entered into with its Associated Enterprises [hereafter referred 
to as “AEs”]. These transactions are, broadly, referred to as 
“indenting transactions”.  
8. We may note, and qua which there is no dispute, disputes 
concerning AYs 2007-08 to 2010-11, had reached this court.  
8.1.   This court via judgment dated 22.07.2016 had remitted the 
subject appeals to the Tribunal. Via the very same judgment, the

inquiry to examine the high degree of comparability 
of relevant control and uncontrolled transactions. 
Further, if the average rate of commission on such 
transactions was to be applied to the FOB value of 
goods involved in the indenting transactions with the 
AEs, then this Tribunal has to satisfy itself that there 
is no significant variation in the rate of commission 
between different products. From the perusal of the

 volume, difference in value, markets and

16. It is quite settled proposition that while 
applying CUP method, a very high degree of 
similarity has to be seen between the control and 
uncontrolled transactions not only in terms of 
products, contractual terms, volume, value but also 
market and geography locations. The reason being 
under CUP, price charged or paid for the property 
transferred has to be identified and the differences 
between the international transaction and the 
comparable uncontrolled transactions has to be 
seen which could materially affect the price in the 
open market. The price of different products 
cannot be the same as it depends upon the 
negotiation based on volumes, value and other 
contractual terms. Further different market and 
geographical location also affects the pricing 
factors and therefore, if there are differences on 
account of these factors CUP cannot be held to be 
the most appropriate method for bench marking 
the arm's length price. Here in this case, under the 
indenting segment there are various dissimilarities 
in the transaction with the AE and non AE as 
discussed above and for this reason alone the 
average commission earned cannot be the 
benchmarking factor for determining the ALP, and 
therefore, we hold that neither the CUP method 
can be applied nor the transaction with the AE and 
non AE can be taken for the purpose of 
comparability analysis. Thus, we reject the CUP 
method by taking the average commission earned 
in the transaction with the AE and non AE.  
 
17. Now, in these circumstances, we have to see 
whether TNMM can be considered as most 
appropriate method. First of all, it has been 
brought on record before us that right from the 
Assessment Years 2003-04 to 2006-07, TNMM has 
been accepted as the most appropriate method by 
the TPO. However, instead of ‘berry ratio’ as PLI, 
TPO has taken OP/TC as PLI. Further, it has been 
brought to our notice that from the Assessment 
Years 2011-12 to 2018-19 under the MAP 
agreement it has been agreed that TNMM should 
Digitally Signed
By:NEELAM SHARMA
Signing Date:18.07.2023
12:43:43Signature Not Verified
 
ITA 22/2023 & ITA 23/2023       Page 6 of 11 
 be the most appropriate method to determine the 
ALP of the international transaction of the indent 
keeping into the fact that assessee is a low risk 
service provider and there is no change in FAR 
right from Assessment Years 2003-04 to 2018-19. 
Once TNMM has been accepted under the similar 
FAR, we do not find any reason to deviate by 
adopting some other method. Otherwise also we 
have held that CUP method cannot be applied and 
other methods admittedly are incapable of 
capturing the true arm's length result and 
therefore, we hold that TNMM should be taken as 
a most appropriate method for benchmarking the 
said transaction.  
 
18. Now having accepted that TNMM is the most 
appropriate method, the second issue which needs to 
be clarified is what should be the base for computing 
the PLI. As stated above, the Hon'ble High Court 
has approved the permissibility of using all „berry 
ratio‟ as PLI in a situation where the functions 
performed did not entail huge creation of valuable 
intangibles. The nature of the assessee's business is 
a routine business support services and there is no 
creation of any human capital or supply chain 
intangible.  The Hon'ble High Court has held that 
‘berry ratio’ can  only be applied where the value of 
goods is not directly linked to the quantum of 
profits and the profits are mainly determined on 
expenses incurred. Here in this case, the assessee is 
acting as an indenting agent commission service 
provider, i.e., as a facilitator of a trade and has no 
financial risk, because assessee was not required to 
raise any invoice for sale and purchase in its 
financial commitment and risk are insignificant. 
As a service provider, the key business driver for 
the assessee is operating expenses incurred on  
establishment and operation of business, i.e., 
salary, rent and other such expenses and it does 
not employ any significant assets in the business 
except for routine assets like office, furniture and 
fixtures to run its business and also there is no 
intangible creation by the assessee company. 
Besides there is no trading capital employed as 
goods are neither bought nor sold by the assessee 
Digitally Signed
By:NEELAM SHARMA
Signing Date:18.07.2023
12:43:43Signature Not Verified
 
ITA 22/2023 & ITA 23/2023       Page 7 of 11 
 in the indenting segment. Under these facts and 
circumstances, the profit derived by the assessee is 
mainly depended on its operating expenditure as 
the value of goods does not enter in its financial. 
As a low risk service provider, it seeks to obtain 
adequate return on its  operating expenses as the 
operating expenses incurred represents the value 
added carried on by the assessee. In other  words, 
the operating expenses adequately and sufficiently 
represents the functions performed and the risk 
undertaken by the assessee . Thus, we hold that the 
‘berry ratio’ should be accepted as the most 
appropriate PLI for taking as base under TNMM  
while determining the ALP of the Indian 
transaction for all the five years under appeal.  
19. Accordingly, we remand the matter back to the 
file of the TPO to examine and benchmark the 
international transaction by adopting TNMM as 
the most appropriate method by taking ‘berry ratio’ 
as PLI . The assessee has to substantiate its margin 
by bringing comparable uncontrolled transactions 
to demonstrate that its commission earned in this 
segment is at arm's length; and the TPO shall 
examine the same and decide accordingly. Needless 
to say that TPO shall give due and effective 
opportunity to the assessee to substantiate its ALP 
as per direction given above. ”

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner is entitled to anticipatory bail in a case of alleged rape and molestation.
summary: The petitioner, MD SHAMSHER, has filed an application for anticipatory bail in a case of alleged rape and molestation. The victim, who is the petitioner's sister-in-law, has alleged that the petitioner grabbed her breast, tried to remove her clothes, and attempted to indulge in intercourse with her. The petitioner has been accused of committing the offence under Section 376/506 of the Indian Penal Code. The court has dismissed the application for anticipatory bail, holding that the allegations against the petitioner are grave and serious in nature, and that the petitioner is not entitled to the privilege of pre-arrest bail.
facts: The victim had made two PCR calls on 11.10.2022, and subsequently, her statement was recorded before the DCW and under Section 164 Cr.P.C. The petitioner has been accused of committing the offence under Section 376/506 of the Indian Penal Code. The petitioner has been absconding and evading his arrest, and PO proceedings have been initiated against him.
arguments: The learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that the petitioner has been falsely implicated in the case, and that the victim has a habit of lodging false FIRs. The learned APP for the State opposed the application, submitting that the allegations against the petitioner are grave and serious in nature, and that the petitioner is not entitled to the privilege of pre-arrest bail.
judgment_reasoning: The court has held that the allegations against the petitioner are grave and serious in nature, and that the petitioner is not entitled to the privilege of pre-arrest bail. The court has also held that the delay in lodging the FIR is not fatal to the case of the prosecution, and that the incident recorded in the MLC and the statement before the DCW are duly corroborated with the statement of the victim under Section 164 Cr.P.C.
key_legal_points: The court has held that the allegations against the petitioner are grave and serious in nature.
The petitioner is not entitled to the privilege of pre-arrest bail.
The delay in lodging the FIR is not fatal to the case of the prosecution.
legal_issues: Whether the petitioner is entitled to anticipatory bail in a case of alleged rape and molestation.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the income received by the respondent/assessee as fee is amenable to deduction under Section 10(26AAB) of the Income Tax Act, 1961
summary: The Delhi High Court dismissed an appeal filed by the Commissioner of Income Tax against an order of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, which had ruled in favor of the respondent/assessee, an Agricultural Produce Marketing Committee. The Tribunal had held that the fee earned by the respondent/assessee from regulating the marketing of fish, poultry, and eggs was exempt from income tax under Section 10(26AAB) of the Income Tax Act, 1961. The High Court upheld the Tribunal's order, observing that the expression 'agricultural produce' in Section 10(26AAB) is wide enough to include fish, poultry, and eggs, and that the fee earned by the respondent/assessee was derived from regulating the marketing of these products.
facts: The respondent/assessee had filed its return declaring a loss of Rs.2,23,585/- after excluding Rs.6,04,06,259/- from its total income by taking recourse to the provisions of Section 10(26AAB) of the 1961 Act. The Assessing Officer made an addition of Rs. 6,04,06,259/-, which was later ruled in favor of the respondent/assessee by the Commissioner of Income Tax (Appeals) and the Tribunal.
arguments: The appellant/revenue argued that the Tribunal had committed an error in holding that the subject products fell within the scope of the expression 'agricultural produce'. The respondent/assessee argued that the fee earned by it was exempt from income tax under Section 10(26AAB) of the 1961 Act.
judgment_reasoning: The High Court observed that the expression 'agricultural produce' in Section 10(26AAB) is wide enough to include fish, poultry, and eggs, and that the fee earned by the respondent/assessee was derived from regulating the marketing of these products. The Court also noted that the definition of 'agricultural produce' in the Delhi Agricultural Produce Marketing (Regulation) Act, 1998, includes all kinds of produce, including fish, poultry, and eggs.
key_legal_points: The expression 'agricultural produce' in Section 10(26AAB) is wide enough to include fish, poultry, and eggs
The fee earned by the respondent/assessee is exempt from income tax under Section 10(26AAB) of the 1961 Act

6.     The facts which have emerged from the record [and which are n ot in

(i) The respondent/assessee had filed its return on 29.09.2012 declaring a

7. Therefore, before the Tribunal, the aspect which arose for 
consideration was as to whether the fee i.e., income derived by the  
respondent/assessee for regulating the market dealing with produ cts such as 
fish, poultry and eggs, would fall within the scope of Sectio n10(26AAB). In

9. After taking into account the definition and contents of t he schedule 
the Tribunal made the following observations: 
“21. The above definitions show that DAPM Act does not restrict 
constitution of committee only for marketing agricultural product. It has 
within its scope various other commodities like decorative plants 
productions of honey and silk. It also includes the marking of forest 
products which otherwise do not fall within the definition of agriculture. 
The DAPM, Act, therefore, has given very wide meaning to the word 
agricultural produce. Apparently, the Income-tax Act has also imported the 
word agricultural produce from the DAPM, Act, 1998 to cover APMC 
notified under it to provide the benefit to all APMCs provided in the DAPM 
Act or similar Acts, in other states.  It could not have been the intention of 
the Act to leave out some of the committees, notified under the DAPM 
especially when all the committees were rendering similar services in 
respect of various products .

23. As discussed above, the word agricultural produce, used in 
connection with APMC connotes a very wide meaning bringing within its 
preview a large gamut of commodities besides agricultural products. Since 
the income accrues to the APMCs from pursuing these activities, the 
Income Tax Act, also perceives a wider meaning by referring to the DAPM . 
 
xxx                         xxx                      xxx 
 
25. It is however observed that the assessee has claimed a loss of 
Rs.2,23,585/- in her return of Income. The same represents depreciation for 
the year, which has not been set off against the profits/income of the 
committee. In fact, the assessee has committed a mistake in filing the return,

 26. Without prejudice to the above, the Supreme Court in the case of CIT 
vs Harprasad & Company (P) Ltd. (99 ITR 118) has held that "From the 
charging provisions of the Act, it is discernible that the words 'income' or 
'profits and gains' should be understood as including losses also that, in one 
sense 'profits and gains ' represent plus 'income' whereas losses represent 
'minus income'. In other words, loss is negative profit. Both positive and 
negative profits are of a revenue character. Both must enter into 
computation, wherever it becomes material, in the same mode of the taxable 
income of the assessee. " 
 
 
10. Mr Hossain says that the Tribunal has committed an error b y holding 
that the subject products fell within the scope of the e xpression “agricultural 
produce”. According to Mr Hossain, agricultural produce will be t hat 
produce which is yielded in the course of cultivation and not  the kind 
referred to in the Tribunal’s order.  
10.1. Mr Hossain goes on to argue that since the income earned by the 
respondent/assessee is not derived from agricultural produce, the 
respondent/assessee could not have excluded it from its total income by 
taking recourse to the provisions of Section 10(26AAB) of the 1961 Act. 
11.     It is, however, not disputed by Mr Hossain that the d efinition of the 
expression “agricultural produce” is not provided in the 1961  Act. Before 
we proceed further, it would be relevant to extract the provision in issue, i.e., 
Section 10(26AAB) of the 1961 Act: 
 
“Section 10(26AA B): any income  of an agricultural produce market 
committee or board constituted under any law for the time being in force  for 
the purpose of regulating the marketing of agricultural produce ” 
 
[Emphasis is ours] 
 
11.1, This definition, if broken down, would entail the followi ng: 
(i) It concerns “ any income ” of the Agricultural Produce Market

12. Therefore, the argument advanced by Mr Hossain, on behalf of the 
appellant/revenue, that unless income which is earned is relata ble to 
agricultural produce, it cannot be kept out of the pale of total i ncome of the 
assessee, is clearly not tenable, since the expression incorporated  in Section

primary_legal_issue: Whether interest under Section 220(2) of the Income Tax Act, 1961 is payable by the respondent/assessee in respect of the demand raised via the order dated 29.03.1990.
summary: The appeal concerns the assessment year 1987-88 and seeks to challenge the order dated 13.08.2018 passed by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal. The short issue was whether interest under Section 220(2) of the Income Tax Act, 1961 was payable by the respondent/assessee in respect of the demand raised via the order dated 29.03.1990. The Tribunal sustained the view taken by the CIT(A) as regards levy of interest under Section 220(2) of the Act. The High Court held that the liability to pay interest would arise only with respect to the amount specified in the notice of demand issued under Section 156 of the Act, which was not paid within the prescribed time.
facts: The assessment order was passed under Section 143(3) of the Act on 29.03.1990, assessing the respondent/assessee's income at Rs. 11,40,79,686/-. The CIT(A) reduced the income to Rs.5,83,45,420/- on 30.06.1999. The Tribunal passed a common order on 22.07.1996, scaling down the assessed income to Rs.92,49,259/-. The AO gave effect to the Tribunal's order on 29.04.1997, pegging the assessed income at Rs.66,80,645/-. The CIT(A) directed the AO to consider allowing deduction towards excise duty paid by the respondent/assessee on 07.06.2002.
arguments: The appellant/revenue argued that interest under Section 220(2) of the Act was payable by the respondent/assessee. The respondent/assessee argued that no demand notice was raised under Section 156 of the Act when the assessment order dated 29.03.1990 was passed.
judgment_reasoning: The High Court held that the plain language of sub-section (2) of Section 220 shows that the liability to pay interest would arise only with respect to the amount specified in the notice of demand issued under Section 156 of the Act, which was not paid within the prescribed time. The demand notice was issued only on 15.09.2014, and therefore, the order of the AO seeking to levy interest for the period spanning between 01.05.1990 and 15.09.2014 cannot be sustained.
key_legal_points: The liability to pay interest under Section 220(2) of the Act arises only with respect to the amount specified in the notice of demand issued under Section 156 of the Act.
The demand notice was issued only on 15.09.2014, and therefore, the order of the AO seeking to levy interest for the period spanning between 01.05.1990 and 15.09.2014 cannot be sustained.

primary_legal_issue: The court examined the validity of the rejection of the petitioner's bid in a tender process for a high-speed rail project.
summary: The petitioner, M/S J KUMAR INFRAPROJECTS LIMITED, challenged the rejection of its bid in a tender process for a high-speed rail project. The respondent, NATIONAL HIGH SPEED RAIL CORPORATION (NHSRCL), had rejected the bid due to a missing formal sentence in the bank guarantee. The court considered the clauses of the Instructions to Bidders and the decisions of the Apex Court in similar cases, and ultimately dismissed the petition.
facts: The petitioner submitted a bid for a high-speed rail project, but the respondent rejected it due to a missing formal sentence in the bank guarantee. The petitioner challenged the rejection, arguing that it was not a valid ground for rejection.
arguments: The petitioner argued that the rejection of its bid was not justified, as the missing sentence was a minor defect that could be corrected. The respondent argued that the bid was rejected due to a material deviation from the technical requirements of the bidding documents.
judgment_reasoning: The court considered the clauses of the Instructions to Bidders and the decisions of the Apex Court in similar cases. The court held that the petitioner had accepted the terms and conditions of the tender process, including the clauses that prohibited disclosure of information about the evaluation of bids until the contract award was communicated to all bidders.
key_legal_points: The court considered the validity of the rejection of the petitioner's bid in a tender process for a high-speed rail project.
The court examined the clauses of the Instructions to Bidders and the decisions of the Apex Court in similar cases.
legal_issues: The validity of the rejection of the petitioner's bid
The interpretation of the clauses of the Instructions to Bidders

primary_legal_issue: Whether the Court can recall a witness for re-cross-examination under Section 311 of the Cr.P.C.?
summary: The petitioner, Raj Kumar, has filed a revision petition against the order of the Trial Court rejecting his application for recalling the prosecutrix for re-cross-examination. The petitioner argues that he was unable to convey to his previous counsel the existence of certain WhatsApp chats and photographs that are crucial evidence in the case. The Court allows the petition, permitting the prosecutrix to be cross-examined on a single occasion, limited to confronting her with the said WhatsApp chats and photographs.
facts: The prosecutrix, a student of Mata Sundari College, alleged that the petitioner, a security guard at the college, took her to the sports complex and committed rape upon her. The petitioner was arrested and has been in judicial custody since 08.05.2019.
arguments: The petitioner's counsel argued that the previous counsel could not cross-examine the prosecutrix to the extent of confronting her with the WhatsApp chats and photographs, which are crucial evidence in the case. The respondent's counsel argued that the prosecutrix had already been cross-examined at length and that the present petition is liable to be rejected.
judgment_reasoning: The Court relies on the provisions of Section 311 of the Cr.P.C. and the judgments of the Supreme Court in Varsha Garg v. State of Madhya Pradesh and Zahira Habibullah Sheikh v. State of Gujarat, to hold that the Court has the power to recall a witness for re-cross-examination if the evidence appears to be essential to the just decision of the case.
key_legal_points: Section 311 of the Cr.P.C. gives the Court the power to recall a witness for re-cross-examination
The Court can exercise this power if the evidence appears to be essential to the just decision of the case
legal_issues: Whether the Court can recall a witness for re-cross-examination under Section 311 of the Cr.P.C.
Whether the evidence sought to be adduced is essential to the just decision of the case

 “311. Power to summon material witness, or examine

 12. Recently, the Hon’ble Supreme Court in Varsha Garg v. The 
State of Madhya Pradesh & Ors., 2022 SCC OnLine SC 986 , held 
as under:  
“32. This power can be exercised at any stage of any inquiry,  
trial or other proceeding under the CrPC. The latter part of  
Section 311 states that the Court “shall” summon and exam ine 
or recall and re- examine any such person “if his evidence 
appears to the Court to be essential to the just decision  of the 
case”. Section 311 contains a power upon the Court in broad  
terms. The statutory provision must be read purposively, to 
achieve the intent of the statute to aid in the discovery of truth.  
******  
37. The power of the court is not constrained by the closur e of 
evidence. Therefore, it is amply clear from the above 
discussion that the broad powers under Section 311 are to  be 
governed by the requirement of justice. The power must be 
exercised wherever the court finds that any evidence is 
essential for the just decision of the case. The statutory 
provision goes to emphasise that the court is not a hapless 
bystander in the derailment of justice. Quite to the contrar y, 
the court has a vital role to discharge in ensuring that the 
cause of discovering truth as an aid in the realization of justice 
is manifest.”

noted that:-

primary_legal_issue: Whether the delay in filing and re-filing the appeal can be condoned
summary: The Principal Commissioner Central Tax, Delhi South, filed an appeal against an order passed by the Customs, Excise & Service Tax Appellate Tribunal, New Delhi. The appeal was filed after a delay of 10 months, and the appellant sought condonation of the delay. The court dismissed the application for condonation of delay and consequently dismissed the appeal.
facts: The appellant received the impugned order on 23.07.2018 and filed the appeal on 31.05.2019. The appeal was returned under objection on 10.06.2019 due to defects, and the defects were not cured for over two months. The appeal was re-filed on 19.08.2019 but was still defective.
arguments: The appellant sought condonation of delay, stating that the delay was due to misplacement of file papers and oversight. The respondent argued that the delay was inordinate and without plausible explanation.
judgment_reasoning: The court held that the appellant had not provided a plausible explanation for the delay and that the delay was inordinate. The court relied on the Supreme Court's decision in Post Master General and Ors. v. Living Media India Ltd and Anr., which held that government departments cannot take advantage of liberal concession for condonation of delay without reasonable explanation.
key_legal_points: Condonation of delay is an exception and should not be used as an anticipated benefit for government departments
Government departments are under a special obligation to ensure that they perform their duties with diligence and commitment
legal_issues: Whether the delay in filing and re-filing the appeal can be condoned
Whether the appellant has provided a plausible explanation for the delay

1. The appellant has filed the present appeal impugning an order
dated 06.07.2018 passed by the Customs, Excise & Service Tax
Appellate Tribunal, New Delhi in Appeal No.ST/53655/2015. The
appellant states that the said order was received on 23.07.2018. The

receipt of the impugned order.

aforesaid, no other reason for condoning the delay was mentioned in t he
application (CM. APPL. 9867/2022). Further, the application also did

application. The reasons for seeking condonation of delay as stated in
the said application are set out below:-
“3. That the delay which has occurred in filling the appeal is due
misplacement of some of the file papers in the office of the
counsel which were recovered later on and the matter further
got delayed due oversight and inadvertence.
4. That upon the receipt of the aforesaid impugned order in the

Branch for taking a decision as to whether the said order has
to be challenge/appeal against or note. The review branch,

order passed by the Ld. Tribunal deserved to be challenged
before this Hon'ble Court and thereafter the appeal papers
were sent to the counsel for the appellant.
5. That, owing to the bulky nature of the appeal, some papers
were inadvertently left out when the matter was handed over
to the counsel for the appellant and thereafter upon a request
being made by the counsel to the department for complete

and which was later on provided by the appellant
department to the counsel. The status as to whether the
relied upon judgment had been appealed against or not or

4. Although the appellant had somewhat improved its explanation
for the reasons which had led to the delay in filing the present appeal, i t
is apparent that the same were also wanting in particulars.
5. It is well settled that each day of delay in filing has to be
explained. In the present case, there are large gaps in the time period
for which no ostensible reason has been provided.
6. The appellant has not only delayed in filing the present appeal
but there is also an unexplained and inordinate delay in re-filing t he
appeal. The above captioned appeal was filed on 31.05.2019. It was
returned under objection on 10.06.2019. This was because the court fee
was missing and the title was incorrect, apart from other defects. The
defects were not cured for more than two months thereafter. The appeal
was re-filed on 19.08.2019, however, the same was still defective. It is
material to note that the appellant had not filed a hard copy as required .
Thus, the appeal was retuned on 20.08.2019. Thereafter, there was
complete inaction for more than two years and five months. Even if the
period commencing from 15.03.2020 is excluded on account of
disruption caused due to outbreak of covid 19. There was a period of
six months between the date on which the appeal was marked as

SERTA No.3/2022 Page 4 of 5defective and the date when the lockdown was imposed in the wake of
the pandemic.
7. There is no explanation for this inordinate delay as well.
8. In the case of Post Master General and Ors. v. Living Media
India Ltd and Anr.: (2012) 3 SCC 563; the Supreme Court had
observed as under:
“27.It is not in dispute that the person(s) concerned were well aware or
conversant with the issues involved including the prescribed period
of limitation for taking up the matter by way of filing a special
leave petition in this Court. They cannot claim that they have a
separate period of limitation when the Department was possessed
with competent persons familiar with court proceedings. In the
absence of plausible and acceptable explanation, we are posing a
question why the delay is to be condoned mechanically merely
because the Government or a wing of the Government is a party
before us.
28.Though we are conscious of the fact that in a matter of condonation
of delay when there was no gross negligence or deliberate inaction
or lack of bona fides, a liberal concession has to be adopted to
advance substantial justice, we are of the view that in the facts and
circumstances, the Department cannot take advantage of various
earlier decisions. The claim on account of impersonal machinery
and inherited bureaucratic methodology of making several notes
cannot be accepted in view of the modern technologies being used
and available. The law of limitation undoubtedly binds everybody,
including the Government.
29. In our view, it is the right time to inform all the government bodies,
their agencies and instrumentalities that unless they have
reasonable and acceptable explanation for the delay and there was
bona fide effort, there is no need to accept the usual explanation
that the file was kept pending for several months/years due to
considerable degree of procedural red tape in the process. The
government departments are under a special obligation to ensure
that they perform their duties with diligence and commitment.
Condonation of delay is an exception and should not be used as an
anticipated benefit for the government departments. The law
shelters everyone under the same light and should not be swirled
for the benefit of a few.”

primary_legal_issue: Whether the ITAT was correct in deleting the addition of Rs.4,63,18,300/- made by the Assessing Officer under Section 68 of the Act
summary: The appellant, Pr. Commissioner of Income Tax -2- Agra, challenged the order of the ITAT, which deleted the addition of Rs.4,63,18,300/- made by the Assessing Officer under Section 68 of the Act. The High Court dismissed the appeal, holding that there was no substantial question of law and no perversity in the order passed by the tribunal.
facts: The assessee, Madhur Mittal, filed a return of income for the assessment year 2008-09, declaring an income of Rs.2,82,271/-. A search and seizure operation was carried out, and a notice was issued under Section 153A of the Act. The Assessing Officer made an addition of Rs.5,01,90,000/- under Section 68 of the Act, which was partly allowed by the CIT (A). The ITAT confirmed the order of the CIT (A), and the department appealed to the High Court.
arguments: The appellant argued that the ITAT failed to appreciate that the assessee had deposited Rs.5,01,90,000/- in cash in his bank account, and that the assessee did not produce any evidence to substantiate the receipt of money. The appellant also argued that the ITAT relied blindly on the cash flow statement and report of DIT (Systems) without corroborating it with other substantial evidence.
judgment_reasoning: The High Court held that the ITAT is the final arbiter of facts, and the High Court can interfere only if there is a substantial question of law or manifest illegality or perversity. The Court found that the ITAT had minutely examined the case and marshaled the facts well, and that there was no substantial question of law or perversity in the order passed by the tribunal.
key_legal_points: The ITAT is the final arbiter of facts
The High Court can interfere only if there is a substantial question of law or manifest illegality or perversity
Section 68 of the Act provides for the treatment of unexplained cash credits
legal_issues: Whether the ITAT was correct in deleting the addition made by the Assessing Officer under Section 68 of the Act
Whether the appellant had produced sufficient evidence to substantiate the receipt of money

petitioners: The Pr. Commissioner of Income Tax -6
judges: HON'BLE MS. JUSTICE MANMEET PRITAM SINGH ARORA
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Advertising, Marketing and Promotion (AMP) expenditure incurred by the Assessee is an international transaction.
summary: The Delhi High Court allowed the appeal filed by the Assessee, Moet Hennessy India Pvt. Ltd., and deleted the adjustment of Rs. 6,64,70,841/- made on account of AMP expenditure incurred by the Assessee. The Court held that there is no material on record to suggest that there was an international transaction between the Assessee and its Associated Enterprise (AE).
facts: The Assessee, Moet Hennessy India Pvt. Ltd., filed its Return of Income for the Assessment Year 2009-10, declaring a loss of Rs. 8,70,19,143/-. The Assessing Officer (AO) made a reference to the Transfer Pricing Officer (TPO) for determining the Arms’s Length Price (ALP) of the international transactions under Section 92CA(3) of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
arguments: The Revenue contended that the AMP expenses incurred by the Assessee is an international transaction, while the Assessee argued that there is no material on record to suggest that there was an international transaction between the Assessee and its AE.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the TPO had determined the existence of an international transaction on a matter of presumption, which runs counter to the decision of the Court in Maruti Suzuki (supra). The Court also held that the ITAT had correctly deleted the ALP adjustment made on account of AMP expenditure incurred by the Assessee.
key_legal_points: The existence of an international transaction cannot be a matter for inference or surmise.
The Bright Line Test (BLT) method is not a valid means for determining the ALP of an international transaction involving AMP expenses.
legal_issues: Whether the AMP expenditure incurred by the Assessee is an international transaction.
Whether the TPO had correctly determined the ALP of the international transactions.
precedents_cited: Sony Ericsson Mobile Communications India (P.) Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax – III
Maruti Suzuki vs. CIT
CIT v. EKL Appliances Ltd.

existence of an international transaction on a matter of a presumption, which
runs counter to the decision of this Court in Maruti Suzuki (supra ).

case_type: Appeal under Section 173 of the Motor Vehicle Act, 1988
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Tribunal erred in calculating the compensation for the deceased and the injured?
summary: The appellants challenged the Award dated 03.10.2018 passed by the Tribunal, seeking enhancement of compensation for the death of Pitesh @ Hitesh and injuries to Rajeev Kumar. The Court dismissed the appeal, holding that the Tribunal's calculation of compensation was just and proper.
facts: Pitesh @ Hitesh and Rajeev Kumar were travelling in a truck when it collided with another truck, resulting in Pitesh's death and Rajeev's injuries.
arguments: The appellants argued that the Tribunal erred in considering the deceased as unskilled and in calculating the injured's monthly income. The respondents argued that the Tribunal's Award was correct and that the appellants failed to produce documentary evidence to support their claims.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the Tribunal's calculation of compensation was based on the minimum wages prescribed under the Minimum Wages Act, as there was no documentary evidence to support the appellants' claims. The Court also relied on the Supreme Court's decision in Gurpreet Kaur and others versus United India Insurance Company and others, which held that the Notification of Minimum Wages Act can be a guiding factor only in cases where there is no clue available to evaluate the monthly income of the deceased.
key_legal_points: The Tribunal's calculation of compensation must be based on the evidence produced before it.
The Notification of Minimum Wages Act can be a guiding factor in calculating compensation only in cases where there is no clue available to evaluate the monthly income of the deceased.
legal_issues: Calculation of compensation for death and injuries
Relevance of Minimum Wages Act in calculating compensation
precedents_cited: Gurpreet Kaur and others versus United India Insurance Company and others
K. Suresh v. New India Assurance Co. Ltd.

summary: The appellant/revenue challenged the order of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal allowing the respondent/assessee to claim a deduction under Section 35D(2)(c)(iv) of the Income-tax Act, 1961 for expenditure incurred in connection with the issue of equity shares to QIBs. The court dismissed the appeal as the tax effect was less than the prescribed threshold of Rs. 1 crore.
facts: The respondent/assessee had incurred an expenditure of Rs. 9,46,22,358 in connection with the issue of equity shares to QIBs and had claimed a deduction of Rs. 1,89,24,471 under Section 35D(2)(c)(iv) of the Income-tax Act, 1961.
arguments: The appellant/revenue argued that the issue of shares to QIB was not a 'public subscription' and therefore, the deduction was not allowable. The respondent/assessee argued that the expenditure was eligible for deduction under Section 35D(2)(c)(iv) of the Income-tax Act, 1961.
judgment_reasoning: The court held that the tax effect was less than the prescribed threshold of Rs. 1 crore and therefore, the appeal was dismissed. The court also noted that the appellant/revenue had not obtained instructions from the concerned Assessment Officer (AO) despite the opportunity.
key_legal_points: Section 35D(2)(c)(iv) of the Income-tax Act, 1961 allows for a deduction for expenditure incurred in connection with the issue of equity shares to QIBs
The tax effect should be more than the prescribed threshold of Rs. 1 crore for the appeal to be maintainable

The court held that the Assessing Officer is required to specify the limb of Section 271(1)(c) of the Income Tax Act, 1961, for levying a penalty on the respondent/assessee.
facts: The respondent/assessee, Shyam Sunder Jindal, was issued penalty notices by the Assessing Officer for the assessment years 2008-09, 2009-10, 2010-11, and 2011-12. The notices did not specify which limb of Section 271(1)(c) of the Income Tax Act, 1961, was triggered against the respondent/assessee.
arguments: The counsel for the appellant/revenue did not dispute that the penalty notices issued to the respondent/assessee did not specify the limb of Section 271(1)(c) of the Income Tax Act, 1961, which was triggered against him.
judgment_reasoning: The court relied on its previous judgments, including Pr. Commissioner of Income Tax-3 v. Ms Minu Bakshi and Pr. Commissioner of Income Tax, Delhi-7 v. Unitech Reliable Projects Pvt. Ltd., which held that the Assessing Officer is required to specify the limb of Section 271(1)(c) of the Income Tax Act, 1961, for levying a penalty on the respondent/assessee.
key_legal_points: The Assessing Officer is required to specify the limb of Section 271(1)(c) of the Income Tax Act, 1961, for levying a penalty on the respondent/assessee.
The penalty notices issued to the respondent/assessee must indicate which limb of Section 271(1)(c) is triggered against him.

hereafter: 
 
“7. In our opinion, the conclusion reached by the Tribunal 
in the instant case that the notice for imposition of penalty 
under Section 271(1) (c) of the Act, did not specify which 
limb of the said provision the penalty was sought to be 
levied, is covered by the following decisions, which includes 
a decision rendered by a coordinate bench of this Court.  
(i) CIT and Anr. v M/s SS A’s Emerald Meadows, passed in 
ITA No. 380/2015, dated 23.11.2015.  
(ii) Commissioner of Income Tax v Manjunatha Cotton and 
Ginning Factory (2013) 359 ITR 565 (Kar.)  
(iii) PCIT vs M/s Sahara India Life Insurance Company 
Ltd., passed in ITA No.475/2019, dated 02.08.2019.  
7.1. To be noted, the Special Leave Petition filed against the 
judgement in SSA’s Emerald (mentioned above) was 
dismissed via order dated 05.08.2016. 
7.2. We are in agreement with the view taken by the 
Karnataka High Court in the above-mentioned judgements 
(in SSA’s Emerald and Manjunatha Cotton) and, in any 
event, are bound by the view taken by the coordinate bench 
of this court in the Sahara India case. ”

following observation made by the AO: “Penalty 
proceeding u/s 271(1)(c) is being initiated separately for 
concealment of income & for furnishing inaccurate 
particulars of income.”  
 
20. We may note, that another coordinate bench of this 
Court, of which one of us [i.e., Rajiv Shakdher, J.] was a 
party has reached the same conclusion in PCIT vs. Minu 
Bakshi 222 (7) TMI 1370-Delhi. 21. Penalty proceedings 
entail civil consequences for the assessee. The AO is

indicate clearly, as to what is being put against the

proceedings.  
 
21. Penalty proceedings entail civil consequences for the 
assessee. The AO is required to apply his mind to the 
material particulars, and indicate clearly, as to what is 
being put against the respondent/assessee when triggering 
the penalty proceedings.

key_legal_points: The AO must specify the limb of Section 271(1)(c) under which penalty proceedings are triggered.

sections: Rule 29 of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal Rules, 1963
primary_legal_issue: Whether the delay of 465 days in re-filing the appeals can be condoned and whether the matter should be remitted to the Transfer Pricing Officer (TPO) for fresh consideration.
summary: The Delhi High Court disposed of the appeals filed by the Principal Commissioner of Income Tax against the order of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, which had remitted the matter to the Transfer Pricing Officer (TPO) for fresh consideration. The Court condoned the delay of 465 days in re-filing the appeals and allowed the appeals to be disposed of without prejudice to the rights and contentions of the parties.
facts: The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal had passed a common order dated 22.10.2018, remitting the matter to the TPO with a direction to decide the issues afresh, after consideration of the evidence filed by the assessee. The Tribunal had invoked Rule 29 of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal Rules, 1963, and admitted additional supporting evidence.
arguments: The appellant/revenue sought condonation of delay of 465 days in re-filing the appeals. The respondent/assessee did not appear in the proceedings.
judgment_reasoning: The Court considered the reasons given in the applications for condonation of delay and found them to be sufficient. The Court also noted that the matter required further examination by the TPO and that no prejudice would be caused to either side if the matter was remitted to the TPO.
key_legal_points: Condonation of delay under the Income Tax Act, 1961
Remand to the Transfer Pricing Officer (TPO) under Rule 29 of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal Rules, 1963
legal_issues: Whether the delay of 465 days in re-filing the appeals can be condoned
Whether the matter should be remitted to the TPO for fresh consideration

primary_legal_issue: Whether the plaintiff is entitled to amend the plaint to incorporate the shares of the parties on account of death of some of the original parties and for correction in suit valuation
summary: The plaintiff filed an application under Order VI Rule 17 of the Code of Civil Procedure to amend the plaint to incorporate the shares of the parties on account of death of some of the original parties and for correction in suit valuation. The defendant opposed the application on the grounds that it is barred by limitation and does not meet the requirements of Order VI Rule 17 CPC.
facts: The suit was filed in 1972 and has been pending for 50 years. The plaintiff seeks to amend the plaint to incorporate the shares of the parties on account of death of some of the original parties and for correction in suit valuation.
arguments: The defendant argued that the application is barred by limitation and does not meet the requirements of Order VI Rule 17 CPC. The plaintiff argued that the amendment is necessary for determining the real questions in controversy between the parties.
judgment_reasoning: The court held that the application is not barred by limitation as the amendment, if allowed, would relate back to the date of institution of the suit. The court also held that the amendment meets the requirements of Order VI Rule 17 CPC as it is necessary for determining the real questions in controversy between the parties.
key_legal_points: Order VI Rule 17 of the Code of Civil Procedure allows for amendment of pleadings at any stage of the proceedings
The amendment must be necessary for determining the real questions in controversy between the parties
The amendment, if allowed, relates back to the date of institution of the suit
legal_issues: Whether the application is barred by limitation
Whether the amendment meets the requirements of Order VI Rule 17 CPC
precedents_cited: Subhashini Malik vs. S.K.Gandhi (2016) 233 DLT83
SI Bullah Khan vs. Hairunisha Beevi & Ors.  2016-4-LW-430
