Through: Dr. Reema Salkan, R-2 in person and 
Power of Attorney Holder for R-1. 
CORAM:  
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL  
JUDGMENT  
AMIT BANSAL, J.  
1. The present petition under Article 227 of the Constitution of India 
seeks setting aside of (i) the order dated 6th February, 2018, whereby an 
application filed on behalf of the respondent no. 1/defendant no. 7 under 
Order I Rule 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC) seeking 
deletion from the array of parties has been allowed; and (ii)  the order dated 
12th July, 2018, whereby the review filed on behalf of the petitione r/plaintiff 
[hereinafter ‘plaintiff’] against the order dated 6th February, 2018 has been 
dismissed. 
2. Notice was issued in the present petition on 11th January, 2019 and 
pursuant thereto, counter affidavit has been filed on behalf of the  
respondents no. 1 and 2. Arguments of the counsels for the parties were  
heard on 16th December, 2021 and thereafter, the judgment was reserved. 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000117
 
CM(M) 37/2019                           Page 2 of 10 
 Pursuant to the liberty granted by the Court to both sides, w ritten 
submissions have been filed on behalf of the petitioner. 
3. Brief facts necessary for deciding the present petition are set out 
hereinafter: 
3.1  The plaintiff and the defendant no. 1 got married on 24th March, 2002 
but soon thereafter, the petitioner left for Canada. Differences arose  between 
them, which resulted in filing of police complaints by the d efendant no. 1 
against the plaintiff. 
3.2  On 3rd March, 2004 a ‘Red Corner Notice’ (RCN) was issued against 
the plaintiff, who, at that point of time was in Canada, in whic h it was 
incorrectly recorded that the maximum possible penalty for the of fences 
allegedly committed by the plaintiff was 10 years, whereas t he maximum 
punishment prescribed for the said offences under Sections 498A, 40 6 and 
34 of the Indian Penal Code, 1908 (IPC) was three years. 
3.3  The plaintiff filed a writ petition before this Court seeking quashi ng 
of the illegal RCN and the LOC issued against the plaintiff, bei ng W.P.Crl. 
1315/2008, and vide the order dated 11th August, 2010, this Court allowed 
the petition and quashed the RCN. 
3.4  The suit from which the present petition arises, being CS 58517/16, 
was filed on 10th August, 2011 seeking damages of Rs.50,00,000/- against, 
inter alia , the respondent no. 1, being defendant no. 7, and the respondent 
no. 2, being defendant no. 1, in the suit. 
3.5  The suit was premised on damage to the plaintiff’s career, rep utation 
and life caused by the misuse and abuse of the legal process i n getting a 
‘Look Out Circular’ (LOC) and RCN issued by the defendants ag ainst the 
plaintiff. 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000117
 
CM(M) 37/2019                           Page 3 of 10 
 3.6  The case set up in the plaint was that the defendant no. 1, who was 
married to the plaintiff, used her brother, defendant no. 7, who was a s enior 
IPS officer, to have a false FIR lodged and illegal LOC and RCN i ssued 
against the plaintiff, which caused immense harm to his career and  
reputation. 
3.7  The said suit was contested by the defendants by filing a writt en 
statement. In the said suit, the defendants no. 5 and 6 filed two a pplications 
under Order I Rule 10 of the CPC seeking deletion of their names from the  
array of parties and the Single Judge, vide judgment dated 20th February, 
2015 dismissed the application filed by the defendant no. 5 but allow ed the 
application filed by the defendant no. 6. However, vide judgment dated 1st 
February, 2016, a Division Bench of this Court deleted defendants no. 5 a nd 
6 from the array of parties. The plaintiff filed a Special Leave P etition 
against the said judgment, which is pending before the Supreme Court. 
3.8  On 29th February, 2016, the suit was transferred to the District Court. 
3.9  Thereafter, the defendants no. 1 and 7 filed a joint application u nder 
Order I Rule 10 and Order VII Rule 11(d) of the CPC seeking (i) the ir 
deletion from the array of parties; and, (ii) rejection of the  plaint. The 
impugned order dated 6th February, 2018 allowed the application partially 
by rejecting the plaint qua the defendant no. 7 and deleting the defendant no. 
7 from the array of parties. However, the plaint was not rejected  qua  the 
defendant no. 1. The impugned order held that: 
(i) in the whole plaint, there are vague allegations of collusion 
against the defendant no. 7; 
(ii)  no particulars have been given by the plaintiff as to how the 
defendant no. 7 was involved in issuing of LOC or RCN; 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000117
 
CM(M) 37/2019                           Page 4 of 10 
 (iii)  the defendant no. 7 being the brother of the defendant no. 1 and 
an IPS officer cannot be a ground to implead him in the suit  on the 
basis of vague allegations of collusion; 
(iv)  based on the aforesaid, it was held by the Trial Court that t here 
is no cause of action against the defendant no. 7 and hence, the pl aint 
qua him was rejected; 
(v)  the application under Order I Rule 10 of the CPC has been filed 
on the same grounds as the application filed under Order VII Rule 
11(a) of the CPC and accordingly, the defendant no. 7 was deleted 
from the array of parties. 
3.10 The plaintiff preferred a review application against the afores aid 
judgment of the Trial Court, which was dismissed by the i mpugned order 
dated 12th July, 2018 by observing that the judgment dated 11th august, 2020 
passed by this Court in W.P. Crl 1315/2008 does not help the case of  the 
plaintiff and there are no specific allegations against the de fendant no. 7 in 
the plaint. 
4. The counsel for the petitioner contended that (i) averments hav e been 
made against the defendant no. 7 with regard to his involvement and 
collusion with the defendant no. 1 so as to initiate various unl awful 
proceedings against the plaintiff, resulting in issuance of the R CN and the 
LOC. In this regard, attention of the Court is drawn to paragraphs 5 , 6 (xiv), 
(xxii), (xxvi), (xxvii), (xxviii), (xxxii), (xxxiii) (xxxix) and 9 of the plaint ; 
(ii) a Co-ordinate Bench of this Court in the judgment dated 11th August, 
2010 in W.P.Crl. No.1315/2008 quashed the RCN issued against the 
plaintiff and observed in paragraph 10 of the said judgment that the LOC 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000117
 
CM(M) 37/2019                           Page 5 of 10 
 against the plaintiff was issued in view of the fact that defend ant no. 7 was 
the brother of defendant no. 1 and also an IPS officer; and, (iii) accordingly, 
keeping in mind the principles to be applied while deciding an appli cation 
under Order I Rule 10 of the CPC, defendant no. 7 is a necessary and pr oper 
party to the suit and therefore, cannot be deleted from the array of parties. 
5. Defendant no.1 appeared in person on her own behalf as well as on 
behalf of the defendant no. 7 as his Power of Attorney Holder.  S he submits 
that (i) there is no infirmity in the impugned order as only vague averments 
have been made in respect of the defendant no. 7; (ii) there is no finding  in 
the judgment dated 11th August, 2010 against the defendant no. 7 and the 
observations in paragraph 10 relied upon by the plaintiff are only al legations 
made by the plaintiff and not findings of the Court.  Even otherwise, any  
observations made in the aforesaid judgment are not binding on the  
defendant no. 7 since the defendant no. 7 was not a party in aforesaid w rit 
petition; and, (iii) the defendant no.7 was not posted in Delhi at the relevant 
point of time and therefore, could not have played any role in the issuanc e of 
RCN and LOC against the plaintiff.  
6. I have perused the record and heard the counsels for the parties.   
7. In order to decide the controversy at hand, it may be useful to ref er to 
the principles to be applied while invoking principles of Order I Ru le 10 of 
the CPC.  Order I Rule 10(2) of the CPC empowers the Court to delete or 
add parties to the suit. In Vidur Impex and Traders Pvt. Ltd. & Ors. Vs. 
Tosh Apartments Pvt. Ltd. & Ors. , (2012) 8 SCC 384, the Supreme Court 
has succinctly laid down the principles to be followed while d eciding an 
application filed under Order I Rule 10(2) of the CPC.  Paragraph 36 in thi s 
regard is set out below: 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000117
 
CM(M) 37/2019                           Page 6 of 10 
 “36. Though there is apparent conflict in the observations mad e 
in some of the aforementioned judgments, the broad principles 
which should govern disposal of an application for impleadment 
are: 
 
1. The Court can, at any stage of the proceedings, either on an 
application made by the parties or otherwise, direct impleadment 
of any person as party, who ought to have been joined as 
Plaintiff or Defendant or whose presence before the Court is 
necessary for effective and complete adjudication of the issues 
involved in the suit. 
 
2. A necessary party is the person who ought to be joined a s 
party to the suit and in whose absence an effective decree 
cannot be passed by the Court. 
 
3. A proper party is a person whose presence would enable the  
Court to completely, effectively and properly adjudicate upon 
all matters and issues, though he may not be a person in favour 
of or against whom a decree is to be made. 
 
4. If a person is not found to be a proper or necessary party, the 
Court does not have the jurisdiction to order his impleadment 
against the wishes of the Plaintiff.” 
 
8. The Supreme Court in Mumbai International Airport Pvt. Ltd. Vs. 
Regency Convention Centre and Hotels Pvt. Ltd. & Ors. , (2010) 7 SCC 
417 has observed that the general rule in regard to impleadment of p arties is 
that the plaintiff in a suit, being dominus litis , may choose the persons 
against whom he wishes to litigate and cannot be compelled to s ue a person 
against whom he does not seek any relief.   
9. Applying the aforesaid principles to the present case, in my  view, a 
bare reading of the plaint discloses that the plaintiff has made a verments in 
the plaint against the defendant no. 7, which are sufficient in nature for the 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000117
 
CM(M) 37/2019                           Page 7 of 10 
 defendant no. 7 to be a necessary and a proper party for the adjudicat ion of 
the suit.  Some of the averments made in the plaint with re gard to defendant 
no. 7 are set out below: 
 “(xxii) The defendant No.1 using the contact network in the police 
and influence of her brother, Mr. Vikram Singh Mann, (who is a 
senior IPS officer) managed to get an illegal Look-Out-Circ ular 
(LOC) issued against the plaintiff on the 27.05.2003 by an  who was 
not even authorised to issue LOC. 
 
xxxx   xxxx   xxxx 
 
(xxvi) The defendant No.1 continued to harass the plaintiff and h is 
family in the garb of proceedings under Section 498-A/406/34 of IPC. 
The defendant No.l with ulterior motives has spurned every effo rt by 
the plaintiff/his family and their representatives to resolv e the matters 
in an amicable manner. Using her brother's, the defendant No.6, 
influence with the police, she managed to get an LOC issued against 
the plaintiff on 30.05.2003. After lodging the F.I.R No.127 of 2003 
dated 22.04.2003, a Red Corner Notice was also issued by 'lnte rpol 
on 03.03.2004 and displayed on internet containing wrong and

primary_legal_issue: Whether the property can be sold through public auction without payment of stamp duty
summary: The appeal arises from a partition suit filed in 2007 regarding a residential property. The decree was impugned, and a consent decree was passed, which has attained finality. The property was to be sold off through private sale, but since it did not materialize, it was directed to be sold through public auction. The appellant now contends that the decree is not executable due to non-payment of stamp duty.
facts: The partition suit was filed in 2007, and the decree was impugned in FAO(OS) 701-702/2010. The consent decree was passed, which directed the sale of the property through private sale or public auction. The parties agreed to make the court fee/stamp duty a first charge on the sale proceeds.
arguments: The appellant submits that the decree is not executable due to non-payment of stamp duty. The respondents argue that the property should be sold through public auction, and the first charge on the sale proceeds should be towards payment of stamp duty.
judgment_reasoning: The court holds that the compromise decree is clear that the property shall be disposed of at the best market price. The issue of stamp duty cannot be a stumbling block, as the first charge on the sale proceeds would be towards payment of stamp duty.
key_legal_points: The Stamp Act is a fiscal measure enacted to secure revenue for the State
The stringent provisions of the Act are conceived in the interest of the revenue
legal_issues: Whether the decree is executable without payment of stamp duty
Whether the property can be sold through public auction without payment of stamp duty

primary_legal_issue: Whether the 18‑year‑old unmarried daughter of the deceased is a dependent for purposes of loss‑of‑dependency compensation and the correct quantum of compensation payable.
summary: The appellants, Krishan Pal Mourya and others, appealed the award of the Motor Accident Claims Tribunal (MACT) dated 27‑03‑2018 which granted only Rs.50,000 as compensation on the ground that all claimants were adults and therefore not dependent on the deceased, Sh. Balak Ram. The accident involved a mini‑bus (DL‑1VA‑0384) driven at high speed, resulting in the death of the deceased. The appellants argued that the deceased's 18‑year‑old unmarried daughter was financially dependent and that the Tribunal erred in applying a nominal compensation. They relied on Supreme Court precedents (Sarla Verma, National Insurance Co. v. Birender) and a Punjab‑Haryana High Court decision (Oriental Insurance Co. v. Raj Rani) to establish dependency and appropriate quantum. The respondents contended that no documentary proof of the deceased’s income was produced. Justice Navin Chawla held that in the absence of income proof, the minimum wage for an unskilled worker (Rs.9,048 per month) should be used, applied a 10% future prospects factor, a half‑deduction for personal expenses, and a multiplier of 9, arriving at a loss‑of‑dependency award of Rs.5,37,500. Additional awards for loss of consortium, estate, and funeral expenses brought total compensation to Rs.7,27,500, less the Rs.50,000 already paid, resulting in enhanced compensation of Rs.6,77,500 with interest. The appeal was allowed and the enhanced amount ordered to be paid.
facts: The deceased, Sh. Balak Ram, a 56‑year‑old labourer, was walking with a companion when a mini‑bus (DL‑1VA‑0384) driven by respondent No.1 at high speed struck him, causing fatal injuries. The deceased was declared dead on arrival at the hospital. The claimants—his children and other relatives—filed a claim before the MACT. The Tribunal found the bus driver negligent but awarded only Rs.50,000, reasoning that the claimants were adults and not dependent on the deceased. The appellants challenged the quantum, asserting that the 18‑year‑old unmarried daughter was dependent and that the Tribunal failed to consider appropriate compensation heads.
arguments: Appellants: Asserted that the daughter (appellant No.4) was financially dependent, citing Sarla Verma and other Supreme Court rulings that unmarried daughters are presumed dependent. Requested compensation based on loss of dependency, loss of consortium, loss of estate, and funeral expenses. Submitted that in absence of income proof, minimum wages should be used for calculation. Respondents: Contended that no documentary evidence of the deceased’s income was produced, and therefore the Tribunal’s modest award was appropriate. Emphasized that the claimants were adults and not dependent.
judgment_reasoning: Justice Chawla examined precedent that dependency is not limited to minors; an unmarried daughter of 18 is presumed dependent. In the absence of income proof, the court adopted the minimum wage for an unskilled worker as the deceased’s earnings. Applying the 10% future prospects factor, a half‑deduction for personal expenses, and a multiplier of 9 (per Sarla Verma), the loss‑of‑dependency was calculated at Rs.5,37,500. The court further awarded loss of consortium, loss of estate, and funeral expenses as per Supreme Court guidance in Pranay Sethi and United India Insurance cases. Interest at 9% per annum was ordered, and the enhanced compensation was directed to be paid within six weeks.
key_legal_points: An unmarried daughter of 18 is presumed financially dependent on the deceased
In absence of income proof, minimum wage rates may be used to determine earnings
Loss of dependency is calculated using future prospects (10%), personal deduction (½), and multiplier (9)
Compensation heads include loss of dependency, loss of consortium, loss of estate, and funeral expenses
Interest accrues on enhanced compensation at 9% per annum

1. This appeal has been filed challenging the Award dated

passed by the learned Motor Accident Claims Tribunal, (Pilot 
Court), Karkardooma Courts, Delhi (hereinafter referred to as 
the ‘Tribunal’)  in MACT No. 15441/15, titled Krishan Pal 
Mourya & Ors. v. Ravinder Kumar & Ors .   
2. It was the case of the claimants before the learned 
Tribunal that their father, Sh.Balak Ram (hereinafter referred to 
as the ‘Deceased ’) along with one Nafees was going towards IT 
Park from Jamuna Khadar on foot. As they reached IT Park Red

Resultantly, the deceased fell down on the road and sustained 
fatal injuries. Though he was rushed to Dr. Jag Parvesh Chand 
Hospital, Shastri Park by the CAT Ambulance, he was declared 
as brought dead.  
3. The learned Tribunal, on appreciation of evidence led 
before it, came to a conclusion that the accident had taken place 
due to the Offending Vehicle being driven in a rash and 
negligent manner. However, on the quantum of compensation to 
be awarded to the appellants, the learned Tribunal held that as  
all the claimants were major, they could not be considered as 
dependent on the deceased and, therefore, awarded only a sum 
of Rs.50,000/- as compensation, relying upon the judgment of 
the Supreme Court in Manjuri Bera v. Oriental Insurance Co. 
Ltd., (2007) 10 SCC 643.  
4. The limited challenge of the appellants to the Impugned 
Award is on the quantum of compensation awarded in their 
favour.  
5. The learned counsel for the appellants submits that the 
appellant no.4, the daughter of the deceased was aged only 18 
years and was unmarried. She was clearly dependent on the 
income of the father, that is, the deceased. He submits that t he 
appellant no. 1 appeared before the learned Tribunal as PW-1,

 and deposed that the appellants were dependent on the incom e 
of the deceased. He submits that in terms of the judgment of t he 
Supreme Court in Sarla Verma (Smt) and Others v. Delhi 
Transport Corporation and Another , (2009) 6 SCC 121, the 
appellant no. 4 would be dependent on the deceased and his 
income, by deducting one half of the income of the deceased 
towards personal expenses, should have been taken into 
consideration for awarding the compensation to the appellants. 
6. On the other hand, the learned counsel for respondent 
no.3 submits that there was no document filed by the appell ants 
to prove the income of the deceased.  
7. I have considered the submissions made by the learned 
counsels for the parties. 
8. In National Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Birender , (2020) 11 
SCC 356, the Supreme Court has held as under:-  
“14. It is thus settled by now that the legal 
representatives of the deceased have a right to 
apply for compensation. Having said that, it 
must necessarily follow that even the major 
married and earning sons of the deceased 
being legal representatives have a right to 
apply for compensation and it would be the 
bounden duty of the Tribunal to consider the 
application irrespective of the fact whether the 
legal representative concerned was fully 
dependent on the deceased and not to limit the 
claim towards conventional heads only. The 
evidence on record in the present case would 
suggest that the claimants were working as 
agricultural labourers on contract basis and 
were earning meagre income between Rs 
1,00,000 and Rs 1,50,000 per annum. In that 
sense, they were largely dependent on the 
Digitally Signed By:SUNIL

16:06:32Signature Not Verified
                                                                                 
  
MAC.APP. 77/2019       Page 4 of 8 
 earning of their mother and in fact, were 
staying with her, who met with an accident at 
the young age of 48 years. ” 
9. In Oriental Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Raj Rani , 2022 SCC 
OnLine P&H 3673, the High Court of Punjab and Haryana, 
while dealing with a similar issue, held as under:- 
“19. I find that though no fault can be found 
with the observations by the Tribunal that 
claimant Sanju Kumar could not be taken to be 
dependent upon earnings of the deceased for 
the reason that he had attained majority but 
same cannot be said to be true with regard to 
claimant Shavnam, aged about 21 years, an 
unmarried daughter of the deceased. There is 
nothing on record to show that Shavnam is 
engaged in any avocation or has any source of 
income. Therefore, she should have been taken 
to be dependent family member of the 
deceased. As has been generally observed, an 
unmarried daughter of the age of 21 years is 
financially dependent upon her parents and 
rather father in most of the cases, for meeting 
her basis needs. Most girls in that age group 
are usually students and after completion of 
studies, they are to be married off by the 
parents bearing the necessary expenses. 
Therefore, observing that Shavnam was not

view taken by the Tribunal. The Tribunal has 
however found Smt. Raj Rani - widow and

10. As noted hereinabove, PW-1 Sh. Krishan Pal Maurya had 
stated that appellant no.4 was aged only 18 years and was

The learned Tribunal has, therefore, erred in not treating the

11. As it would be a case of a single dependent, one half of

case_type: Arbitration Appeal under Section 37 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996
primary_legal_issue: Whether the collaboration agreements filed by the respondent were forged and whether the appellate court should set aside the Single Judge’s modification of the arbitral award.
summary: The Delhi High Court examined an appeal filed by Tejpal Singh under Section 37 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, challenging a Single Judge’s order that partially modified an arbitral award arising from a collaboration agreement dated 03.05.2005 concerning a property at Model Town, Delhi. The respondent, Surinder Kumar Dewan, claimed ownership of the property and alleged that the appellant failed to complete construction, erected an unauthorized third floor, and caused demolition and sealing of the building, leading to multiple monetary claims (Claims A‑E). The appellant contested the authenticity of two collaboration agreements filed by the respondent, alleging forgery, while the respondent asserted the agreements were genuine. The arbitrator, after cross‑examination, concluded the appellant’s signatures on the documents were authentic, rejecting the forgery claim. The High Court upheld this finding, noting that the arbitrator’s view was a permissible interpretation of the evidence. Consequently, the Court affirmed the Single Judge’s decision to retain the award’s modifications, including the reduced monthly payment of Rs.35,000 and the upholding of other award directions. The appeal was dismissed, confirming the validity of the arbitration process and the authenticity of the collaboration agreement used as the basis for the award.
facts: The respondent owned property A‑2/5 (450 sq. yards) and entered into a collaboration agreement with the appellant on 03.05.2005 to demolish the existing structure and construct a new building. The agreement stipulated construction within 12 months, cost sharing, and allocation of floors. The appellant allegedly built an unauthorized third floor, leading to demolition by the Municipal Corporation of Delhi (MCD) and sealing of the property. The respondent terminated the agreement on 11.05.2007 and invoked the arbitration clause. The arbitrator awarded the respondent various monetary sums (Claims A‑E) for rent, damages, demolition costs, etc. The Single Judge later modified the award, setting aside Claim A and limiting Claim B to Rs.35,000 per month. The appellant appealed, challenging the authenticity of two agreements filed by the respondent and the award modification.
arguments: Appellant argued that the two collaboration agreements filed by the respondent were forged, citing discrepancies in signatures and cuttings. The respondent contended that the agreements were genuine, that the appellant had signed all pages, and that the arbitrator’s findings on authenticity were correct. The appellant also sought reversal of the Single Judge’s modification of the award. The respondent relied on the arbitrator’s acceptance of the agreements and the contractual obligations breached by the appellant, seeking enforcement of the award as modified.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the cross‑examination records and found that the appellant had admitted his signatures on the disputed agreement (Ex.CW‑1/C) and on the cuttings, undermining his claim of forgery. The arbitrator’s conclusion that the agreement was authentic was deemed a permissible view of the evidence. Consequently, the Court held that there was no ground to interfere with the arbitrator’s findings or the Single Judge’s partial modification of the award. The appeal was dismissed, confirming the award’s validity as modified.
key_legal_points: The authenticity of a contract is determined by the parties' admissions and signature comparison.
An arbitrator's view of evidence is entitled to deference unless manifestly erroneous.
Section 37 of the Arbitration Act permits judicial review of arbitral awards on limited grounds.
Partial modification of an award by a lower court can be upheld on appeal if based on sound reasoning.
legal_issues: Forgery and authenticity of the collaboration agreements
Whether the Single Judge correctly exercised power to modify the arbitral award
Scope of judicial review under Section 37 of the Arbitration Act

primary_legal_issue: Whether the Tribunal erred in remanding the matter to the Assessing Officer despite the CIT(A) having exercised powers under Section 250(4) of the Income Tax Act and whether Rule 46A of the Income Tax Rules was applicable.
summary: International Tractors Ltd appealed against the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal’s order remanding its claims for deduction under Section 80JJAA and prior‑period expenses to the Assessing Officer (AO). The appellant argued that the Commissioner of Income Tax (Appeals) [CIT(A)] was empowered by Section 250(4) to entertain fresh claims and that the Tribunal’s direction to re‑verify the claims violated procedural law, particularly Rule 46A, which the appellant claimed was inapplicable because the evidence was produced by the CIT(A) and not the assessee. The revenue contended that the claims were invalid as the statutory accountant’s report required under Section 80JJAA was absent at the time of filing, justifying the Tribunal’s remand. The Court examined the factual matrix, the statutory provisions, and precedents such as Smt. Prabhavati S. Shah v. CIT, B.L. Choudhury v. CIT, and Goetze (India) Ltd v. CIT. It held that the CIT(A) had correctly exercised its powers under Section 250(4) and that the Tribunal’s remand was unnecessary. Consequently, the appeal was disposed of in favour of the appellant, setting aside the Tribunal’s order and directing that the deductions be allowed as per the CIT(A)’s findings.
facts: International Tractors Ltd, engaged in manufacturing tractors, filed its AY 2007‑08 return without claiming deductions under Section 80JJAA or prior‑period expenses. On 14‑12‑2009 it submitted a statement with a chartered accountant’s report (Form 10DA) claiming a deduction of Rs.1,07,33,164 under Section 80JJAA and Rs.51,21,024 for prior‑period expenses. The AO rejected both claims, leading to an appeal before the CIT(A), which allowed the claims. The revenue appealed to the Tribunal, which upheld the CIT(A)’s allowance but remanded the matter to the AO for fresh verification and an opportunity of hearing.
arguments: Appellant (International Tractors Ltd) argued that the CIT(A) was empowered by Section 250(4) to make fresh inquiries and that Rule 46A did not apply because the evidence was produced by the CIT(A), not the assessee. Revenue argued that the absence of the accountant’s report at the time of filing made the claim invalid under the pre‑amendment provisions of Section 80JJAA and that the Tribunal was correct in directing re‑verification by the AO.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the scope of Section 250(4) and held that the CIT(A) could indeed entertain fresh claims and direct production of evidence. It found that Rule 46A was inapplicable where the CIT(A) itself directed the evidence, distinguishing it from the procedural requirements applicable to the assessee. The Court also noted that the revenue’s reliance on the pre‑amendment requirement was misplaced, as the CIT(A)’s order was issued after the amendment and complied with the statutory conditions. Consequently, the Tribunal’s remand was deemed unnecessary and contrary to law.
key_legal_points: Section 250(4) empowers the CIT(A) to entertain fresh claims and direct evidence.
Rule 46A of the Income Tax Rules is not applicable when the CIT(A) initiates evidence production.
The Tribunal cannot remand a matter already properly adjudicated by the CIT(A).
Amendments to Section 80JJAA by Finance Act 2016 affect the applicability of pre‑amendment requirements.
legal_issues: Whether the Tribunal erred in remanding the case to the AO after the CIT(A) allowed the claims.
Whether Rule 46A applies to the evidence produced at the CIT(A)’s direction.
Interpretation of Section 250(4) in relation to fresh claims.

case_type: Application for Remand of Tribunal Award
primary_legal_issue: Whether the award dated 11‑09‑2018 should be set aside and remitted to the tribunal for fresh assessment of compensation in view of newly submitted disability certificate and educational records.
summary: The Delhi High Court, on 20 September 2021, heard MAC.APP.134/2019, an application filed by Ratan Majumdar (appellant) seeking a remit to the tribunal to lead additional evidence concerning his permanent disability and academic status. The appellant challenged the award dated 11 September 2018 on the ground that a disability certificate was not available at the time of the award and that his educational records, necessary for assessing future loss of income, were missing. The Court noted that the Medical Superintendent of Jag Pravesh Chandra Hospital had, on 5 February 2019, forwarded a disability certificate indicating a 40% permanent disability of the appellant's lower limbs. The appellant also produced his educational documents thereafter. The Court observed that the original award made no reference to permanent disability or future loss of income and had assessed income on the basis of unskilled workers' minimum wage. Consequently, the Court set aside the impugned award, remitted the matter to the tribunal to consider the new evidence, and directed that the tribunal pass a fresh award, taking into account the amount already released and the certified disability certificate. The appeal was disposed of in the appellant's favour.
facts: The appellant, Ratan Majumdar, was awarded compensation on 11‑09‑2018 by a tribunal concerning a motor accident. At the time of the award, a disability certificate was not available because the appellant had not been examined by a disability board. Subsequent directions by the Court on 22‑01‑2019 led to the formation of a medical board, which on 5‑02‑2019 issued a certificate confirming 40% permanent disability of the appellant's lower limbs. The appellant also later produced his educational records, which were absent during the original award. The original award did not discuss permanent disability or future loss of income and used a benchmark of minimum wage for unskilled workers to assess monthly income.
arguments: The appellant argued that the absence of a disability certificate and educational records at the time of the award rendered the compensation assessment incomplete and that the tribunal should reassess compensation, including future loss of income, based on the newly submitted evidence. The appellant contended that the tribunal erred by not considering permanent disability and by using an inappropriate wage benchmark. The respondents did not contest the submission of the disability certificate but raised no substantive objection to the remand.
judgment_reasoning: Justice Sanjeev Sachdeva held that the lack of consideration of permanent disability and future loss of income in the original award constituted a material omission. The newly submitted disability certificate (40% permanent disability) and educational records warranted a fresh assessment. Accordingly, the award dated 11‑09‑2018 was set aside, and the matter was remitted to the tribunal to lead additional evidence and pass a fresh award, taking into account the amount already released and the certified disability certificate.
key_legal_points: Award must consider permanent disability when assessing compensation.
Future loss of income can be quantified based on the claimant's educational qualifications.
Newly submitted evidence after an award can justify remand for fresh assessment.
Tribunal's award can be set aside if material factors were omitted.
legal_issues: Whether the tribunal erred by not considering permanent disability.
Whether the omission of educational records affected the assessment of future loss of income.
Whether the award can be remitted for fresh consideration in light of new evidence.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the conviction of the appellant for murder under Section 302 IPC can be sustained despite the hostile testimony of key eyewitnesses and reliance on circumstantial evidence.
summary: The appellant Nadeem appealed against a trial‑court judgment dated 10 September 2018 that convicted him of murder under Section 302 IPC and sentenced him to life imprisonment and a fine. The incident concerned the killing of his wife Shabana on the night of 10‑11 April 2012 at their residence in Sarai Mahal, Delhi, allegedly by thrusting a screwdriver into her head. The prosecution relied on the statements of several witnesses, including two primary eye‑witnesses (PW‑3 and PW‑6) who later turned hostile, medical evidence establishing a homicidal death, and testimonies establishing motive and prior quarrels. The appellant contended that the hostile witnesses rendered the case purely circumstantial, lacking direct evidence such as a last‑seen statement, recovery of the weapon, or fingerprints, and argued that the trial court’s reliance on Section 106 of the Indian Evidence Act was erroneous. The prosecution countered that the appellant failed to produce a credible alibi and that the cumulative evidence, including motive, medical findings, and corroborative family testimonies, satisfied the burden of proof. The appellate bench examined the admissibility and weight of the hostile testimonies, the applicability of Sections 106 and 313 CrPC, and relevant precedents. Ultimately, the court upheld the trial‑court’s conviction, finding the evidence sufficient to sustain the murder charge.
facts: On 10‑11 April 2012, Shabana was found dead at her Delhi residence with a screwdriver wound to the head. Police were alerted by PW‑6 (Abrar Mirza) after PW‑3 (Ballu Qureshi) reported the incident. The deceased’s family members testified to cohabitation with the appellant and a history of violent quarrels. Medical examination confirmed a homicidal death. The appellant claimed he was sleeping at home until his arrest on 11 April and presented an alibi witness (DW‑1).
arguments: Appellant argued that the two primary eye‑witnesses turned hostile, leaving only circumstantial evidence without direct proof, and that reliance on Section 106 Indian Evidence Act was improper. He cited Mangu Singh v. Dharmendra, Reena Hazarika v. State of Assam, and Md. Yunis Ali Tarafdar v. State of West Bengal. Prosecution maintained that the cumulative evidence—hostile but still admissible testimonies, medical proof, motive, prior complaints, and failure to produce a credible alibi—satisfied the burden of proof, and that the appellant bore the onus under Section 106 to explain the circumstances.
judgment_reasoning: The bench held that hostile witness statements, while diminishing probative value, do not render evidence inadmissible if corroborated by other material. The medical evidence established homicide, and the series of family testimonies demonstrated motive and prior threats. The appellant’s alibi was discredited by the investigating officer’s testimony. Applying the principles of Sections 106 and 313 CrPC, the court concluded that the prosecution had discharged the burden of proof beyond reasonable doubt, and the conviction was upheld.
key_legal_points: Hostile witness testimony can be admitted if corroborated
Section 106 Indian Evidence Act places burden on accused to explain adverse circumstances
Medical evidence confirming homicide is decisive
Cumulative circumstantial evidence can sustain a murder conviction
legal_issues: Admissibility and weight of hostile eyewitness statements
Whether the prosecution met the burden of proof under Section 302 IPC
Application of Section 106 Indian Evidence Act in murder trials

case_type: Condonation of delay (Regular First Appeal) under Limitation Act, 1963
primary_legal_issue: Whether the 1150‑day delay in filing the appeal can be condoned under Section 5 of the Limitation Act, 1963.
summary: The Kolkata Municipal Corporation & Anr filed a Regular First Appeal (RFA) seeking condonation of a 1,150‑day delay in filing an appeal against a decree dated 17‑09‑2015 in Civil Suit No. 1090/2013. The appellants argued that the delay was due to a genuine belief that the suit would be transferred to the Calcutta High Court because of territorial jurisdiction issues, and that they only learned of the decree when execution proceedings were initiated in 2017. The respondents contended that the appellants offered no sufficient cause, relying on precedents that stress strict adherence to limitation periods. The Delhi High Court examined Section 5 of the Limitation Act, the doctrine of substantial justice, and several Supreme Court decisions interpreting "sufficient cause". The Court emphasized that condonation is discretionary, requires a showing of sufficient cause, and must balance technical limitation rules against the ends of justice. Applying these principles, the Court found the appellants’ belief to be bona‑fide and not deliberate, and consequently allowed the condonation of delay, permitting the appeal to proceed on its merits.
facts: The appellants, Kolkata Municipal Corporation & Anr, were parties to Civil Suit No. 1090/2013. A decree was passed on 17‑09‑2015. Believing the case would be transferred to the Calcutta High Court due to jurisdictional concerns, they did not file an appeal. They only became aware of the decree when an execution petition was filed in March 2017. An application under Order IX Rule 13 CPC to set aside the ex‑parte decree was dismissed on 05‑10‑2018. The regular first appeal was finally filed in December 2018, resulting in a delay of 1,150 days.
arguments: Appellants: The delay was caused by a genuine, bona‑fide belief that the suit would be transferred to the Calcutta High Court; there was no intentional or negligent delay; they sought condonation under Section 5 of the Limitation Act. Respondents: The appellants failed to show sufficient cause; reliance on erroneous legal advice does not constitute material grounds; the delay should be dismissed per established precedent.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the purpose of limitation statutes—preventing stale claims—and the discretionary power under Section 5 to condone delay when sufficient cause is shown. It cited Supreme Court jurisprudence emphasizing substantial justice, the elastic nature of "sufficient cause," and the need for a pragmatic, non‑pedantic approach. The Court held that the appellants’ belief about jurisdictional transfer, though mistaken, was made in good faith and not a product of deliberate neglect. Consequently, the Court exercised its discretion to condone the delay, allowing the appeal to be heard on its merits.
key_legal_points: Section 5 of the Limitation Act allows condonation of delay upon showing sufficient cause
"Sufficient cause" is an elastic concept interpreted to further substantial justice
Delay caused by genuine misapprehension of jurisdiction can constitute sufficient cause
Condonation is discretionary, not a matter of right
The court must balance technical limitation rules against the ends of justice
legal_issues: Whether the appellants have demonstrated sufficient cause for the 1,150‑day delay
Whether the court’s discretion under Section 5 can be exercised in favor of the appellants
Impact of jurisdictional misunderstanding on the assessment of delay

1. The appellants have filed the present appeal challenging  the 
judgment and decree dated  17.09.2015 passed by the learned Single 
Judge of this court in Civil Suit No. 1090/2013 titled as  M/s Rana 
Chairs V Director General (Town Planning), Kolkata Municipal

 2. The appellants filed the present application under Section 5 of 
Limitation Act, 1963 for condonation of delay of 1150 days i n filing 
present appeal. The appellants pleaded that appellant no. 1 di d not 
participate in the proceedings pertaining to suit no. 1090/2 013 under 
genuine belief that the case would be transferred to the High C ourt of 
Calcutta due to lack of territorial jurisdiction in court at D elhi. The 
appellants came to know about passing of the judgment and decree  
dated 17.05.2015 on 08.03.2017 in execution petition no 5  of 2017 
which was preferred by the respondent no. 1 before High Court of 
Calcutta when the appellants received notice of said execution 
proceedings. The appellants filed an application bearing IA No . 
4956/2016 under Order IX Rule 13 CPC for setting aside the ex-parte  
judgment and decree dated 17.09.2015 which was dismissed by  the 
learned Single Judge vide judgment dated 05.10.2018. The ap pellants 
also decided to prefer the Regular First Appeal (RFA) which was 
accordingly prepared by the counsel for the appellants and draft of 
RFA was sent to the concerned department for vetting and signi ng of 
the affidavits in the month of November, 2018. The appeal was fi led 
in December, 2018. The delay on part of the appellants in filing 
present appeal was owing to genuine and bona fide  belief that the suit 
would be transferred to the High Court of Calcutta due to lack  of 
territorial jurisdiction in court at Delhi. The delay of 1150  days was 
neither intentional nor deliberate. It was prayed that delay of 1 150 
days in filing present appeal be condoned. 
3. The respondent no. 1 submitted that the appellants did n ot show 
sufficient cause for condonation of delay of 1150 days in filing pre sent

 appeal but took flimsy ground of wrong legal advice for cond onation 
of delay which is lacking material particulars. The application for  
condonation of delay is without any merit and be dismiss ed. The 
respondent no. 1 relied on Popat Bahiri Govardhane &  Others V 
Special Land Acquisition  Officer &  Another,  2013 (10) SCC 765 ;  
Office of  the Chief Post Master General &  Others V  Living 
Media Ltd &  Another, AIR 2012 SC  1506 and The State of 
Madhya Pradesh &  Others V Bherulal, 2020 (10) SCC 654. 
4. The Law of limitation is based on equitable princip le that a 
litigant should be prompt in claiming the relief in  legal 
proceedings and is required to bury acts of the past whic h become 
stale due to lapse of time and have not been agitated withi n time. 
Section 3 of the Act, provides that every suit, appeal and applicat ion if 
filed or instituted after the prescribed period is liable to be di smissed 
although limitation has not been set up as a defence. Section 5  of the 
Act deals with the extension of prescribed period of limitat ion. The 
Court with discretionary jurisdiction can condone the delay and  
proceed with the case if concerned party furnishes sufficient cause f or 
delay in institution of appeal and application. Section 5  of the 
Limitation Act reads as under:- 
5. Extension of prescribed period in certain cases. —Any 
appeal or any application, other than an application under 
any of the provisions of Order XXI of the Code of Civil 
Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908), may be admitted after the 
prescribed period, if the appellant or the applicant satisfies the 
court that he had sufficient cause for not preferring the appeal 
or making the application within such period.

 Explanation. — The fact that the appellant or the applicant 
was misled by any order, practice or judgment of the High 
Court in ascertaining or computing the prescribed period may 
be sufficient cause within the meaning of this section. 
 
5. The ter m “sufficient cause” as appearing in Section 5 of the Act 
is not defined and is required to be interpreted to advance cau se of 
justice. The Supreme Court in Ramlal, Motilal and Chhotelal V 
Rewa Coalfields Ltd, 1962 SCR (3) 762 connected Section 5 of the 
Act with doctrine of substantial justice and observed as under:- 
In construing S.5, it is relevant to bear in mind two important 
considerations. The first consideration is that the expiration of 
the period of limitation prescribed for making an appeal gives 
rise to a right in favour of the decree-holder to treat the decree 
as binding between the parties. In other words, when the 
period of limitation prescribed has expired the decree-holder 
has obtained a benefit under the law of limitation to treat the 
decree as beyond challenge, and this legal right which has 
accrued to the decree-holder by lapse of time should not be 
light-heartedly disturbed. The other consideration which 
cannot be ignored is that if sufficient cause for excusing delay 
is shown discretion is given to the Court to condone delay and 
admit the appeal. This discretion has been deliberately 
conferred on the Court in order that judicial power and 
discretion in that behalf should be exercised to advance 
substantial justice.  
6. The Supreme Court in  Collector Land Acquisition V Mst. 
Katiji & others, 1987 SCR (2) 387 observed that the legislature has 
conferred the power to condone delay by enacting Section 5 of the 
Limitation Act in order to enable the Courts to do substantial ju stice to 
parties by disposing of matters on merits. The expression “sufficient 
cause ” is adequately elastic to enable the Courts to apply the law in a 
Digitally Signed
By:HARVINDER KAUR
BHATIA
Signing Date:05.07.2022
16:59:49Signature Not Verified
 
  
RFA(OS) 8/2019                          Page 5 of 35  
 meaningful manner which sub-serves the ends of justice which is 
being the life-purpose for the existence of the institution of Co urts. 
The Supreme Court laid down certain principles which need to be  
followed while employing doctrine of condonation of delay wh ich are 
as under:- 
1. Ordinarily a litigant does not stand to benefit by lodging an 
appeal late. 
2. Refusing to condone delay can result in a meritorious 
matter being thrown out at the very threshold and cause of 
justice being defeated. As against this when delay is condoned 
the highest that can happen is that a cause would be decided 
on merits after hearing the parties. 
3. "Every day's delay must be explained" does not mean that a 
pedantic approach should be made. Why not every hour's 
delay, every second's delay? The doctrine must be applied in a 
rational common sense pragmatic manner. 
4. When substantial justice and technical considerations are 
pitted against each other, cause of substantial justice deserves 
to be preferred for the other side cannot claim to have vested 
right in injustice being done because of a non-deliberate delay. 
5. There is no presumption that delay is occasioned 
deliberately, or on account of culpable negligence, or on 
account of mala fides. A litigant does not stand to benefit by 
resorting to delay. In fact he runs a serious risk. 
6. It must be grasped that judiciary is respected not on 
account of its power to legalize injustice on technical grounds 
but because it is capable of removing injustice and is expected 
to do so. 
7.  It must be noted that no party can claim condonation of del ay 
even if sufficient cause has been made out in the facts of a give n case. 
It was held in Ramlal, Motilal and Chhotelal V Rewa Coalfields 
Ltd. as under:- 
Digitally Signed
By:HARVINDER KAUR
BHATIA
Signing Date:05.07.2022
16:59:49Signature Not Verified
 
  
RFA(OS) 8/2019                          Page 6 of 35  
 It is, however, necessary to emphasize that even after 
sufficient cause has been shown a party is not entitled to the 
condonation of delay in question as a matter of right. The 
proof of a sufficient cause is a condition precedent for the 
exercise of the discretionary jurisdiction vested in the court by 
S. 5. If sufficient cause is not proved nothing further has to be 
done; the application for condoning delay has to be dismissed 
on that ground alone. If sufficient cause is shown then the 
Court has to enquire whether in its discretion it should 
condone the delay. This aspect of the matter naturally 
introduces the consideration of all relevant facts and it is at 
this stage that diligence of the party or its bona fides may fall 
for consideration; but the scope of the enquiry while 
exercising the discretionary power after sufficient cause is 
shown would naturally be limited only to such facts as the 
Court may regard as relevant. It cannot justify an enquiry as 
to why the party was sitting idle during all the time available 
to it.  
8.  The Supreme Court in Ramlal, Motilal and Chhotelal V Rewa 
Coalfields Ltd. also considered condonation in relation to delay 
caused in filing an appeal by the State and observed as under:- 
Making a justice-oriented approach from this perspective, 
there was sufficient cause for condoning the delay in the 
institution of the appeal. The fact that it was the 'State' 
which was seeking condonation and not a private party was 
altogether irrelevant. The doctrine of equality before law 
demands that all litigants, including the State as a litigant, 
are accorded the same treatment and the law is 
administered in an even handed manner. There is no 
warrant for according a step motherly treatment when the 
'State' is the applicant praying for condonation of delay. In 
fact experience shows that on account of an impersonal 
machinery (no one in charge of the matter is directly hit or 
hurt by the judgment sought to be subjected to appeal) and 
the inherited bureaucratic methodology imbued with the 
note-making, file pushing, and passing-on-the-buck ethos,

BHATIA

 delay on its part is less difficult to understand though more 
difficult to approve. In any event, the State which represents 
the collective cause of the community does not deserve a 
litigant-non-grata status. The Courts therefore have to be 
informed with the spirit and philosophy of the provision in 
the course of the interpretation of the expression "sufficient 
cause". 
9. The Supreme Court after relying on  Postmaster General V 
Living Media India Ltd.,  (2012) 3 SCC 563 in Government of

primary_legal_issue: Whether the High Court can set aside the Labour Court's award and enquiry findings on the ground of violation of natural justice under Article 226.
summary: The petitioner, Shri Raja Ram, a senior foreman at Delhi Transport Corporation's Dwarka Depot, filed W.P.(C) 895/2019 seeking quashing of a Labour Court order dated 26.08.2017 and the award dated 21.09.2017 that dismissed his claim. The dispute arose from an incident on 12.10.2011 when a bus (DL-1PC-7709) entered the depot in an accidental condition. The petitioner was alleged to have failed to get the bus repaired or to list it as a held‑up bus, resulting in the bus being taken out without repair. He contended that a false report by Sh. Dinesh Thakur led to a charge‑sheet, an enquiry that found him guilty despite contradictory witness statements, and a subsequent show‑cause notice that resulted in the stoppage of two annual increments. The respondent argued that the petitioner neglected his duty, and the Labour Court, after examining evidence, held the enquiry complied with natural justice. The High Court, relying on precedents that the Labour Court is the final fact‑finder and that writ jurisdiction under Article 226 is supervisory, declined to re‑appraise evidence or substitute its view. Finding no merit in the writ petition, the Court dismissed it.
facts: Petitioner Raja Ram was senior foreman at Dwarka Depot‑2. On 12.10.2011 a bus arrived in accidental condition. He was responsible for arranging repair or placing the bus in the held‑up list. He allegedly failed to do so, allowing the bus to be taken out without repair. A charge‑sheet was filed based on a report by Sh. Dinesh Thakur. An enquiry officer found Raja Ram guilty, leading to a show‑cause notice and stoppage of two annual increments. The departmental appeal was dismissed. The petitioner raised an industrial dispute, which was referred to the Labour Court.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the Labour Court did not consider material evidence, particularly the report of Sh. Dinesh Thakur, and that the enquiry violated principles of natural justice. He sought quashing of the award and the order. Respondent contended that the Labour Court examined all documents, found the petitioner negligent for not repairing or listing the bus, and that the award was in accordance with law.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the Labour Court is the final arbiter of facts and its findings, having been made after a thorough appreciation of evidence, cannot be re‑appraised by the writ court absent exceptional circumstances. The writ jurisdiction under Article 226 is supervisory, not appellate. Citing Parshuram Shah v GNCTD, Indian Overseas Bank v IOB Staff Canteen Workers, and Avatar Singh Hit v Delhi Sikh Gurudwara Management Committee, the Court emphasized that re‑evaluation of evidence without sufficient cause is beyond the scope of Article 226. Consequently, the petition lacked substance and was dismissed.
key_legal_points: Labour Court is the final fact‑finder in industrial disputes.
Writ jurisdiction under Article 226 is supervisory, not appellate.
Re‑appraisal of evidence by a writ court is permissible only in exceptional cases.
Petitioner failed to demonstrate violation of natural justice sufficient to set aside the award.
legal_issues: Whether the enquiry complied with principles of natural justice.
Whether the writ court can interfere with a Labour Court award under Article 226.

1. Present petition has been filed seeking quashing and setti ng aside the 
order dated 26.08.2017 passed by the learned labour court deci ding the 
preliminary issue and against the award dated 21.09.2017 whereb y the 
claim petition being filed by the petitioner was dismissed.

in Dwarka Depot -2. On 12.10.2011, while the petitioner was  on duty 
Bus No.DL1PC 7709 came in the Depot in an accidental condition .  
Foreman of the general shift, Sh.Dinesh Singh was asked to get  the bus 
repaired and the bus was parked in the depot for repairing.  The

despite contradiction in the statement of the witnesses.  The grievance 
of the petitioner is that acting upon the enquiry report, a show cause 
notice was issued and the department without taking into acc ount his

repaired and nor kept it in held up list and due to that reason, the bus 
had out shedded on 12.10.2011 at 2.40 p.m..  The managemen t has 
alleged that by not getting the bus repaired and by not menti oning the 
same in the held up buses, the petitioner had shown negligence. 
4. The labour court initially framed a preliminary issue so as to ascert ain 
whether the enquiry was conducted in accordance with the principles of 
natural justice. It was inter alia held that the enquiry was held  in 
accordance with principles of natural justice.  Learned counsel for th e 
petitioner has submitted that in fact, the labour court has not co nsidered 
the material on record and therefore, the order is liable to be set aside.  
It has further been submitted that the respondent management has  not 
furnished the report of Sh.Dinesh Thakur which was a material

5.  Plea of the learned counsel for the respondent is that the labou r court 
had taken into account all the documents and has passed th e order in

indicates that the learned Labour court has considered all the material 
on record and inter alia passed the order as under: 
 “8. From the deposition of witnesses produced by 
management and claimant before Enquiry Officer, it becomes

    It has been admitted by claimant in statement of cla im

intimation report thereof. It has further been admitted that the

to get the bus rectified or to put the same in held up category. 
Why he buckled under the pressure of Sh. Dinesh Singh 
Thakur? By bowing before Sh. Dinesh Singh Thakur, he did 
not do his duty. He cannot be allowed to say that he put th e

6. This court in the case of Parshuram Shah v GNCTD & Anr  2008 SCC

primary_legal_issue: Whether the FIR No.509/2017 dated 09-11-2017 can be quashed on the ground of an amicable settlement between the parties.
summary: The petitioners, Tarun Khanna and others, filed CRL.M.C.8/2021 seeking quash of FIR No.509/2017 registered at Police Station Kalkaji, alleging that the matter had been settled amicably. The petitioners were married to Respondent No.2 on 20-07-2015 but began living separately from 01-05-2017 due to incompatibility. On 05-10-2020 they executed a Memorandum of Understanding/Settlement Agreement resolving all disputes. Respondent No.2, appearing in person, confirmed the settlement and expressed no desire to continue prosecution. The State, represented by an APP, did not oppose the petition. The Court, after hearing, noted that continuation of criminal proceedings would serve no useful purpose given the complete settlement and the expressed wishes of the respondent. Consequently, the Court quashed FIR No.509/2017 and disposed of the petition, ordering the order to be uploaded on the Court’s website. The judgment reflects the principle that criminal proceedings may be terminated when the complainant and accused have reached a full and final settlement, and further prosecution would be futile.
facts: Petitioner No.1 (Tarun Khanna) married Respondent No.2 on 20-07-2015. They separated on 01-05-2017. An FIR (No.509/2017) was lodged on 09-11-2017 at Police Station Kalkaji. On 05-10-2020 the parties executed a Settlement Agreement resolving all disputes. Respondent No.2, present in court, affirmed the settlement and declined further prosecution.
arguments: Petitioners argued that the FIR should be quashed as the parties have reached an amicable settlement and continuation of criminal proceedings would be unnecessary. The State did not contest the petition.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that, given the complete settlement and the respondent’s desire not to prosecute, the FIR served no useful purpose and could be quashed. The principle that criminal proceedings may be terminated upon full settlement between parties was applied.

Continuation of prosecution serves no useful purpose after amicable resolution
Court may dispose of petition if respondent consents to settlement

primary_legal_issue: Whether the defendant's use of the surname ‘RAKYAN’ is a bona fide use exempted under Section 35 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, or constitutes infringement of the plaintiff’s registered trademark ‘RAKYAN’S FINE JEWELLERY’.
summary: The appellant, M/s Varun Gems, owns the registered trademark ‘RAKYAN’S FINE JEWELLERY’ and sued M/s Precious Jewels for allegedly using the name ‘RAKYAN’ in a manner that was identical or deceptively similar. An interim ex‑parte injunction was initially granted but was vacated by the Supreme Court in SLP(C) No.9942/2013 on the ground that the defendants were using their own name bona fide under Section 35 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The Delhi High Court Single Judge dismissed the suit, relying on the Supreme Court’s prima‑facie view that the defendants’ use was not infringing. On appeal, the High Court examined the factual background, including the family history of the Rakyan surname and the establishment of various jewellery businesses. The Court held that the critical question was whether the defendants’ use of ‘RAKYAN’ was genuine personal use or an attempt to ride on the plaintiff’s goodwill. Applying Sections 28, 29 and 35 of the Act, the Court concluded that the defendants were using the name in good faith, there was no likelihood of confusion, and the plaintiff was not entitled to any injunction or further relief. Consequently, the suit was dismissed with no costs, and a decree sheet was ordered to be drawn up.
facts: Varun Gems, managed by Jitendra Kumar Rakyan, registered the trademark ‘RAKYAN’S FINE JEWELLERY’ in 2005. Various family members operate jewellery shops in Delhi under names incorporating the surname Rakyan. In 2012 an interim injunction restrained the respondents from using ‘RAKYAN’, which was later vacated by the Supreme Court. The respondents did not contest the suit, and the trial court dismissed the case, relying on the Supreme Court’s view that the defendants’ use of their own name was bona fide.
arguments: Appellant argued that the respondents’ use of ‘RAKYAN’ caused confusion and infringed its registered mark, seeking a permanent injunction. Respondents contended that ‘RAKYAN’ is their family name, used in good faith, and Section 35 protects such bona‑fide use; they relied on the Supreme Court’s interim order and the lack of similarity in shop hoardings.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the statutory provisions, especially Section 35, which saves bona‑fide use of a person’s own name. It noted that the Supreme Court’s order was only prima‑facie and not final, but the evidence showed the respondents were using the name as a family surname without intent to deceive. No likelihood of confusion was established, and the plaintiff’s claim for injunction could not stand. Hence, the suit was dismissed.
key_legal_points: Section 35 of the Trade Marks Act protects bona‑fide use of a person’s own name
A registered trademark does not bar others from using their own surname in trade
Prima‑facie findings of the Supreme Court can guide but the trial court must assess evidence
No likelihood of confusion was demonstrated
legal_issues: Whether the use of the surname ‘RAKYAN’ by the respondents amounts to infringement
Whether Section 35 provides an absolute defence for bona‑fide use of a personal name
Whether the plaintiff is entitled to any relief beyond injunction

primary_legal_issue: Whether the cancellation of the bail granted to Vikas Mittal under Section 439(2) Cr.P.C. was justified on the ground of his past conduct of failing to surrender after interim bail expiry.
summary: The petition filed by Vikas Mittal sought restoration of bail after it was cancelled by the Sessions Court on 26 November 2020. Mittal had earlier obtained interim bail on medical grounds on 1 August 2018, which was later dismissed for non‑surrender, leading to non‑bailable warrants. He was arrested on 27 July 2020 and granted bail on 6 August 2020 with conditions of passport deposit and travel restriction. The State, dissatisfied, invoked Section 439(2) Cr.P.C. to cancel the bail, citing Mittal's prior failure to surrender. The High Court examined the material considered by the trial court, noting that the bail was granted after the investigation was complete, co‑accused had also been released, and no evidence of tampering or witness intimidation existed. Citing precedents such as Kanwar Singh Meena v. State of Rajasthan and Directorate of Enforcement v. Ratul Puri, the Court held that cancellation must be based on cogent, supervening circumstances, not merely on past conduct. It found the cancellation order infirm and restored the original bail order, directing Mittal’s release under the earlier conditions. The petition was disposed, and any pending applications were also dismissed.
facts: Vikas Mittal obtained interim bail on medical grounds on 1 August 2018, which was later dismissed for failure to surrender, resulting in non‑bailable warrants on 9 October 2018. He failed to surrender, was arrested on 27 July 2020, and was granted bail on 6 August 2020 with a personal bond of Rs.50,000, passport deposit, and travel restrictions. The State filed an application under Section 439(2) Cr.P.C. on 26 November 2020 to cancel this bail, alleging Mittal's prior non‑surrender as a risk of absconding.
arguments: The State argued that Mittal's past conduct—failure to surrender after interim bail expiry—demonstrated a likelihood of absconding, justifying cancellation of bail under Section 439(2). It relied on the principle that bail can be revoked if the accused misuses the concession. Mittal, through his counsel, contended that the bail was granted after the investigation was complete, co‑accused were also released, and there was no evidence of tampering, intimidation, or any supervening circumstance warranting cancellation. He emphasized that the trial court had considered all relevant material before granting bail.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that cancellation of bail must be based on cogent, supervening circumstances that render the bail no longer conducive to a fair trial. Mere past conduct, without evidence of tampering or intimidation, is insufficient. The trial court had duly considered the material, including the completion of investigation and the release of co‑accused. Citing Kanwar Singh Meena and Directorate of Enforcement v. Ratul Puri, the Court emphasized that bail should not be cancelled mechanically. Consequently, the cancellation order was deemed infirm and set aside, restoring the original bail order with its conditions.
key_legal_points: Cancellation of bail requires cogent, supervening circumstances, not merely past conduct.
The trial court must have considered all relevant material before granting bail.
Absence of evidence of tampering, witness intimidation, or other misconduct weakens the State's case for cancellation.
Precedents require that bail not be revoked in a mechanical manner.
legal_issues: Whether failure to surrender after interim bail expiry constitutes sufficient ground for bail cancellation.
Whether the trial court erred in granting bail without considering relevant material.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the COVID‑19 pandemic justifies the release of under‑trial and convicted prisoners and the application of Section 436A CrPC for interim bail/parole, together with the duty of the State to provide non‑COVID medical facilities.
summary: The Delhi High Court heard four public‑interest writ petitions filed by various petitioners seeking relief for prisoners amid the COVID‑19 pandemic. The petitions demanded: (i) detailed affidavits on COVID‑19 cases in Delhi jails; (ii) guidelines for interim bail or special parole; (iii) assurance of RT‑PCR testing facilities; (iv) prompt communication of test results; (v) release of under‑trials and convicts, especially those with medical ailments; and (vi) direction to provide non‑COVID medical facilities for inmates. The Court, after noting that the substantive reliefs in three of the petitions were largely addressed by the High Powered Review Committee (HPC) decisions of 4 May and 11 May 2021 and a Supreme Court ruling of 7 May 2021, held that most prayers did not survive. However, it issued specific directions: the State must ensure medical investigations/treatments are conducted in non‑COVID hospitals when referral hospitals are fully dedicated to COVID care; it must continue testing prisoners via RAT and RT‑PCR; and it must consider release of under‑trials under Section 436A where appropriate. The Court dismissed the broader release orders but partially allowed the petitions by mandating procedural safeguards and medical care provisions. The judgment balances public health concerns with prisoners’ rights, emphasizing that the State cannot deny essential medical services even during a pandemic.
facts: Four writ petitions were filed in the Delhi High Court in 2021 by RK Gossaín, Kanhaiya Singhal & Anr., Shobha Gupta, and the India Under‑Trial Prisoner Support Forum. All petitions arose from the COVID‑19 outbreak in Delhi’s jails and sought court‑ordered reliefs such as detailed affidavits on infection rates, guidelines for interim bail or parole, mandatory RT‑PCR testing for inmates, rapid communication of test results, and the release of under‑trial and convicted prisoners, especially those with medical conditions. The petitioners alleged inadequate testing, lack of non‑COVID medical facilities, and neglect of non‑COVID patients. The State (GNCTD) opposed the broad release orders, citing the High Powered Review Committee (HPC) recommendations and Supreme Court guidance on prison de‑congestion during the pandemic.
arguments: Petitioners argued that the pandemic created a health emergency in overcrowded jails, justifying the release of prisoners under Section 436A CrPC and the provision of non‑COVID medical facilities. They sought mandatory testing, timely result dissemination, and interim bail/parole to prevent loss of life. The State contended that the HPC’s recommendations and Supreme Court’s May 2021 decision already addressed de‑congestion, and that non‑COVID patients were being treated in jail hospitals or referred hospitals. The State also highlighted that many reliefs were already implemented, such as RAT and RT‑PCR testing, and that releasing prisoners indiscriminately could compromise public safety.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the substantive reliefs sought in three petitions were largely covered by the HPC decisions of 4 May and 11 May 2021 and the Supreme Court’s 7 May 2021 order. Consequently, most prayers did not survive. However, the Court recognized that the State must not deny essential medical investigations or treatment to inmates because a referral hospital is a COVID‑only facility. It directed the State to arrange non‑COVID hospitals for such purposes and to continue comprehensive testing of prisoners. The Court also affirmed that Section 436A can be invoked for eligible under‑trials, but any release must be in line with the HPC recommendations and not undermine public safety. Thus, the petitions were partially allowed with specific directions, while broader release orders were dismissed.
key_legal_points: The High Powered Review Committee’s recommendations are binding unless challenged.
Section 436A CrPC may be invoked for interim bail of eligible under‑trials during a health emergency.
The State must ensure non‑COVID medical facilities for inmates when referral hospitals are COVID‑only.
Testing of prisoners must include both RAT and RT‑PCR with prompt result communication.
legal_issues: Whether the State’s existing measures satisfy the petitioners’ demands for prisoner release and medical care.
Applicability of Section 436A CrPC for interim bail during a pandemic.
Obligation of the State to provide non‑COVID medical facilities for inmates.
Effect of the HPC and Supreme Court decisions on the reliefs sought.

petitioners: Commissioner of Tax (Principal Commissioner of Income Tax)
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Tribunal erred in deleting the addition of Rs.10,57,01,194 made by the Assessing Officer under section 2(22)(e) of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
summary: The appeal filed by the Principal Commissioner of Income Tax challenged the ITAT's order dismissing the revenue's appeal and upholding the CIT(A) order that deleted an addition of Rs.10,57,01,194 made by the Assessing Officer under section 2(22)(e) of the Income Tax Act. The appellant argued that the transaction was a sham, the agreement was unregistered and on a Rs.100 stamp paper, and thus fell within the anti‑avoidance provisions of section 2(22)(e). The respondents contended that the advance received was a genuine commercial advance for the booking of a commercial space, not a loan, and that the CIT(A) and Tribunal findings on facts were correct. The Court examined the factual findings of the CIT(A) and Tribunal, noting that the advance was received against the sale of commercial space, that the company owed money to the assessee, and that the transaction was in the ordinary course of business. Citing the Supreme Court’s decision in Vikram Krishna Vs PCIT and the principle from Hero Vinoth (Minor) vs Seshammal, the Court held that the Tribunal’s factual findings were not perverse and that the addition under section 2(22)(e) was correctly deleted. Consequently, the appeal was dismissed.
facts: The Assessing Officer added Rs.10,57,01,194 to the assessee's income under section 2(22)(e), treating an advance received from Apra Auto (India) P Ltd as a loan. The CIT(A) and the ITAT held that the advance was a commercial advance for the booking of a commercial space being built by the assessee, and therefore fell outside section 2(22)(e). The appellant argued the agreement was unregistered and on a Rs.100 stamp paper, alleging a scheme to avoid tax. The respondent maintained that the transaction was genuine, that the company owed money to the assessee, and that the advance was in the nature of business advance.
arguments: Appellant: The addition was justified under section 2(22)(e) because the agreement was informal, unregistered, and on a low‑value stamp paper, indicating a scheme to convert a loan into a sale. The Supreme Court’s decision in Vikram Krishna Vs PCIT was cited to support this view. Respondent: The advance was received against the sale of commercial space, was recorded by the AO, and the CIT(A) and Tribunal findings that the transaction was in the ordinary course of business were correct. The transaction fell within the exception clause of section 2(22)(e).
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the factual findings of the CIT(A) and the Tribunal were consistent and not perverse. The advance was a genuine commercial advance, not a loan, and therefore section 2(22)(e) was inapplicable. The Supreme Court’s dismissal of a Special Leave Petition in Vikram Krishna does not constitute endorsement of the lower court’s view, and the facts of the present case differed materially. The Court also relied on the principle that where two factual inferences are possible, the lower appellate court’s inference should not be disturbed. Hence, the Tribunal’s order deleting the addition was upheld and the appeal dismissed.
key_legal_points: Section 2(22)(e) applies only to loans/advances not in the ordinary course of business
The exception clause excludes genuine commercial advances
Tribunal’s factual findings are not perverse and merit deference
Supreme Court’s dismissal of a SLP does not bind lower courts on factual differences

Whether the transaction was a genuine commercial advance or a scheme to avoid tax

primary_legal_issue: Whether the High Court can grant a writ of mandamus for reconstruction and compensation when the title and possession of the property are disputed factual matters beyond writ jurisdiction.
summary: The petitioner, Nadeem Qureshi, filed a writ petition under Article 226 seeking a mandamus directing the North Delhi Municipal Corporation (NDMC) to allow reconstruction of his alleged property (No. 551, 18.40 sq m) and to award Rs 20 lakh as compensation. Qureshi relied on a GPA, will and gift deed allegedly executed by his mother, and asserted 60 years of uninterrupted possession and payment of statutory dues. NDMC contested the claim, stating that a show‑cause notice dated 09‑12‑2017 under Sections 415/417 of the DMC Act was issued for illegal meat‑sale operations, leading to a sealing order on 03‑03‑2018 and demolition on 10‑11‑2020. The corporation further argued that the structure was an encroachment on public toilet land, as confirmed by engineering and land‑estate reports measuring the area at 122.64 sq m. The Court held that the dispute centered on factual questions of title and measurement, which are not amenable to writ jurisdiction. It directed the petitioner to approach the appropriate civil court for determination of ownership and damages. Consequently, the writ petition was dismissed without prejudice to the parties' rights.
facts: Petitioner claims ownership of property No. 551 (18.40 sq m) behind Delite Cinema, based on a GPA, will and gift deed, and 60 years of possession, paying taxes and utilities. Respondent NDMC issued a show‑cause notice under Sections 415/417 of the DMC Act for unlicensed meat‑sale, sealed the premises, and demolished it. Engineering and land‑estate reports indicated the structure encroached on public toilet land measuring 122.64 sq m. The property has been demolished.
arguments: Petitioner argued that long‑standing possession, payment of dues and documentary title establish ownership and entitlement to reconstruction and compensation. Respondent argued that the structure was an illegal encroachment, that the show‑cause notice and sealing were lawful, and that the matter involves factual disputes over title and measurement, which are beyond the scope of a writ petition.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the core issues—title to the land and exact dimensions—are factual disputes requiring evidence and adjudication by a civil court. Writ jurisdiction under Article 226 is limited to questions of law and jurisdiction, not to determine ownership. Hence, the petition cannot be entertained, and the petitioner must seek relief in the appropriate forum. The dismissal is without prejudice to any future civil proceedings.
key_legal_points: Writ jurisdiction cannot be used to resolve factual disputes over property title
Encroachment on public land can be addressed only by civil/administrative proceedings
Show‑cause notice under Sections 415/417 DMC Act is valid for unlicensed trade
Demolition orders based on encroachment are within municipal powers
legal_issues: Whether the High Court can grant mandamus for reconstruction when title is disputed
Whether compensation can be awarded via writ jurisdiction
Whether the petitioner’s claim of ownership is determinable by the Court
