primary_legal_issue: Whether the blacklisting order without a specified end date is valid and what interest rate should apply to the outstanding dues owed by the appellant to the respondent.
summary: The appeal filed by M/s Graphisads Private Limited challenges a judgment of a Single Judge dated 01‑06‑2018 that upheld a blacklisting order dated 12‑06‑2015 against the company by South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC). The blacklisting order had no expiry date, which the appellant argued contravenes Supreme Court precedent in Kulja Industries Ltd. v. Chief General Manager (2014) 14 SCC 731. Both parties agreed to settle the outstanding dues arising from two contracts – the Parking Media Contract and the Street Furniture Cluster No.2 Contract – but disputed the quantum of interest and surcharge. The respondent claimed principal, interest (calculated at 24%), and advertisement tax, while the appellant offered to pay the principal and tax and to accept interest at 8% per annum. The Court, noting the prolonged dispute and the impact of COVID‑19, held that interest should be fixed at a reasonable 8% simple rate for both contracts, ordered payment of the principal amounts and advertisement tax as calculated by SDMC, and left the question of surcharge (potentially a penalty) to be resolved, possibly via arbitration. The judgment thus partially allows the appellant’s relief by fixing a lower interest rate while leaving other issues open for further determination.
facts: The appellant, Graphisads Private Limited, was blacklisted by SDMC on 12‑06‑2015 without a specified end date. The blacklisting stemmed from alleged non‑payment of dues under two contracts: the Parking Media Contract (2009‑2014) and the Street Furniture Cluster No.2 Contract (2010‑2017). The respondent claimed large sums comprising principal, interest, surcharge and advertisement tax. The appellant contended the blacklisting order was invalid for lacking an expiry date and offered to settle the principal and tax while seeking a reduced interest rate of 8% instead of the respondent’s 24% calculation.
arguments: The appellant argued that the blacklisting order violated Supreme Court precedent requiring a definite period, and that the 24% interest rate was excessive given prevailing market rates and the COVID‑19 pandemic. The respondent maintained that the contract terms entitled it to the claimed amounts, including interest at 24% and surcharge, and that the blacklisting was lawful. Both parties expressed willingness to resolve the outstanding dues and suggested arbitration for any remaining disputes.
judgment_reasoning: The Court accepted that the blacklisting order without an end date conflicted with the Supreme Court’s decision in Kulja Industries Ltd., but refrained from setting aside the order, opting instead to address the monetary dispute. Considering the prolonged litigation, the impact of COVID‑19, and prevailing lower interest rates on deposits and loans, the Court deemed an 8% simple interest rate equitable for both contracts. It ordered payment of the principal amounts and advertisement tax as calculated by SDMC and left the surcharge issue, potentially a penalty, to be determined, possibly through arbitration.
key_legal_points: Blacklisting orders must specify an end date per Supreme Court precedent
Interest on contractual dues should be reasonable and reflect current market rates
Surcharge may be characterized as a penalty and thus subject to waiver
Arbitration clause in contracts can be invoked for unresolved monetary disputes
legal_issues: Validity of a blacklisting order without a specified expiry date
Appropriate rate of interest on outstanding contractual dues
Whether surcharge amounts constitute a penalty
Applicability of arbitration for remaining disputes

primary_legal_issue: Whether the appellants can be compelled to pay the full cost of the flats with interest and avoid coercive steps pending the outcome of W.P.(C)4756/2020, and whether such payment would amount to an admission of liability.
summary: The Delhi High Court heard LPA No.1/2021 filed by SH Vipin Bihari Sharan Dwivadi & Ors. (appellants) against the Union of India and others (respondents) challenging the order dated 3 November 2020 passed by a Single Judge in W.P.(C) No.4756/2020. The appellants, who are original petitioners in the writ petition, sought relief from coercive steps indicated in demand‑cum‑allotment letters issued by the Delhi Development Authority (DDA) for payment of flat costs. The Court, after hearing counsel and reviewing earlier orders dated 10 August 2020 (LPA31/2020) and 31 December 2020 (W.P.(C) No.11254/2020), noted the appellants’ willingness to pay the entire cost of the flats, including interest, within two weeks. The Court directed that, subject to payment within the stipulated period and without prejudice to the pending writ petition, no coercive steps shall be taken by the respondents. The order expressly excluded Appellant No.2, who had not yet been joined in the writ petition. The Court clarified that the payment would not constitute an admission of any facts and that the rights and contentions of the parties remain intact. Consequently, the appeal and related applications were disposed of, with the payment condition linked to the outcome of the pending writ petition. The judgment underscores the Court’s equitable approach, balancing the parties’ interests while preserving procedural rights pending final determination of the writ case.
facts: The appellants are original petitioners in W.P.(C) No.4756/2020, a writ petition concerning the allocation and payment of flats by the DDA. An order dated 3 November 2020 by a Single Judge directed the respondents to issue demand‑cum‑allotment letters, which the appellants contested, claiming they were coercive. The appellants filed a letters patent appeal (LPA No.1/2021) alleging dissatisfaction with the Single Judge’s order and seeking relief from the coercive steps. The respondents, represented by the Union of India, argued that the demand‑cum‑allotment process was lawful and that the appellants were liable to pay the flat cost. The Court noted that the appellants expressed readiness to pay the full amount with interest within two weeks, subject to the pending writ petition’s outcome.
arguments: Appellants argued that the demand‑cum‑allotment letters amounted to coercive action, violating their right to a fair hearing and that they should be allowed to settle the payment without prejudice to the writ petition. They also contended that the Single Judge’s order was erroneous and that the DDA’s actions were not justified. Respondents maintained that the DDA’s demand‑cum‑allotment was a statutory procedure, that the appellants were obligated to pay the flat cost, and that no relief should be granted absent a clear legal infirmity in the earlier order.
judgment_reasoning: The Court considered the factual matrix, the parties’ willingness to settle, and the pending writ petition. It held that allowing payment without coercive steps would preserve the status quo and avoid unnecessary hardship, provided the payment is made within two weeks and does not prejudice the pending writ. The Court emphasized that such payment does not amount to an admission of liability and that the rights and contentions of the parties remain intact. The exclusion of Appellant No.2 was justified as he had not been joined in the writ petition. Accordingly, the appeal and related applications were disposed of.
key_legal_points: Payment of flat cost with interest can be conditioned on a short‑term deadline without prejudice to pending litigation
Coercive steps may be stayed if parties are willing to comply with payment obligations
Payment under such conditions does not constitute an admission of liability
Appellant not joined in the underlying writ cannot be bound by the order
legal_issues: Whether coercive steps under the demand‑cum‑allotment letters can be stayed pending payment
Whether payment of the flat cost constitutes an admission of facts
Whether the order can be extended to an appellant not joined in the writ petition

primary_legal_issue: Whether the Central Administrative Tribunal could dispose of the original application by merely applying the coordinate bench judgment without a fresh hearing, given the Supreme Court’s limited modification of that judgment.
summary: The Delhi High Court, in W.P.(C) 18/2021 decided on 14 February 2022, set aside the order of the Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT) dated 7 August 2019, which had directed fresh cadre allocation for Indian Forest Service officers based solely on a coordinate bench judgment of the High Court dated 3 May 2019. The petitioners, Union of India and others, contended that the Tribunal erred by not hearing the parties afresh, especially after the Supreme Court, in SLP (C) Nos.12430‑12431/2019, limited the relief to a narrow class of candidates and kept all questions of law open. The Court held that the Tribunal must consider the Supreme Court’s observations and conduct a merit‑based hearing on the merits. Consequently, the impugned order was set aside and the matter remitted to the Tribunal for fresh hearing, with a deadline of 2 March 2022. The Court also ordered the deletion of respondent No.3 (Rushal Garg) from the proceedings, subject to procedural conditions. The judgment underscores the principle that higher‑court directives cannot be mechanically applied without respecting the scope of relief and the need for a fresh adjudication when legal questions remain unsettled.
facts: The petitioners challenged a CAT order that, relying on a High Court coordinate bench judgment (W.P.(C) No.109/2019), directed fresh cadre allocation for IFoS officers without a fresh hearing. The Supreme Court, in a related SLP, limited that relief to candidates who approached the Court in time and kept all legal questions open. The Tribunal, however, applied the coordinate bench judgment indiscriminately, prompting the petitioners to seek its set‑aside.
arguments: Petitioners argued that the Tribunal erred by not conducting a fresh hearing and by extending relief beyond the narrow class identified by the Supreme Court. They emphasized that the Supreme Court’s order was an exceptional accommodation, not a precedent, and that all questions of law remained open. Respondents contended that the Tribunal was correctly applying the coordinate bench direction and that the cadre allocation should proceed as ordered.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the Supreme Court’s modification limited relief to a specific group and expressly kept legal questions open, requiring a fresh merits‑based adjudication. Hence, the Tribunal could not rely solely on the coordinate bench judgment. The Court set aside the CAT order, remitted the matter for fresh hearing, and ordered the deletion of respondent No.3 subject to procedural safeguards.
key_legal_points: A Tribunal must not mechanically apply a higher‑court judgment when the Supreme Court has limited its scope.
Relief granted in exceptional cases does not create a general precedent.
All questions of law kept open by the Supreme Court require fresh adjudication.
Parties must be given an opportunity to be heard on merits before any allocation order is made.
legal_issues: Scope of the Supreme Court’s modification of the coordinate bench judgment.
Whether the Tribunal can dispense with a fresh hearing.
Effect of exceptional accommodation on future cases.

[Court hearing convened via video-conferencing on acc ount of COVID-19] 
 
RAJIV SHAKDHER, J. (ORAL):- 
 
1. This writ petition is directed against the order dated 07.08.2019, 
passed by the Central Administrative Tribunal [in short the “Tribunal”] in 
O.A. No.1802/2019.   
2. At the heart of the matter, is the cadre allocated to the respondents, 
who were the original applicants before the Tribunal.  
2.1. The Tribunal has disposed of the O.A. [i.e., O.A. No.1802/2019], 
without examining the rights and contentions of the parties, by relying upon 
the judgment of the co-ordinate bench of this Court dated 03.05.2019, 
passed in a bunch of matters including W.P.(C) No.109/2019, titled 
Himanshu Kumar Verma & Anr. v. Union of India & Ors.  This is evident 
upon a perusal of paragraph 6 of the impugned order. In the said paragraph, 
the Tribunal has extracted paragraph 88 of the said decision rendered by this 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000646
 
W.P. (C) 18/2021        Pg. 2 of 6 
 Court. 
2.2. Based on the direction issued by the co-ordinate bench in the above-
mentioned writ petition, the Tribunal has directed the petitioners to carry out 
fresh cadre allocation vis-a-vis  the respondents, who belong to the Indian 
Forest Service (IFoS).   
2.3. The Tribunal had, in effect, applied the same yardstick that the co-
ordinate bench of this Court stipulated in the aforementioned judgment. The 
petitioners were, thus, directed to make cadre allocation according to the 
merit of the candidates, by taking into consideration the preference given by 
the candidates irrespective of whether they had filled numerical “99” in any 
of the zones or cadres, and if a candidate was not able to get any of the 
preferred cadres as per his/her rank, cadre allocat ion qua such a candidate 
could be made in the manner set out in later part of paragraph 4 of the Office 
Memorandum (OM) dated 05.09.2017.  The operative direction issued, in 
this behalf, is contained in paragraph 8 of the impugned order: 
“..8. In view of these developments, we allow the O.A. in 
terms of the judgment dated 03.05.2019 in W.P. (C) 
No.109/2019 & batch, and direct the respondents to 
undertake fresh cadre allocation of the successful candidates 
allocated to the IFoS, according to their merit and  by taking 
into consideration the preferences given by the candidates 
irrespective of whether they have filled "99" in any of the 
zones or cadres. If a candidate is not able to get any of the 
preferred cadres according to his rank, cadre alloc ation in 
respect of such a candidate may be resorted to in t he manner 
set out in later part of paragraph 4 of the O.M. dated 
05.09.2017, i.e. he may "be allotted along with other such 
candidates in the order of rank to any of the remaining 
cadres, 5 arranged in alphabetical order, in which there are 
vacancies in his category if allocation of all the candidates 
who could be allotted to cadres in accordance with their 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000646
 
W.P. (C) 18/2021        Pg. 3 of 6 
 preference"….”  
  
2.4. We may note that, while passing the impugned order, the Tribunal 
was aware of the fact that the aforesaid judgment of the co-ordinate bench 
dated 03.05.2019, was carried in appeal to the Supreme Court via a Special 
Leave Petition i.e., SLP (C) Nos.12430-12431/2019, titled Ministry of 
Home Affairs v. Himanshu Kumar Verma & Ors.  The Tribunal also took 
notice of the fact that the Supreme Court, via an order dated 17.05.2019 
passed in the said SLP and other connected matters, had clearly held that the 
relief  granted, would be confined to those candidates who approached the 
Court/Tribunal in time. This aspect is noticed in paragraph 7 of the 
impugned order.  
2.5. It would thus be relevant, at this juncture, to extract the order dated 
17.05.2019 passed by the Supreme Court in the aforementioned SLP: - 
“Heard learned counsel for the parties at length. Permission 
to file special leave petitions is granted. In exemplary 
fairness, learned Solicitor General suggests that the 18 writ 
petitioners who had approached the High Court (one of the 
writ petitioners being the respondent No.4 in S.L.P.(Civil) 
Nos.12420-12421 of 2019, having withdrawn) and two 
petitioners, who had approached the Central Administrative 
Tribunal shall be accommodated without cons idering “99” in 
their respective choices. This will be done by increasing one 
post in the respective State cadres this year, which will have 
to be adjusted in coming years. The suggestion is accepted by 
the respondents. The impugned judgment and order is, 
accordingly, modified by directing the petitioners to 
accommodate the twenty trainee officers in the manner 
suggested by the learned Advocate General. It is ma de clear 
that such accommodation is being made as an exceptional 
case and will not be treated as a precedent for other 
candidates of the same batch or in future as only these 20 
persons approached the Court/Tribunal in time. The special 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000646
 
W.P. (C) 18/2021        Pg. 4 of 6 
 leave petitions are disposed of with the above 
directions/observations. It is made clear that all questions of 
law are kept open. Needless to mention that the original 
cadre allocation of the other candidates shall not be 
disturbed .” 
 
2.6. A careful perusal of the aforementioned extract would show that the 
Supreme Court modified the judgment of the co-ordinate bench of this 
Court, and also went on to say that the accommodation made by the 
Supreme Court had been made as an exceptional case and would not be 
treated as a precedent for other candidates of the same batch or in future, 
given the fact that only 20 persons had approached the Court/Tribunal in 
time.   
2.7. Furthermore, more importantly, the Supreme Court also observed that 
all questions of law are kept open, and that the original cadre allocation of 
other candidates shall not be disturbed. 
3. Given this position, the Tribunal could not have simply taken recourse 
to the aforementioned judgment of the co-ordinate bench of this Court and 
disposed of O.A. No. 1802/2019 pending before it.  
3.1. In our opinion, since the questions of law have been kept open by the 
Supreme Court, the Tribunal would have to decide the matter on merits, 
after hearing both parties. This is especially so, given the fact that it is not 
disputed that the Indian Administrative Service (IAS) and Indian Police 
Service (IPS) officers who were arrayed as parties before the Supreme Court 
belonged to the same batch i.e., 2018 batch.  
3.2. We may add that even Mr Asheesh Jain, learned central government 
standing counsel, who appears for the  petitioners, does not dispute that the 
order passed by the Supreme Court, extracted above, was restricted, if at all, 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000646
 
W.P. (C) 18/2021        Pg. 5 of 6 
 to the IAS and IPS officers who were represented before the Court. 
Therefore, the Tribunal, according to both Mr Jain and Mr Ankur 
Khandelwal, who appears for the respondents, would have to examine the 
matter, as indicated above, afresh vis-a-vis  IFoS officers.   
4. Therefore, given the foregoing circumstances, we are of the view that 
impugned order of the Tribunal is required to be set aside.  
4.1. It is ordered accordingly.  
4.2. The matter is remitted to the Tribunal for a fresh hearing. It will be 
open to the parties to advance their respective submissions before the 
Tribunal.   To hasten the proceedings, parties and/or their respective counsel 
are directed to appear before the concerned bench of the Tribunal on 
02.03.2022.   
4.3. Furthermore, we would request the Tribunal to make an endeavour to 
dispose of the case at the earliest. 
5. Before we conclude, it is required to be noticed that respondent no. 3 
i.e., Rushal Garg was arrayed as party in the instant writ petition, even 
though he had succeeded in his case which was lodged before the 
Chandigarh Bench of the Tribunal. This aspect is recorded in the order dated 
29.04.2021. It appears that Mr Khandelwal, on instructions of respondent 
no. 3 i.e., Mr Rushal Garg, got the said respondent not only arrayed as party 
but also have him subject himself to the interim order dated 19.01.2021 
passed in the writ petition .   
5.1. Therefore, at this stage, when the matter is being remanded to the 
Tribunal i.e., the Principal Bench, New Delhi, Mr Khandelwal seeks to 
delink respondent no. 3 from the matter. It is Mr Khandelwal’s submission 
that respondent no. 3 should be allowed to file appropriate proceedings 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/000646
 
W.P. (C) 18/2021        Pg. 6 of 6 
 before the Chandigarh Bench of the Tribunal.  
5.2. While we would have no difficulty in de-linking respondent no. 3, 
however, given the stand that Mr Khandelwal took before the Court on 
29.04.2021 [on instructions of the said respondent], respondent no.3 can 
only file an execution petition or a contempt petition after a decision is 
rendered in the O.A. from which the instant petitio n arises [i.e., O.A. 
No.1802/2019]. It is ordered accordingly.  
5.3. Thus, respondent no.3 is deleted from the array of parties, subject to 
him abiding with the condition adverted to in paragraph 5.2 above.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation's revised licence‑fee scheme for parking contractors during the COVID‑19 pandemic is lawful and enforceable.
summary: The petitioners, parking contractors including Kake Finvest Pvt. Ltd., challenged a scheme issued by the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) on 1 December 2020 that altered the payment of licence fees during the COVID‑19 lockdown. The scheme waived fees from 22 March to 11 September 2020 and thereafter imposed a 25% fixed fee plus a variable component linked to average total journeys compared with the previous year. Petitioners argued that the scheme should be based on passenger journeys from parking entry points, not total train journeys, and that the terms were onerous, seeking termination of contracts. DMRC explained the three categories of parking licences, the existing conciliation and arbitration mechanisms, and clarified that “total journeys” meant total passenger journeys. The Court examined the scheme, noted the waiver during lockdown as a force‑majeure measure, and found the post‑lockdown calculation reasonable. Given the presence of dispute‑resolution clauses, the Court declined to intervene under its writ jurisdiction, effectively dismissing the petitions.
facts: DMRC awarded parking contracts to various contractors. During the COVID‑19 lockdown (23 March–11 September 2020) DMRC waived licence fees. Post‑lockdown, DMRC issued a scheme charging 25% of the licence fee as a fixed amount and linking the remaining 75% to average total journeys of the previous year. Petitioners contested the calculation method and the fairness of the scheme, seeking contract termination.
arguments: Petitioners argued that traffic reduction due to lockdown, social distancing, and work‑from‑home trends justified a more favorable fee structure and that the variable component should be based on passenger journeys from parking points. DMRC contended that the scheme was a reasonable adjustment, explained the three licence categories, and highlighted the existing conciliation and arbitration provisions.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the waiver during lockdown was a valid force‑majeure response. The clarification that “total journeys” refers to passenger journeys removed the petitioners' main grievance. Since the contracts contain clear conciliation and arbitration clauses, the Court deemed it inappropriate to interfere via writ jurisdiction and therefore dismissed the petitions.
key_legal_points: Waiver of licence fees during lockdown is permissible as a force‑majeure measure.
Post‑lockdown fee calculation based on average passenger journeys is reasonable.
Contractual dispute‑resolution clauses (conciliation and arbitration) preclude judicial intervention in fee disputes.
The Court will not exercise writ jurisdiction where contractual mechanisms exist.
legal_issues: Validity of DMRC's revised licence‑fee scheme during a pandemic.
Interpretation of “total journeys” in the fee calculation.
Scope of judicial intervention when contracts contain conciliation and arbitration clauses.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the fee‑adjustment scheme introduced by DMRC for parking contractors during the COVID‑19 lockdown is legally valid and enforceable.
summary: The Delhi High Court heard a series of writ petitions filed by Kake Finvest Pvt. Ltd. and other parking contractors challenging a scheme issued by the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) on 1 December 2020 for the payment of licence fees during the COVID‑19 lockdown. The petitioners argued that the scheme, which waived licence fees from 23 March 2020 to 11 September 2020 and thereafter linked the remaining 75 % of the fee to average passenger journeys of the previous year, was unfair because it did not reflect the drastic reduction in metro traffic and imposed onerous terms. DMRC contended that the scheme was a reasonable response to a force‑majeure event, that the fee calculation was based on total passenger journeys (not train journeys), and that the contracts contain built‑in conciliation and arbitration mechanisms for dispute resolution. The Court examined the scheme, the clarification that ‘total journeys’ meant passenger journeys, and the contractual dispute‑resolution clauses. Finding no violation of law and noting that the parties had agreed to conciliation and arbitration, the Court declined to interfere with DMRC’s scheme, effectively dismissing the writ petitions. The decision underscores the court’s reluctance to intervene in contractual matters where alternative dispute‑resolution mechanisms exist.
facts: The petitioners are parking contractors who hold licences under three types of DMRC tenders (old three‑year licences, short‑term six‑month licences, and open tender four‑year licences). During the COVID‑19 lockdown (23 Mar 2020‑11 Sep 2020) DMRC waived licence fees. Post‑lockdown, DMRC issued a scheme charging 25 % of the licence fee as a fixed amount and linking the remaining 75 % to the average total passenger journeys for the same month in the previous year. The petitioners claimed the scheme was onerous, sought a more reasonable basis for calculation, and eventually wished to terminate their contracts. DMRC argued the scheme was a reasonable adjustment to a force‑majeure situation and highlighted the contractual conciliation and arbitration clauses.
arguments: Petitioners argued that (1) traffic had fallen dramatically due to lockdown, social distancing, and work‑from‑home trends, making the percentage‑based fee excessive; (2) the scheme should consider passenger entries from parking points rather than total train journeys; and (3) the contract terms were being imposed unilaterally, effectively forcing termination. DMRC countered that (1) the waiver period covered the worst of the pandemic; (2) the scheme uses total passenger journeys, which was clarified during hearing; and (3) the contracts contain clear dispute‑resolution mechanisms, and the fee reduction is a reasonable response to a force‑majeure event.
judgment_reasoning: The Court noted that DMRC had expressly waived fees during the lockdown and that the post‑lockdown scheme was based on a transparent, percentage‑based calculation linked to passenger journeys, not train journeys. The clarification that ‘total journeys’ meant passenger journeys removed the petitioners’ principal objection. Moreover, the contracts provide for conciliation followed by arbitration, which the Court deemed the appropriate forum for any residual dispute. Since the scheme did not contravene any statutory provision and the parties had contractually agreed to alternative dispute resolution, the Court exercised restraint and declined to interfere, effectively dismissing the writ petitions.
key_legal_points: DMRC’s fee waiver during lockdown qualifies as a force‑majeure response.
Post‑lockdown fee calculation is based on total passenger journeys, not train journeys.
Contractual clauses mandate conciliation and arbitration before court intervention.
The court will not disturb contractual arrangements where alternative dispute‑resolution mechanisms exist.
legal_issues: Validity of DMRC’s fee‑adjustment scheme during COVID‑19.
Interpretation of ‘total journeys’ in the fee calculation.
Applicability of contractual conciliation and arbitration clauses.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the insurance company’s recovery rights against the appellant should be set aside due to the appellant’s failure to prove that the driver possessed a valid licence.
summary: The Delhi High Court heard appeals (MAC.APP.286/2020 and MAC.APP.3/2021) filed by Ashok Kumar Chaudhary against orders granting recovery rights to an insurance company. The appellant contended that the trial court erred in holding him liable because the genuineness of the driver’s licence had been verified at the time of employment, and no evidence suggested the licence was invalid. The respondent insurance company conceded the licence verification but did not object to limiting the award. The High Court examined the impugned award dated 04.03.2020, which held that the vehicle owner failed to prove the driver’s licence was valid. Finding no material to show the licence was invalid, the Court set aside the award and the associated recovery rights of the insurer. Consequently, the appeals were allowed, directing the tribunal to refund amounts deposited by the appellant and to restore statutory deposits. The order was to be uploaded on the Court’s website and communicated to counsel. The judgment underscores the principle that recovery cannot be awarded where the plaintiff fails to establish a crucial factual element, such as the validity of a driver’s licence, especially when verification records exist.
facts: Ashok Kumar Chaudhary (appellant) was subject to an order granting recovery rights to an insurance company, based on the finding that the vehicle owner failed to prove the driver held a valid licence. The appellant argued that the driving licence had been verified at the time of employment (report dated 17.07.2013) and that there was no evidence of its invalidity. The insurance company acknowledged the verification but did not contest limiting the award.
arguments: The appellant’s counsel argued that the trial court’s reasoning was flawed because the licence’s genuineness had already been verified, making any further evidence unnecessary. He asserted there was no material indicating the licence was invalid. The respondent’s counsel conceded the verification and raised no objection to a limited award, effectively supporting the appellant’s position that the recovery rights should be curtailed.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the impugned award, which found the appellant failed to prove the driver’s licence validity, was unsustainable given the verification report and lack of contrary material. Consequently, the award and the insurance company’s recovery rights were set aside. The Court ordered the refund of amounts deposited by the appellant and the restitution of statutory deposits, emphasizing that recovery cannot be granted without proof of a material fact.
key_legal_points: Verification of a driver’s licence at the time of employment is conclusive unless contradicted by evidence.
Recovery rights cannot be awarded where the plaintiff fails to prove a crucial factual element.
The tribunal must refund deposits made by the appellant when the award is set aside.
legal_issues: Validity of the driver’s licence and its impact on recovery rights.
Whether the insurance company is entitled to recover amounts from the appellant.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioners are entitled to pro rata pension on the same basis as granted in the earlier Brijlal Kumar and Govind Kumar Srivastava judgments.
summary: The Delhi High Court heard three civil writ petitions (WP(C) 33, 43 and 49 of 2021) filed by former armed forces personnel seeking pro rata pension similar to that awarded in the Brijlal Kumar and Govind Kumar Srivastava cases. The petitioners, represented by Ms. Pallavi Awasthi, claimed they were similarly situated to the earlier petitioners and had filed the requisite No Objection Certificates. The respondents, Union of India, argued that verification of entitlement and the right to appeal to the Supreme Court should be preserved. The Court, after video‑conferenced hearing, directed the Indian Air Force to verify the petitioners' claims within twelve weeks and, if verified, to pay arrears of pro rata pension from the date of discharge, continue future payments, and pay interest at 7% per annum on delayed amounts. If verification finds any petitioner ineligible, written reasons must be communicated, allowing the petitioner to seek further remedies. The order was to be uploaded online and communicated to counsel. The judgment essentially disposes of the petitions by granting them the same relief as in the earlier cases, subject to verification.
facts: Former armed forces personnel Shivashish Shubham, Pradeep Chandra Nahak and Vipin Kumar Yadav filed writ petitions claiming entitlement to pro rata pension. They asserted that they were in the same position as petitioners in the Brijlal Kumar and Govind Kumar Srivastava cases, for which the Court had previously ordered payment of pro rata pension. The petitioners submitted No Objection Certificates and sought the same relief—payment of arrears and continuation of pro rata pension. The Union of India, as respondent, contended that verification of eligibility and the right to appeal to the Supreme Court must be preserved.
arguments: Petitioners argued that the factual circumstances of their service and discharge were analogous to those in the earlier judgments, thereby warranting identical relief. They emphasized that they had complied with procedural requirements, including filing NOCs. Respondents argued that each case must be individually verified to ensure eligibility and that the petitioners should retain the right to appeal any adverse verification decision to the Supreme Court.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the petitioners' claims closely mirror those in the Brijlal Kumar and Govind Kumar Srivastava cases, where pro rata pension was granted. However, it stressed the necessity of verification to confirm eligibility, preserving the respondents' right to appeal adverse findings. Accordingly, the Court directed the Indian Air Force to verify the petitioners' status within twelve weeks and, upon verification, to award arrears and future pro rata pension, with interest for delayed payment. If verification fails, written reasons must be provided, allowing petitioners to pursue further remedies.
key_legal_points: Petitioners are entitled to the same relief as earlier petitioners if verification confirms eligibility.
Verification must be completed within twelve weeks.
Interest at 7% per annum applies to delayed arrears.
Petitioners retain the right to appeal adverse verification decisions to the Supreme Court.
legal_issues: Eligibility for pro rata pension for former armed forces personnel.
Whether the relief granted in earlier cases applies to similarly situated petitioners.

acts_referred: National Textile Corporation Limited Leave Rules, 2015
primary_legal_issue: Whether the appellant can lawfully withhold the respondent's leave encashment and employer's share of PF pending disciplinary proceedings instituted before or after the respondent's superannuation.
summary: The appeal (LPA 4/2021) filed by National Textile Corporation Ltd. challenges a single judge's order directing the release of the respondent S B Singh's leave encashment and the employer's share of provident fund (PF) while disciplinary proceedings are pending. The single judge had held that, absent an express opinion that the amount could be recovered from the respondent, the leave encashment could not be withheld. The appellant argued that Rule 25.13 of the Conduct, Discipline and Appeal Rules, 2009, which treats disciplinary proceedings instituted before retirement as continuing post‑superannuation, should preclude withholding of any retiral benefits, including leave encashment. The court examined the leave rules, which specifically govern withholding of leave encashment, and held that they are the controlling provision; the disciplinary rules cannot override them without express provision. Consequently, the direction to release the leave encashment was upheld, while the order to release the employer's share of PF was stayed pending further consideration of the disciplinary proceedings. The court also noted timing issues regarding the exact moment of superannuation and the issuance of the show‑cause notice, directing the parties to expedite the disciplinary inquiry.
facts: S B Singh, a senior employee of National Textile Corporation Ltd., retired (superannuated) on 31 January 2020. A show‑cause notice dated 31 January 2020 was issued on 1 February 2020, initiating disciplinary proceedings for alleged misconduct. The respondent sought release of his retiral benefits – gratuity, leave encashment, and PF – via a writ petition. The single judge directed the appellant to release the leave encashment and employer's share of PF, holding that no express opinion existed to justify withholding the leave encashment. The appellant appealed, contending that Rule 25.13 of its Conduct, Discipline and Appeal Rules, 2009, should allow withholding of all retiral benefits until disciplinary proceedings conclude, and that the proceedings were instituted before retirement.
arguments: Appellant: Asserted that Rule 25.13 treats disciplinary proceedings instituted before retirement as continuing post‑superannuation, thereby permitting withholding of all retiral benefits, including leave encashment and PF. Cited the timing of the show‑cause notice and internal notes to argue the proceedings were instituted before superannuation. Respondent: Relied on the Leave Rules, 2015, which require an express opinion in the order to withhold leave encashment. Pointed to precedents (Satya Prakash v. BSNL and Govt. of NCT of Delhi v. Prem Nath Manchanda) stating that withholding is permissible only with a clear finding of recoverable amount.
judgment_reasoning: The court held that leave encashment is governed exclusively by the Leave Rules, 2015, which stipulate that withholding is permissible only if the order expressly states a possibility of recovery. Since the single judge’s order lacked such an opinion, the appellant could not withhold the leave encashment. The Conduct, Discipline and Appeal Rules, 2009, cannot be used to override the specific provisions of the Leave Rules absent an express cross‑reference. Regarding PF, the court stayed the release of the employer's share pending further determination of the disciplinary proceedings. The timing of superannuation and issuance of the show‑cause notice was noted but left for detailed consideration.
key_legal_points: Leave encashment is a retiral benefit governed by the National Textile Corporation Leave Rules, 2015.
Withholding of leave encashment requires an express opinion in the order that the amount may be recoverable.
Conduct, Discipline and Appeal Rules, 2009, cannot override specific provisions of the Leave Rules.
The timing of disciplinary proceedings relative to superannuation is crucial for determining entitlement to benefits.
The employer's share of PF remains stayed pending resolution of disciplinary proceedings.
legal_issues: Whether Rule 25.13 of the Conduct, Discipline and Appeal Rules applies to withhold leave encashment.
Whether an express opinion is required to withhold leave encashment under the Leave Rules.
Whether the employer's share of PF can be released while disciplinary proceedings are pending.

1. On 5th January, 2021, when this appeal first came up for 
consideration, the following order was passed:- 
3.  The appeal impugns the judgment dated 17th November, 
2020 of the Single Judge in W.P.(C) No.3114/2020 instituted by 
the respondent, seeking a mandamus directing the appellant  to 
release the retiral benefits comprising of gratuity, leave 
encashment and provident fund (PF) to the respondent. Dur ing 
the pendency of the petition, the respondent‟s share of PF was 
released to the respondent, with the appella nt‟s share of PF 
amount only being retained/withheld. Further, though the  
Signed By:ASHWANI
Signing Date:05.04.2021
09:54:52Signature Not Verified
 
LPA 4/2021                             Page 2 of 10  
 respondent, in the writ petition had sought release of  gratuity 
also, but during the hearing before the Single Judge, ga ve up 
the relief of release of gratuity and agreed to the same b eing 
withheld by the appellant, till the culmination of the disciplinar y 
proceedings initiated against the respondent. Thus, only t he 
claim for release of leave encashment amount and the 
employer‟s share of PF amount remained for adjudication  
before the Single Judge and the Single Judge, vide the 
impugned judgment has directed the appellant to release bo th 
the said amounts to the respondent. Aggrieved therefrom, t his 
appeal has been preferred.  
4.  We have heard the counsel for the appellant as well as 
the counsel for the respondent, appearing on advance noti ce, at 
length.  
5.  We will first deal with the impugned direction of the  
Single Judge, insofar as it concerns the release of the lea ve 
encashment amount. Leave encashment of the employees of the 
appellant is governed by the National Textile Corporation 
Limited Leave Rules, 2015 and Rule 7 whereof deals with Leave  
Encashment. Rule 7.7 inter alia permits the authority competen t 
to grant encashment of leave, to withhold whole or part  of cash 
equivalent of earned leave, in case of any employee who retires 
from service on attaining the age of superannuation, while 
under suspension or while disciplinary or criminal proceed ings 
are pending against him, if in the view of such authori ty there is 
possibility of some money becoming recoverable from him on 
conclusion of the proceedings against him. The Single Judge, in 
the impugned judgment has held that since there was no finding 
returned or opinion expressed in the order withholding th e 
amount of leave encashment, of a possibility of some m oney 
becoming recoverable from the respondent on conclusion of the 
disciplinary proceedings initiated against him, the amou nt due 
towards leave encashment could not be withheld. Relianc e was 
placed on Satya Prakash Vs. Chairman Cum Managing 
Director, Bharat Sanchar Nigam Ltd. 2019 SCC OnLine Del 
8039 and Govt. of NCT of Delhi Through Chief Secretary Vs.  
Prem Nath Manchanda 2018 SCC OnLine 13066, laying down 
Signed By:ASHWANI
Signing Date:05.04.2021
09:54:52Signature Not Verified
 
LPA 4/2021                             Page 3 of 10  
 that for leave encashment amount to be withheld, there has to 
be an express opinion in the order withholding the leave  
encashment amount, of such possibility and which did no t exist 
in the present case.  
6.  The counsel for the appellant has not impugned the 
aforesaid reasoning. He has however drawn our attention to the 
Conduct, Discipline and Appeal Rules, 2009 of the appel lant, 
Rule 25.13 titled “Continuation of Enquiry Beyond 
Superannuation” whereof inter alia provides, that (i) 
disciplinary proceedings, if instituted while the employee was  in 
service, whether before his retirement or during his re-
employment, shall, after the final retirement of the employee, be 
deemed to be subsisting and shall be continued and concl uded 
by the authority by which it was commenced, in the same 
manner as if the employee had continued in service; and, (ii ) in 
such cases, the employee will cease to be in service from the 
date of superannuation/retirement but will not be entitle d to 
payment of retirement benefits till the proceedings are 
completed and final order is passed thereon, except his own 
contribution to Contributory Provident Fund.  
7.  The counsel for the appellant has contended that th e 
impugned judgment does not consider that the word „insti tuted‟ 
used in the aforesaid Rule 25.13.1 and which word has b een 
held to mean, the date when a decision to initiate disciplin ary 
proceedings has been taken. He has contended that since in t he 
present case, though Show Cause Notice dated 31st January,  
2020 was served on the respondent on 1st February, 2020 i.e. 
very next day of his superannuation on 31st January, 2020 , but 
the disciplinary proceeding against the respondent is deem ed to 
have been instituted on 31st January, 2020 i.e. during his 
employment with the appellant; it is stated that till 31st  
January, 2020 the respondent was in the employment of the 
appellant. 
8.  We have enquired from the counsel for the appellant, 
whether leave encashment can be considered as a retiral  
benefit. 
Signed By:ASHWANI
Signing Date:05.04.2021
09:54:52Signature Not Verified
 
LPA 4/2021                             Page 4 of 10  
 9. The counsel for the appellant has referred us to Rule 7 
aforesaid of the Leave Rules and on a reading whereof we a re 
satisfied that the leave encashment, as per the said rule, is a 
retiral benefit. 
10. The contention of the counsel for the appellant is that the 
Single Judge has not considered that besides the Leave Rules , 
the aforesaid Rule 25.13 of Conduct, Discipline and App eal 
Rules would also apply. 
11. We are unable to agree. Leave encashment, though a 
retiral benefit, having been dealt with separately, under t he 
Leave Rules which lay down their own condition/s for 
withholding of leave encashment, we are of the view that no 
case of the appellant being entitled to withhold the leave 
encashment amount, also as a retiral benefit, under R ule 25.13, 
is made out. To withhold the amount of leave encashment, t he 
provisions of the Conduct, Discipline and Appeal Rules , cannot 
be applied, without the Leave Rules, expressly providing so. N o 
ground to interfere with the direction of the Single Judg e, to the 
appellant, to release the leave encashment amount to the 
respondent, is thus made out and the appeal to that exte nt, is 
dismissed. 
12. We however find merit in the contention of the counsel 
for the appellant, that the Single Judge has not consider ed that 
the disciplinary proceedings in the present case were insti tuted 
prior to retirement of the respondent. We have however 
enquired, whether the retirement / superannuation of the 
respondent was in the forenoon or afternoon of 31st January, 
2020 and whether any such thing is mentioned/specified i n the 
records, as is found in cases of certain other department s, 
particularly Armed Forces. If it is so, and the 
retirement/superannuation of the respondent were to be in t he 
forenoon and the decision to initiate disciplinary procee ding 
was taken in the afternoon, then also, what is argued by th e 
counsel for the appellant, will not follow inasmuch as th e 
institution of the disciplinary proceeding would be after  the 
superannuation of the respondent. 
Signed By:ASHWANI
Signing Date:05.04.2021
09:54:52Signature Not Verified
 
LPA 4/2021                             Page 5 of 10  
 13. We have also enquired from the counsel for the 
appellant, whether not institution of a legal proceedi ng in a 
Court is different from institution of a disciplinary proceeding, 
because unlike a proceeding in the Court, which is deemed to 
be instituted on the date of filing in the Court, a discipl inary 
proceeding commences with the issuance of a show cause notice 
and which is a 'communication' within the meaning of Sectio ns 
3 & 4 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 and if it is so, t hen even 
if a decision is taken to institute the proceedings, unless the said 
decision is communicated to the employee, it cannot be said that 
the disciplinary proceedings were instituted prior to 
retirement/superannuation of the employee. 
14. The Single Judge has held that the disciplinary 
proceedings in the present case were initiated after 
superannuation and in which case there is no power to withhold 
the retiral benefits. 
15. Though we have heard the counsels for some time but it 
appears that decision on the said aspect requires consider ation 
and preparation by the counsels. 
16. Issue notice of the appeal qua the aforesaid aspect of

 cooperate in the same. The status of the disciplinary proceedin g

primary_legal_issue: Whether the respondent was entitled to Non‑Functional Upgradation in the grade of Additional Secretary (HAG) despite not having one year of qualifying service as on the crucial date of 01‑01‑2013, in view of the applicable Office Memoranda on eligibility dates.
summary: The petitioners (Union of India and Anr.) challenged a Delhi High Court order dated 11‑07‑2017 that allowed the respondent, Pyare Lal, to receive Non‑Functional Upgradation (NFU) to the grade of Additional Secretary (HAG) effective 01‑01‑2014. The respondent, a former Chief Engineer (Electrical) who superannuated on 31‑03‑2014, had applied for NFU but was initially rejected because he lacked the requisite one‑year qualifying service as on the crucial date of 01‑01‑2013. The Tribunal, relying on Department of Personnel and Training (DoPT) guidelines, held that the respondent could be considered for NFU in the subsequent vacancy year after completing the qualifying service by 01‑04‑2014. Petitioners argued that the Tribunal erred by not producing the governing rule and relied merely on FAQs. They cited an Office Memorandum (OM) dated 28‑05‑2014, which altered the crucial date for financial‑year‑based vacancies to 01‑April, but the Court found this OM inapplicable to the respondent’s case as it pertained only to vacancy years commencing from 2015‑16 onward. The Court held that the earlier OM of 17‑09‑1998, which fixed the crucial date at 01‑January, governed the respondent’s situation. Consequently, the Tribunal’s order was consistent with the applicable rule, and the petition was dismissed with the pending application disposed. Petitioners were directed to implement the Tribunal’s order within six weeks.
facts: The respondent was appointed Assistant Executive Engineer in 1981, promoted through the ranks, and became Chief Engineer (Electrical) on 20‑03‑2012. He superannuated on 31‑03‑2014. He sought NFU in the grade of Additional Secretary (HAG) but was rejected because he did not have one year of qualifying service as on the crucial date 01‑01‑2013. The respondent filed an Original Application, which the Tribunal allowed, directing NFU effective 01‑01‑2014. Petitioners appealed, contending the Tribunal’s decision was unsupported by any rule or memorandum and relied on FAQs.
arguments: Petitioners argued that the Tribunal failed to produce the statutory rule governing eligibility for NFU and merely relied on FAQs, rendering its decision unsustainable. They cited the OM dated 28‑05‑2014, which shifted the crucial date for financial‑year‑based vacancies to 01‑April, asserting that the respondent should be considered eligible based on service completed by 01‑April‑2014. The respondent contended that, despite lacking one year of service as on 01‑01‑2013, he possessed the requisite service by 01‑01‑2014 and thus was entitled to NFU. The Tribunal held that the respondent’s eligibility should be assessed under the earlier OM of 17‑09‑1998, which fixed the crucial date at 01‑January for financial‑year‑based vacancies, making the respondent ineligible for the 2014‑15 vacancy but eligible for the subsequent year, thereby justifying the order.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the chronology of Office Memoranda. The OM dated 28‑05‑2014 applied only to vacancy years commencing from 2015‑16 and therefore could not govern the respondent’s case, which pertained to the 2014‑15 vacancy year. The earlier OM of 17‑09‑1998, incorporated by reference in the 28‑05‑2014 OM, remained the controlling rule for the period in question, fixing the crucial date at 01‑January. Accordingly, the respondent’s lack of one year of qualifying service as on 01‑January‑2014 rendered him ineligible for NFU for that vacancy year, but the Tribunal correctly allowed his application for the subsequent vacancy year after he completed the requisite service. The Court found no infirmity in the Tribunal’s reasoning and dismissed the petition.
key_legal_points: The crucial date for eligibility in financial‑year‑based vacancies before 2015‑16 was 01‑January, as per the 1998 OM.
The 28‑05‑2014 OM applied only to vacancy years from 2015‑16 onward and is inapplicable to the respondent’s case.
The Tribunal’s order was consistent with the governing rule and therefore valid.
legal_issues: Interpretation of the crucial date for NFU eligibility under the 1998 Office Memorandum.
Applicability of the 2014 Office Memorandum to vacancy years preceding 2015‑16.
Whether the Tribunal erred by relying on FAQs without a statutory rule.

case_type: Application for appointment of a sole arbitrator under Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Delhi Jal Board could unilaterally appoint a sole arbitrator under Clause 8.1.2 of the contract when the parties failed to agree on an arbitrator within the stipulated period.
summary: The petition filed by City Lifeline Travels Private Limited (the petitioner) seeks appointment of a sole arbitrator to resolve payment disputes arising from a Water Tanker Supply Services contract for Zone‑II entered into with Delhi Jal Board (DJB) on 27‑08‑2012. After the petitioner’s bid was accepted, DJB issued a Letter of Intent and a Work Order, but later failed to release payments for August‑October 2020. The petitioner invoked the arbitration clause (Clause 8.1.2) and served a notice on 20‑11‑2012, proposing a former Chief Justice as arbitrator. DJB rejected the proposal and suggested two alternative former judges, which the petitioner also rejected. DJB subsequently nominated Justice (Retd) Iqbal Ahmed Ansari, one of its own suggestions, as sole arbitrator. The petitioner challenged this unilateral appointment under Section 11(6) of the A&C Act, arguing it contravenes the contractual procedure and citing Supreme Court decisions in Perkins Eastman Architects and TRF Ltd. The respondent contended those precedents were inapplicable, relying on Central Organization for Railway Electrification and Standard Corrosion Controls cases. The Court examined the contractual clause, the statutory framework, and the cited jurisprudence, concluding that DJB’s unilateral nomination was permissible where the parties could not agree within one month, and thus allowed the petition for appointment of the arbitrator. The judgment underscores the primacy of contractual arbitration clauses and the limited scope of judicial intervention under Section 11(6).
facts: The parties entered into a contract on 27‑08‑2012 for water tanker supply services in Zone‑II. The petitioner performed the work but DJB failed to pay invoices for August‑October 2020. The petitioner issued a notice invoking the arbitration clause on 20‑11‑2012 and suggested a former Chief Justice as arbitrator. DJB rejected the suggestion, proposed two former judges, and later nominated Justice (Retd) Iqbal Ahmed Ansari as sole arbitrator. The petitioner filed an application under Section 11(6) of the A&C Act seeking appointment of an arbitrator and interim relief, which was denied, leading to an appeal under Section 37.
arguments: Petitioner argued that DJB’s unilateral appointment violated Clause 8.1.2, which requires mutual consent and that the DJB’s suggested arbitrators were from its own panel, rendering the appointment improper. The petitioner relied on Supreme Court rulings in Perkins Eastman Architects and TRF Ltd. to assert that an ineligible arbitrator cannot be appointed. Respondent countered that those decisions dealt with Section 12(5) ineligibility and a different procedural context, and that under the contract DJB retained the right to nominate an arbitrator if parties failed to agree within one month. The respondent cited Central Organization for Railway Electrification and Standard Corrosion Controls to support the validity of unilateral nomination from a pre‑existing panel.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the wording of Clause 8.1.2, which expressly provides that if parties cannot agree on an arbitrator within one month, DJB may nominate one. The statutory framework of Section 11(6) supports court‑assisted appointment only when the agreed procedure fails. Since the contract already vested DJB with the power to nominate after the one‑month period, the Court held that DJB’s nomination of Justice Ansari was in accordance with the contract and the A&C Act. The cited precedents were distinguished on factual and procedural grounds; they did not preclude DJB’s right to nominate from its panel. Consequently, the petition for appointment of a sole arbitrator was allowed.
key_legal_points: Clause 8.1.2 grants DJB the right to nominate an arbitrator after a one‑month deadlock
Section 11(6) of the A&C Act is invoked only when the agreed arbitration procedure fails
Supreme Court decisions on Section 12(5) ineligibility are fact‑specific and not applicable here
Unilateral nomination from a pre‑existing panel is permissible under the contract
legal_issues: Interpretation of the arbitration clause regarding unilateral nomination
Applicability of Section 11(6) of the A&C Act
Relevance of Supreme Court precedents on arbitrator eligibility

 IN THE HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI 
%           Judgment delivered on: 27.01.2021 
+  ARB. P. 1/2021 & I. A. 31/2021 
 
CITY LIFELINE TRAVELS PRIVATE  
LIMITED                ..... Petitioner 
 
    versus 
 
DELHI JAL BOARD            ..... Respondent 
Advocates who appeared in this case:  
For the Petitioner:  Ms. Manmeet Arora, Ms. Samapika Biswal 
and Mr. Harkirat Singh. 
For the Respondent:  Mr. Ramesh Singh with Mr R. A. Iyer, 
 Advocates 
 
CORAM 
HON’BLE MR JUSTICE VIBHU BAKHRU  
 
JUDGMENT 
VIBHU BAKHRU, J 
 
1. The petitioner has filed the present application under Section 
11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 (hereafter ‘the  
A&C Act’), inter alia, praying that a Sole Arbitrator be appointed to 
adjudicate the disputes that have arisen between the parties in relati on 
to an Agreement dated 27.08.2012 entered into between the part ies for 
performing the work of “Water Tanker Supply Services (WTSS)” for 
Zone-II (hereafter the ‘Contract’).  
 
  
ARB.P.1/2021                                          Page 2 of 13  
 2. The respondent (hereafter ‘DJB’) issued a Request for Proposal 
(RFP) bearing NIT No.07/RPC-I/(2011-12) inviting competitive 
tenders from agencies for operating Stainless Steel (SS) Water Tanker 
Services on hire basis for the purposes of supplying water throug h 
vehicle mounted water tankers in order to facilitate supply of p otable 
drinking water to different areas in Delhi.  Such services were to be 
provided in five different Zones – Zone I, Zone II, Zone V, Zone VII 
and Zone VIII on identical terms. The subject dispute relates to Z one 
II. 
3. The petitioner submitted its bid pursuant to the RFP. After 
negotiations, an offer made by the petitioner was accepted and the 
DJB issued a Letter of Intent (LoI) dated 16.07.2012.  Thereaft er, the 
DJB issued a Work Order under the cover of its letter dated 
21.08.2012 and on 27.08.2012, the parties entered into a form al 
agreement with respect to performance of the work “ Water Tanker 
Supply Services (WTSS) for Zone- II”. 
4. The petitioner claims that it has been diligently performing th e 
contract, however, the DJB has failed to make payments of the 
invoices raised by the petitioner.  The petitioner claims tha t it had 
issued a notice calling upon the DJB to release the payments 
outstanding for the months of August, September and October, 20 20 
and had also made representations in this regard.  However, the 
petitioner claims that the DJB has failed to address the issues rai sed by 
it.  
 
  
ARB.P.1/2021                                          Page 3 of 13  
 5. In view of the disputes that have arisen between the parties, the  
petitioner issued a notice dated 20.11.2012 invoking the A rbitration 
Agreement as set out in Clause 8.1.2 of the Contract.  It also suggested 
the name of a former Chief Justice of this Court for being appointed as 
an Arbitrator.   
6. Thereafter, on 25.11.2020, the petitioner filed a petition (OMP 
(I) (COMM.) 392/2020) under Section 9 of the A&C Act before this  
Court seeking certain interim measures of protection.  The said matt er 
was listed for hearing on 01.12.2020 and 02.12.2020.  On 02. 12.2020, 
this Court issued notice but did not grant any interim relief, as prayed 
for by the petitioner. Aggrieved by the same, the petitioner preferred 
an appeal –  FAO(OS)(COMM.) 173/2020 – under Section 37 of the 
A&C Act impugning the said order dated 02.12.2020.   
7. The name of the Sole Arbitrator as suggested by the petitioner 
was not accepted by the DJB.  However, the DJB sent a letter dated 
15.12.2020 responding to the petitioner’s notice dated 20 .11.2020, 
whereby the petitioner had invoked the Arbitration Clause. Th e DJB 
proposed names of two persons, one being a former Chief Justice of 
the Patna High Court and the other being a former Judge of this Co urt 
to be appointed as Arbitrators. However, the same were not acceptable 
to the petitioner. Therefore, on 24.12.2020, the petitioner m oved this 
application for appointment of an Arbitrator.   
8. After the petitioner had filed the present application, the DJB 
issued a letter dated 31.12.2020 nominating Justice (Retired) Iq bal 
 
  
ARB.P.1/2021                                          Page 4 of 13  
 Ahmed Ansari as a Sole Arbitrator to adjudicate the disputes between 
the parties. It is material to note that he was one of the two persons 
who were proposed by the DJB for being appointed as an Arbitr ator, 
in its letter dated 15.12.2020  
9. The respondent does not dispute the existence of the Arbitration  
Clause contained in Clause 8.1.2 of the Contract is relev ant and is set 
out below:-  
“8.1 DISPUTE RESOLUTION  
1) Any dispute arising out of or in connection with this 
Agreement shall in the first instance be dealt with in 
accordance with the escalation procedure as set out 
in the Governance Schedule.   
2) Any dispute or difference whatsoever arising 
between to this Contract out of or relating to the 
construction, meaning, scope, operation or effect of 
this Contract or the validity of the breach thereof, 
which cannot be resolved through the application of 
the provisions of the Governance Schedule, shall be 
referred to a sole Arbitrator to be appointed by 
mutual consent of both the parties herein.  If the 
parties cannot agree on the appointment of the 
Arbitrator within a period of one month from the 
notification by one party to the other of existence of 
such dispute, then the Arbitrator shall be nominated 
by DJB.  The provisions of the Arbitration and 
Conciliation Act, 1996 will be applicable and the 
award made there under shall be final and binding 
upon the parties hereto, subject to legal remedies 
available under the law.  Such differences shall be 
deemed to be a submission to arbitration under the 
 
  
ARB.P.1/2021                                          Page 5 of 13  
 Indian Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 or of 
any modifications, Rules or re-enactments thereof.  
The Arbitration proceedings will be held at Delhi, 
India. ” 
10. Ms. Arora, learned counsel appearing for the petitioner referred 
to the decisions of the Supreme Court in Perkins Eastman Architects 
DPC &Anr. v. HSCC (India) Limited : Arbitration Application No 32 
of 2019 decided on 26.11.2019 and a decision of this Court in 
Proddatur Cable TV Digi Services v. Citi Cable Network Li mited: 
(2020) 267 DLT 51  and contended that the unilateral appointment of 
an Arbitrator by the DJB was not permissible.   
11. Mr Singh, learned counsel appearing for the DJB countered the 
aforesaid submissions.  He contended that the decision of th e Supreme 
Court in Perkins Eastman Architects DPC &Anr. v. HSCC (India) 
Limited (supra ) was not applicable in the facts of the present case.  He 
submitted that the said decision must be read in a restricte d manner. 
And, the said decision would be applicable only in cases under Section 
11(6)(a) of the A&C Act, that is, in cases where there had been failure 
on the part of a party to act in accordance with the agreed procedure 
for appointment of an Arbitrator.   
12. He submitted that the said decision must also be read in c ontext 
with an earlier decision of the Supreme Court in TRF Ltd. v. Energo 
Engineering Projects Ltd.: (2017) 8 SCC 377 .  He submitted that in 
Perkins Eastman Architects DPC &Anr. v. HSCC (India) Limited 
(supra ), the issue before the Court was regarding ineligibility of an 
 
  
ARB.P.1/2021                                          Page 6 of 13  
 Arbitrator to act as such under Section 12(5) of the A&C Act.  He  
submitted that there was no dispute that a person whose relati onship 
with any of the parties fell within the categories as specifie d in the 
Seventh Schedule of the A&C Act would be ineligible to be appoi nted 
as an Arbitrator.  He submitted that the said rationale was furth er 
extended by the Supreme Court in TRF Ltd. v. Energo Engineering 
Projects Ltd. (supra ) and the Supreme Court held that once a person is 
ineligible by operation of law to act as an Arbitrator, he also cannot 
nominate another to nominate an Arbitrator.  The Court had held  that 
“it was inconceivable in law that person who is statutorily ineligible 
can nominate a person .” Mr. Singh submitted that the said decision 
was rendered in context of an Arbitration Clause, which provid ed that 
disputes and differences between the parties would be referred to 
“sole arbitration of the Managing Director of buyer or h is nominee” .  
He submitted that in the case of Perkins Eastman Architects DPC & 
Anr. v. HSCC (India) Limited (supra ), the Arbitration Clause 
provided for an arbitration “by a sole arbitrator appointed by the 
CMD HSCC within 30 days from the receipt of the request”.   
However, the CMD, HSCC, had failed to appoint an Arbitrator with in 
the period specified and therefore, the concerned authority had lo st its 
right to appoint an Arbitrator.  He submitted that the decisi on was also 
founded on Section 12(5) of the A&C Act which, inter alia, rendered 
an employee of any party ineligible to act as an Arbitrator.  Th us, the 
said decisions would not be applicable in the present case.  
 
  
ARB.P.1/2021                                          Page 7 of 13  
 13. He earnestly contended that in the facts of the present case, the 
DJB had appointed a former Chief Justice of the Patna High Court as  
an Arbitrator from the panel of Arbitrators maintained by it and  
therefore, the question of an Arbitrator being ineligible under Section 
12(5) of the A&C Act did not arise.  He relied on the decision of the  
Supreme Court in Central Organization for Railway Electrification v. 
ECI-SPIC-SMO-MCML : Civil Appeal Nos. 9486-9487 of 2019 
decided on 17.12.2019 and contended that in cases where an 
Arbitrator has been appointed from a panel of Arbitrators, the 
appointment was necessarily required to be in terms of the agreement 
between the parties.  He submitted that in this case, the DJB had a 
right to nominate an Arbitrator and therefore, the appointment o f the 
Arbitrator could not be faulted.  He also referred to the decision of the 
Supreme Court in Standard Corrosion Controls Pvt. Ltd.  v. Sarku

summary: The petition filed by VSK Technologies Private Limited sought appointment of a sole arbitrator under Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, invoking Clause 8.1.2 of its contract with Delhi Jal Board (DJB) for water‑tanker services in Zone‑I. The contract required mutual consent for arbitrator appointment; failing agreement within one month, DJB was empowered to nominate. After negotiations, DJB issued a Letter of Intent and Work Order in 2012. Payment disputes arose, leading the petitioner to invoke the arbitration clause in November 2020. DJB proposed two former judges, which the petitioner rejected, and subsequently nominated Justice (Retired) Iqbal Ahmed Ansari on 31 December 2020. The petitioner challenged the unilateral nomination, citing Supreme Court decisions in Perkins Eastman Architects and TRF Ltd., arguing ineligibility and procedural violations. DJB contended that those precedents were fact‑specific and did not apply, emphasizing the contractual right to nominate after the one‑month deadline. The Court examined the arbitration clause, the statutory framework, and the cited precedents, concluding that the clause expressly allowed DJB to nominate when parties could not agree, and that the nomination complied with Section 11(6). Consequently, the Court allowed the petition, confirming the validity of DJB’s appointment of Justice Iqbal Ahmed Ansari as sole arbitrator.
facts: The parties entered into a contract on 27‑08‑2012 for Water Tanker Supply Services (WTSS) in Zone‑I. DJB issued a Letter of Intent and Work Order. VSK Technologies performed the work but alleged non‑payment of invoices for Aug‑Oct 2020. adjudicate the disputes that have arisen between the parties in relation
to an Agreement dated 28.08.2012 entered into between the parties for
performing the work of “Water Tanker Supply Services (WTSS)”for
Zone-I (hereinafter ‘the Contract’).

tenders from agencies for operating Stainless Steel (SS) Water Tanker
Services on hire basis for the purposes of supplying water through
vehicle mounted water tankers in order to facilitate supply of potable
drinking water to different areas in Delhi. Such services were to be
provided in five different Zones – Zone I, Zone II, Zone V, Zone VII
and Zone VIII on identical terms. The subject dispute relates to Zone
I.
3. The petitioner submitted its bid pursuant to the RFP. After
negotiations, an offer made by the petitioner was accepted and the
DJB issued a Letter of Intent (LoI) dated 16.07.2012. Thereafter, the
DJB issued a Work Order under the cover of its letter dated
21.08.2012 and on 27.08.2012, the parties entered into a formal
agreement with respect to performance of the work “Water Tanker
Supply Services (WTSS) for Zone-I.”
4. The petitioner claims that it has been diligently performing the
contract, however, the DJB has failed to make payments of the
invoices raised by the petitioner. The petitioner claims that it had
issued a notice calling upon the DJB to release the payments
outstanding for the months of August, September and October, 2020
and had also made representations in this regard. However, the
petitioner claims that the DJB has failed to address the issues raised by
it.
ARB.P.2/2021 Page 3 of 135. In view of the disputes that have arisen between the parties, the
petitioner issued a notice dated 20.11.2012 invoking the Arbitration
Agreement as set out in Clause 8.1.2 of the Contract. It also suggested
the name of a former Chief Justice of this Court for being appointed as
an Arbitrator.
6. Thereafter, on 25.11.2020, the petitioner filed a petition (OMP
(I) (COMM.) 390/2020) under Section 9 of the A&C Act before this
Court seeking certain interim measures of protection. The said matter
was listed for hearing on 01.12.2020 and 02.12.2020. On 02.12.2020,
this Court issued notice but did not grant any interim relief, as prayed
for by the petitioner. The petitioner has also preferred an appeal –
FAO(OS)(COMM.) 174/2020 – under Section 37 of the A&C Act –
challenging the said order dated 02.12.2020.
7. The name of the Sole Arbitrator as suggested by the petitioner
was not accepted by the DJB. However, the DJB sent a letter dated
15.12.2020 responding to the petitioner’s notice dated 20.11.2020,
whereby the petitioner had invoked the Arbitration Clause. The DJB
proposed names of two persons, one being a former Chief Justice of
the Patna High Court and the other being a former Judge of this Court
to be appointed as Arbitrators. However, the same were not acceptable
to the petitioner. Therefore, on 24.12.2020, the petitioner moved this
application for appointment of an Arbitrator.
8. After the petitioner had filed the present application, the DJB
issued a letter dated 31.12.2020 nominating Justice (Retired) Iqbal
ARB.P.2/2021 Page 4 of 13Ahmed Ansari as a Sole Arbitrator to adjudicate the disputes between
the parties. It is material to note that he was one of the two persons
who were proposed by the DJB for being appointed as an Arbitrator,
in its letter dated 15.12.2020
9. The respondent does not dispute the existence of the Arbitration
Clause contained in Clause 8.1.2 of the Contract is relevant and is set
out below:-
“8.1 DISPUTE RESOLUTION
1)Any dispute arising out of or in connection with this
Agreement shall in the first instance be dealt with in
accordance with the escalation procedure as set out
in the Governance Schedule.
2)Any dispute or difference whatsoever arising
between to this Contract out of or relating to the
construction, meaning, scope, operation or effect of
this Contract or the validity of the breach thereof,
which cannot be resolved through the application of
the provisions of the Governance Schedule, shall be
referred to a sole Arbitrator to be appointed by
mutual consent of both the parties herein. If the
parties cannot agree on the appointment of the
Arbitrator within a period of one month from the
notification by one party to the other of existence of
such dispute, then the Arbitrator shall be nominated
by DJB. The provisions of the Arbitration and
Conciliation Act, 1996 will be applicable and the
award made there under shall be final and binding
upon the parties hereto, subject to legal remedies
available under the law. Such differences shall be
deemed to be a submission to arbitration under the
ARB.P.2/2021 Page 5 of 13Indian Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 or of
any modifications, Rules or re-enactments thereof.
The Arbitration proceedings will be held at Delhi,
India.”
10. Ms. Arora, learned counsel appearing for the petitioner referred
to the decisions of the Supreme Court in Perkins Eastman Architects
DPC &Anr. v. HSCC (India) Limited :Arbitration Application No 32
of 2019 decided on 26.11.2019 and a decision of this Court in
Proddatur Cable TV Digi Services v. Citi Cable Network Limited:
(2020) 267 DLT 51 and contended that the unilateral appointment of
an Arbitrator by the DJB was not permissible.
11. Mr Singh, learned counsel appearing for the DJB countered the
aforesaid submissions. He contended that the decision of the Supreme
Court in Perkins Eastman Architects DPC &Anr. v. HSCC (India)
Limited (supra ) was not applicable in the facts of the present case. He
submitted that the said decision must be read in a restricted manner.
And, the said decision would be applicable only in cases under Section
11(6)(a) of the A&C Act, that is, in cases where there had been failure
on the part of a party to act in accordance with the agreed procedure
for appointment of an Arbitrator.
12. He submitted that the said decision must also be read in context
with an earlier decision of the Supreme Court in TRF Ltd. v. Energo
Engineering Projects Ltd.: (2017) 8 SCC 377 . He submitted that in
Perkins Eastman Architects DPC &Anr. v. HSCC (India) Limited
(supra ), the issue before the Court was regarding ineligibility of an
ARB.P.2/2021 Page 6 of 13Arbitrator to act as such under Section 12(5) of the A&C Act. He
submitted that there was no dispute that a person whose relationship
with any of the parties fell within the categories as specified in the
Seventh Schedule of the A&C Act would be ineligible to be appointed
as an Arbitrator. He submitted that the said rationale was further
extended by the Supreme Court in TRF Ltd. v. Energo Engineering
Projects Ltd. (supra ) and the Supreme Court held that once a person is
ineligible by operation of law to act as an Arbitrator, he also cannot
nominate another to nominate an Arbitrator. The Court had held that
“it was inconceivable in law that person who is statutorily ineligible
can nominate a person .” Mr. Singh submitted that the said decision
was rendered in context of an Arbitration Clause, which provided that
disputes and differences between the parties would be referred to
“sole arbitration of the Managing Director of buyer or his nominee” .
He submitted that in the case of Perkins Eastman Architects DPC &
Anr. v. HSCC (India) Limited (supra ), the Arbitration Clause
provided for an arbitration “by a sole arbitrator appointed by the
CMD HSCC within 30 days from the receipt of the request”.
However, the CMD, HSCC, had failed to appoint an Arbitrator within
the period specified and therefore, the concerned authority had lost its
right to appoint an Arbitrator. He submitted that the decision was also
founded on Section 12(5) of the A&C Act which, inter alia, rendered
an employee of any party ineligible to act as an Arbitrator. Thus, the
said decisions would not be applicable in the present case.
