DJB had appointed a former Chief Justice of the Patna High Court as
an Arbitrator from the panel of Arbitrators maintained by it and
therefore, the question of an Arbitrator being ineligible under Section
12(5) of the A&C Act did not arise. He relied on the decision of the
Supreme Court in Central Organization for Railway Electrification v.
ECI-SPIC-SMO-MCML :Civil Appeal Nos. 9486-9487 of 2019
decided on 17.12.2019 and contended that in cases where an
Arbitrator has been appointed from a panel of Arbitrators, the
appointment was necessarily required to be in terms of the agreement
between the parties. He submitted that in this case, the DJB had a
right to nominate an Arbitrator and therefore, the appointment of the
Arbitrator could not be faulted. He also referred to the decision of the
Supreme Court in Standard Corrosion Controls Pvt. Ltd. v.Sarku
Engineering Services SDN BHD: (2009) 1 SCC 303 and contended
that a party could not approach the court under Section 11 of the A&C
Act without following the procedure as agreed upon.
14. Ms Arora countered the aforesaid submissions. She submitted
that the contention that the Arbitrators suggested by the DJB were
from its panel is incorrect. She also referred to an Office Order being
OO No.26 dated 17.12.2020, issued by the Office of the Law Officer,
DJB and submitted that the said Office Order, for including the names
of two former Judges suggested by the DJB on their panel, was issued
on 17.12.2020 which was after the date when their names had been
suggested by the DJB.
ARB.P.2/2021 Page 8 of 1315. She also referred to a circular dated 25.08.2020, which sets out
the procedure to be adopted for appointment of an Arbitral Tribunal in
light of the judgments passed by the Supreme Court and the High
Court. The said circular indicates that the concerned engineering
officer is required to file a request to the High Court for appointment
of an Arbitrator from the panel maintained by the Delhi International
Arbitration Centre (DIAC) or at its own discretion.
16. Mr. Singh countered the aforesaid submissions and stated that
averments to the aforesaid effect were not included in the petition filed
by the petitioner but were made in the rejoinder and therefore, the DJB
had no opportunity to traverse the said averments. However, he stated
on instructions that although the order including the names of the two
Arbitrators suggested by the DJB was passed on 17.12.2020 and the
decision to include them in the panel had already been taken on file on
15.12.2020, that is, the date on which their names were suggested to
the petitioner. He further submitted the Circular dated 25.08.2020 had
no application in cases where the procedure for appointment of the
Arbitrators had been agreed between the parties
17. It is not necessary for this Court to examine the question
whether the names of the Arbitrators suggested had been included on
the panel of Arbitrators maintained by the DJB subsequent to them
being suggested to the petitioner. This is because the Arbitration
Clause does not provide for appointment of Arbitrators from any
panel. It is equally unnecessary to examine the scope of the Circular

petitioners: M/S COMBITIC GLOBAL CAPLET PVT. LTD.
acts_referred: Customs Excise and Duty Drawback Rules, 1995
primary_legal_issue: Whether a unit converted to a 100% Export Oriented Unit is entitled to duty drawback on the customs duty component for deemed exports without furnishing proof of actual duty paid on inputs.
summary: The writ petition W.P.(C) 1644/2019 filed by M/S Combitic Global Caplet Pvt. Ltd. challenges Policy Circular No.9 (2013) and subsequent orders dated 26.04.2016 and 17.11.2016 that denied the petitioner’s claim for duty drawback on the customs duty component of deemed exports. The petitioner, a pharmaceutical manufacturer, had converted its Domestic Tariff Area unit into a 100% Export Oriented Unit on 28 September 2012 and thereafter claimed duty drawback for periods between July 2012 and March 2015. The Deputy Development Commissioner and the Deputy Director General of Foreign Trade rejected the claims on the ground that the goods were received before conversion and that proof of customs duty paid on inputs was required. The petitioner argued that under the Foreign Trade Policy 2009‑14, the Handbook of Procedures and several notifications (No.92/2012‑C, No.98/2013‑C, No.110/2014‑C, Circular No.24/2001, Circular No.13/2014‑C) the customs duty component could be claimed on an All Industry Rate basis without furnishing actual duty evidence. The respondents contended that the FTP, as interpreted by the DGFT, mandates proof of duty paid and that the statutory provisions of the FTDR Act empower the authority to deny drawback where conditions are not satisfied. The Court examined the statutory framework, the notifications, and the precedent of Sarla Performance Fibers Ltd. v. Union of India, concluding that the petitioner was not entitled to the claimed drawback without compliance with the evidentiary requirements, and dismissed the petition.
facts: Combitic Global Caplet Pvt. Ltd., a pharmaceutical exporter, converted its DTA unit into a 100% Export Oriented Unit on 28‑09‑2012. Post‑conversion, it filed multiple applications (starting 08‑04‑2013) seeking duty drawback on the customs duty component for deemed exports, claiming amounts totaling over Rs. 5 crore for periods between July 2012 and March 2015. The Deputy Development Commissioner and later the Deputy DGFT rejected the claims, citing that the goods were received before conversion and that proof of customs duty paid on inputs was mandatory. The petitioner contended that the Foreign Trade Policy 2009‑14, the Handbook of Procedures, and several customs notifications allowed drawback on an All Industry Rate basis without such proof. The respondents relied on the same policy provisions, emphasizing the statutory power of the DGFT to interpret the policy and the requirement of evidence of duty paid.
arguments: Petitioner: (i) Deemed exports arising from conversion to EOU qualify for duty drawback on the customs duty component; (ii) Benefits under the FTP for deemed exports are identical to those for physical exports; (iii) Claim can be made on All Industry Rates without furnishing proof of actual customs duty paid; (iv) Relevant FTP paragraphs (6.11, 8.3(b), 8.5), HBP paragraphs (8.3.3, 8.3.6) and notifications No.92/2012‑C, No.98/2013‑C, No.110/2014‑C, Circulars 24/2001 and 13/2014‑C support the claim. Respondents: (i) FTP, as implemented by DGFT, requires proof of duty paid for drawback; (ii) Sections 2(e)(i), 5, 6(1), 6(2) of the FTDR Act vest interpretative authority in DGFT; (iii) Deemed export scheme is intended to neutralise duty on inputs only when actual duty has been paid; (iv) Without evidence of customs duty, the claim cannot be entertained.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the statutory scheme governing duty drawback, focusing on the Foreign Trade Policy 2009‑14, the Handbook of Procedures, and the Customs Excise and Duty Drawback Rules, 1995. It held that while the policy encourages export promotion, the entitlement to drawback on the customs duty component is conditioned upon the claimant demonstrating that duty has actually been paid on the inputs used. The notifications cited by the petitioner were interpreted as procedural guidelines that do not override the statutory requirement of evidentiary proof. The Court also relied on the precedent of Sarla Performance Fibers Ltd. v. Union of India, which affirmed the necessity of compliance with the procedural safeguards before granting drawback. Consequently, the petitioner's claim was found to be untenable, and the petition was dismissed.
key_legal_points: Duty drawback on customs duty component for deemed exports requires proof of actual duty paid.
All Industry Rates can be used only when statutory conditions, including evidentiary requirements, are satisfied.
The DGFT has the authority to interpret and implement the Foreign Trade Policy under the FTDR Act.
Notifications and circulars are subordinate to the statutory framework and cannot supplant mandatory proof requirements.
Precedent (Sarla Performance Fibers Ltd.) confirms the necessity of compliance with procedural safeguards.
legal_issues: Entitlement to duty drawback for deemed exports after conversion to EOU.
Whether proof of customs duty paid on inputs is mandatory for claiming drawback.
Interpretative authority of DGFT under the FTDR Act.
Effect of policy circulars and notifications on statutory requirements.
precedents_cited: Sarla Performance Fibers Ltd. v. Union of India, W.P. 7210/2017, 27 April 2018 (Bombay High Court)

case_type: Arbitration Petition under Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996
primary_legal_issue: Whether the contractual dispute can be referred to arbitration under Clause 70 of the General Conditions of Contracts and Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996.
summary: The petition filed by NEW OM CONSTRUCTION CO. seeks appointment of an arbitrator to resolve a dispute arising from a construction contract awarded by the Chief Engineer (AF) Palam in October 2013 for security infrastructure at AF STN NAL. The contract, valued at approximately Rs. 4.09 crore, was to be completed within 15 months but was delayed due to the respondent’s failure to finalise the scope of work, incorporate changes, and release payments. The petitioner alleges loss of turnover, interest on locked capital, and non‑payment of final bills. Clause 70 of the General Conditions of Contracts mandates arbitration by a person with an engineering qualification. The petitioner invoked Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, seeking court‑ordered referral to arbitration. The respondent does not oppose arbitration but emphasizes the engineering qualification requirement. The court, after noting the parties’ positions, orders the disputes to be referred to Mr. K.N. Agarwal (Retd. DG, CPWD) as arbitrator, directs compliance with Section 12(2) for disclosure, and leaves all factual and legal issues to the arbitrator. The petition is disposed.
facts: In October 2013, the petitioner was awarded a contract to construct security infrastructure for sensitive locations at AF STN NAL. The work was to start on 10‑Nov‑2013 and finish by 09‑Feb‑2015. The petitioner mobilised resources but faced delays because the respondent did not finalise the scope, introduced changes without fixing a new timeline, and failed to release payments, leading to financial loss. The work was eventually completed on 17‑Jun‑2019, after which the respondent issued a completion certificate.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the respondent’s unilateral changes, non‑payment, and failure to provide a clear schedule amounted to a breach, justifying arbitration under Clause 70 and Section 11(6). Respondent did not oppose arbitration but highlighted that the arbitrator must possess an engineering qualification as per Clause 70.
judgment_reasoning: The court observed that Clause 70 expressly requires an arbitrator with an engineering degree and that Section 11(6) empowers the court to refer disputes to arbitration when parties cannot agree. Since the respondent did not object to arbitration and only raised the qualification issue, the court appointed a suitably qualified arbitrator, Mr. K.N. Agarwal, and ordered compliance with procedural requirements under the 1996 Act.
key_legal_points: Clause 70 of the contract mandates an arbitrator with engineering qualifications
Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act allows court‑ordered referral to arbitration
The respondent’s non‑objection to arbitration satisfies the requirement for appointment
The appointed arbitrator must disclose interests under Section 12(2)
legal_issues: Interpretation of Clause 70 regarding arbitrator qualifications
Applicability of Section 11(6) for court‑ordered arbitration
Whether the respondent’s conduct justifies arbitration

primary_legal_issue: Whether the parties may, by mutual consent, replace a three‑member arbitral tribunal agreed in the contract with a sole arbitrator and obtain a court appointment under Section 11 of the Arbitration Act.
summary: The Delhi High Court, on 8 January 2021, dealt with a series of arbitration petitions filed under Section 11 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, by several ATS group companies and Mr. Getamber Anand against Dalmia Family Office Trust. The petitions arose from nine distinct transactions covered by various Investment, Supplemental, Corporate Guarantee and Personal Guarantee agreements dated between 2013 and 2019. While the contractual arbitration clauses prescribed a three‑member tribunal for some agreements and a sole arbitrator for others, the parties mutually agreed to have all disputes adjudicated by a sole arbitrator, a former Supreme Court judge, without disturbing other contractual terms. The Court noted the commonality of issues across the petitions and, with the parties’ consent, consolidated the orders, directing the appointment of the agreed sole arbitrator. The judgment affirmed that parties may modify the number of arbitrators by agreement and that the court may appoint an arbitrator under Section 11, thereby allowing the petitions seeking a sole arbitrator to proceed.
facts: Multiple arbitration petitions were filed under Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 by five ATS group companies and Mr. Getamber Anand against Dalmia Family Office Trust. The disputes stemmed from nine transactions governed by Investment, Supplemental, Corporate Guarantee and Personal Guarantee agreements executed between 2013 and 2019. The contracts contained differing arbitration clauses—some mandating a three‑member tribunal, others a sole arbitrator. The parties later agreed to resolve all disputes through a sole arbitrator, a former Supreme Court judge.
arguments: Petitioners sought appointment of either a sole arbitrator or the respondent’s nominee arbitrator, arguing that the arbitration clauses allowed such appointments and that the court could intervene under Section 11. Respondents contested the number of arbitrators, citing contractual provisions for a three‑member panel. Both sides eventually consented to a sole arbitrator, emphasizing efficiency and commonality of issues.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that Section 11 empowers it to appoint arbitrators when parties cannot agree. It held that parties may, by mutual consent, alter the agreed number of arbitrators without breaching the arbitration agreement. Given the common factual matrix, the Court found consolidation appropriate and ordered the appointment of the agreed sole arbitrator, a former Supreme Court judge, thereby allowing the petitions to proceed.

Parties may modify the number of arbitrators stipulated in the arbitration clause by mutual consent
Consolidation of multiple arbitration petitions is permissible when they share common issues
A former Supreme Court judge can be appointed as sole arbitrator under the parties’ agreement

Validity of parties’ agreement to replace a three‑member tribunal with a sole arbitrator
Court’s power to appoint arbitrator(s) under Section 11
Consolidation of multiple arbitration petitions

case_type: Arbitration – appointment of arbitrator under Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Delhi Jal Board could unilaterally appoint a sole arbitrator under Clause 8.1.2 of the contract and the applicability of Supreme Court precedents on unilateral appointment and arbitrator ineligibility.
summary: The petition filed by VSK Technologies Private Limited and others seeks appointment of a sole arbitrator to resolve a payment dispute arising from a Water Tanker Supply Services contract for Zone‑V, entered into on 27‑08‑2012 with the Delhi Jal Board (DJB). After the contract was executed, DJB allegedly defaulted on payments for August‑October 2020. The petitioner invoked the arbitration clause (Clause 8.1.2) and proposed a former Chief Justice as arbitrator, which DJB rejected. DJB later nominated Justice (Retd) Iqbal Ahmed Ansari as sole arbitrator. The petitioner challenged this unilateral appointment under Section 11(6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, contending that the appointment was contrary to the contract and Supreme Court rulings in Perkins Eastman and related cases. DJB argued that the appointment was permissible, citing the contract’s provision that DJB could nominate an arbitrator if parties failed to agree within a month, and relying on precedents such as TRF Ltd. v. Energo and Central Organization for Railway Electrification. The court examined the contractual language, the statutory framework, and the cited precedents to determine whether DJB’s appointment was valid and whether the petitioner’s application for court‑appointed arbitrator should be dismissed. The judgment ultimately disposed of the application, addressing the scope of Section 11(6) and the effect of the parties’ agreement on arbitrator nomination.
facts: The DJB issued an RFP for water‑tanker services; VSK Technologies submitted a bid, received a Letter of Intent on 16‑07‑2012, and entered into a formal agreement on 27‑08‑2012 for Zone‑V services. VSK performed the contract but alleges DJB failed to pay invoices for August‑October 2020. VSK issued a notice on 20‑11‑2012 invoking the arbitration clause and suggested a former Chief Justice as arbitrator. DJB rejected the suggestion, later proposing two former judges, which VSK also rejected. On 31‑12‑2020 DJB nominated Justice (Retd) Iqbal Ahmed Ansari as sole arbitrator. VSK filed an application under Section 11(6) of the A&C Act seeking court appointment of an arbitrator and interim relief, which was denied. VSK subsequently appealed the denial under Section 37.
arguments: Petitioner argued that DJB’s unilateral appointment violated the arbitration clause and that Supreme Court decisions in Perkins Eastman and TRF Ltd. preclude such appointments where the appointing party has not complied with agreed procedures. Petitioner's counsel also highlighted procedural irregularities in DJB’s internal orders and circulars. Respondent contended that the contract expressly allows DJB to nominate an arbitrator if parties cannot agree within a month, that the nominated arbitrator was from a panel and thus eligible, and that the cited Supreme Court cases were factually distinct and not applicable. Respondent relied on Central Organization for Railway Electrification and Standard Corrosion Controls decisions to support the validity of panel‑based appointments.
judgment_reasoning: The court examined Clause 8.1.2, which provides that if parties cannot agree on an arbitrator within one month, DJB may nominate one. The court held that the contractual provision is clear and overrides any procedural objections, provided the nominee is not statutorily ineligible under Section 12(5). The nominated arbitrator, a retired judge, did not fall within the categories of ineligibility. The court distinguished Perkins Eastman, noting that case involved a failure to appoint within a statutory period, whereas here the contract itself authorized DJB’s nomination after the one‑month lapse. Accordingly, the court found DJB’s appointment valid and dismissed the petition for court‑appointed arbitrator.
key_legal_points: Clause 8.1.2 authorises DJB to nominate an arbitrator after a one‑month dead‑lock
Section 12(5) bars persons with a specified relationship from acting as arbitrator
The Supreme Court’s Perkins Eastman ruling is limited to cases where the appointing authority loses the right to appoint after missing a statutory deadline
A nominee from a panel of former judges is not ineligible under the Act

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner, Bharat Abhilash, is entitled to bail under Section 439 of the Criminal Procedure Code in view of the grave nature of the offences (rape, attempt to murder, etc.) and the procedural history of the case.
summary: The Delhi High Court considered bail application No.28/2021 filed by Bharat Abhilash under Section 439 Cr.P.C. The application arose from FIR No.115/2018, which alleged offences under Sections 376, 306, 506, 323 and 109 IPC and Sections 6 and 17 of the POCSO Act. The alleged victim, a minor aged 16 at the time, claimed repeated sexual assaults by the accused and others. The petitioner argued that his wife had already been granted bail, that he was the sole breadwinner, that the victim’s statements were inconsistent and recorded under the influence of poison, and that the investigation violated Section 35 of the POCSO Act by not completing evidence collection within 30 days. He also cited several Supreme Court precedents supporting bail in similar circumstances. The State opposed, emphasizing the seriousness of the gang‑rape allegations, the victim’s corroborated statements, and the fact that the petitioner and his wife were arrested after a prolonged period due to alleged absconding. The Court noted the gravity of the charges, the incomplete victim testimony, and the pandemic‑related trial delays, concluding that bail could not be granted. Accordingly, the application was dismissed without expressing any opinion on the merits of the underlying criminal case.
facts: On 11 April 2018 a medical report (MLC) was filed at Paschim Vihar police station. The victim, a 16‑year‑old girl, alleged that the accused Ram Lal (also known as Ganna) repeatedly raped her, threatening to kill her parents. The FIR (No.115/2018) was lodged on 13 January 2018 under Sections 376, 306, 506, 323, 109 IPC and Sections 6 and 17 of the POCSO Act. The victim’s statements were recorded under Sections 161 and 164 Cr.P.C. The petitioner, Bharat Abhilash, was arrested on 17 January 2020, more than 1.5 years after the FIR, and has been in judicial custody since. The victim’s medical reports indicated pesticide consumption and UPT positivity. The victim’s examination‑in‑chief was ongoing at the time of the bail hearing.
arguments: Petitioner’s counsel argued that (i) the petitioner’s wife had already obtained bail, warranting parity; (ii) the petitioner is the family’s sole supporter and his prolonged custody is unjustified; (iii) the victim’s statements were unreliable, recorded under the influence of poison, and she could not identify the petitioner; (iv) the investigation violated Section 35 of the POCSO Act by not completing evidence collection within 30 days; and (v) cited Supreme Court decisions (Vinay v Karnataka, Siddharam Mhetre v Maharashtra, Panchhi v UP, Dataram Singh v Uttar Pradesh) supporting bail in similar contexts. The State’s APP contended that the offences are grave gang‑rape of a minor, the victim’s statements are corroborated by medical reports, the petitioner was arrested after a legitimate investigation, and bail would jeopardise the investigation and public interest.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the allegations involve a serious gang‑rape of a minor, supported by medical evidence and the victim’s recorded statements. The petitioner’s claim of procedural lapse under Section 35 POCSO was rejected as the investigation and evidence collection were ongoing. The Court noted that the victim’s testimony, though incomplete, was being examined‑in‑chief and could not be dismissed. The delay in arrest was explained by the petitioner’s alleged absconding, not by investigative negligence. Given the gravity of the offences, the risk of tampering with evidence, and the public interest in ensuring a fair trial, the Court concluded that bail could not be granted and dismissed the application.
key_legal_points: The seriousness of gang‑rape of a minor outweighs the petitioner’s personal hardships.
Procedural delays do not automatically merit bail where investigation is ongoing.
Medical evidence and victim’s statements under Sections 161/164 Cr.P.C. were deemed credible.
Section 35 POCSO procedural requirement was not fatal to bail denial.
Pandemic‑related trial delays do not justify bail in grave offences.
legal_issues: Whether the petitioner is entitled to bail under Section 439 Cr.P.C. despite serious charges.
Whether the investigation complied with Section 35 of the POCSO Act.
Whether the victim’s statements, recorded under alleged intoxication, are reliable for bail consideration.
Impact of prolonged pre‑trial detention on bail eligibility.

case_type: Arbitration Appeal under Section 37 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Delhi High Court has jurisdiction to issue an injunction against the appellants, who are only "Reference Entities" under the Facility Agreement, in a Section‑9 petition under the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996.
summary: The appellants – Eveready Industries India Ltd, McLeod Russel Pvt Ltd and McNally Bharat Engineering Co. Ltd – filed appeals under Section 37 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 challenging a single‑judge order dated 23‑Nov‑2020 that upheld an interim injunction restraining them from dealing with their assets and altering their capital structure. The injunction stemmed from a Section 9 petition filed by KKR India Financial Services Ltd (a non‑banking financial company) and its security trustee, seeking to enforce a Facility Agreement dated 27‑Sept‑2017 entered with two borrowers, guarantors and an obligor. The respondents argued that the appellants, identified as “Reference Entities” in the agreement, were liable for the loan and therefore fell within the “Group Companies Doctrine”. The appellants contended they had no privity of contract, were not parties to the Facility Agreement, and thus the court lacked jurisdiction to restrain them. The High Court, after hearing counsel and reviewing written submissions, considered the definitions in the Facility Agreement and the scope of Section 9. It ultimately disposed of the appeals, affirming the lower court’s injunction on the ground that the appellants, as reference entities, could be subject to the injunction despite the absence of a direct contractual relationship.
facts: The respondents, a financial services company and its security trustee, entered into a Facility Agreement with two borrowers, guarantors and an obligor for a loan of INR 100 crore. The agreement contained guarantees and security provisions, and identified certain group companies as “Reference Entities”. The borrowers defaulted, prompting the respondents to invoke Section 9 of the Arbitration Act to obtain an interim injunction restraining the borrowers, guarantors, obligor and the reference entities (the appellants) from dealing with their assets or altering their capital structure. The single judge granted the injunction on 13‑Dec‑2019 and dismissed an application for its vacation on 23‑Nov‑2020. The appellants appealed, claiming no contractual liability and lack of jurisdiction.
arguments: Appellants argued (i) they are not parties to the Facility Agreement and have no privity of contract; (ii) the definitions of Guarantor, Obligor, Pledgor and Security Provider do not apply to them; (iii) they are merely “Reference Entities” without obligations, so the court cannot restrain them under Section 9. Respondents argued (i) the Facility Agreement’s Group Companies Doctrine extends liability to reference entities; (ii) the loan was granted on the basis of the collective creditworthiness of the group, including the appellants; (iii) the injunction is necessary to protect the security interests of the lenders.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the Facility Agreement’s clauses, particularly the definition of “Reference Entity”, and held that the agreement expressly contemplated the inclusion of such entities within the security framework. It reasoned that Section 9 of the Arbitration Act permits a court to grant interim relief to preserve the status quo pending arbitration, and that the respondents’ claim of a collective guarantee justified extending the injunction to the reference entities. Consequently, the Court affirmed the lower court’s order, finding that the appellants could be restrained despite the absence of a direct contractual relationship.
key_legal_points: Section 9 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act allows interim injunctions to preserve the status quo pending arbitration
The definition of “Reference Entity” in a Facility Agreement can attract injunctive relief under Section 9
Group Companies Doctrine may extend liability to entities not directly party to the loan agreement
legal_issues: Jurisdiction of the court to restrain non‑party “Reference Entities” under Section 9
Interpretation of contractual definitions in the context of arbitration‑related injunctions

primary_legal_issue: Whether the appellant UPSRTC is liable for the injuries sustained by the claimant and whether the compensation award by the tribunal should be set aside.
summary: The appeal (MAC.APP.5/2021) filed by UP State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) challenges a tribunal award dated 18 July 2020 that granted compensation to the claimant, Nareder Sharma, for injuries sustained in a road accident on 6 October 2016. The claimant was riding a TVS Vicky when a UPSRTC bus, allegedly traveling at high speed, collided with his vehicle at the Loni Gol Chakkar round‑about. UPSRTC contends that the claimant’s own rash and negligent driving caused the accident, asserting that the bus was stationary at a red light and the claimant applied sudden brakes, leading to a skid. The tribunal examined cross‑examinations, a joint written statement, and a mechanical inspection report showing fresh damage on the claimant’s bike consistent with impact from the bus. The court noted contradictions in the driver’s testimony, the fabricated nature of the joint statement, and the nature of the injuries (fracture of ankle and foot) indicating blunt‑force impact rather than abrasions typical of a skid. Applying the pre‑ponderance of probabilities test, the court found no infirmity in the tribunal’s award and dismissed the appeal. The judgment underscores the evidentiary burden on the appellant to overturn a compensation award and affirms the tribunal’s factual findings.
facts: On 6 October 2016 at about 01:45 pm, the claimant was riding a TVS Vicky from Seelampur to Yumnavihar. At Loni Gol Chakkar round‑about a UPSRTC bus, driven at high speed, allegedly struck the claimant’s bike, causing him to fall and sustain grievous injuries (fracture of right ankle, foot, and fabula). UPSRTC argues the bus was stopped at a red light and the claimant applied sudden brakes, causing his bike to skid and hit the stationary bus. The tribunal recorded testimonies, a joint written statement, and a mechanical inspection report indicating impact damage on the bike.
arguments: Appellant (UPSRTC) argued that the claimant’s own rash driving and sudden braking caused the accident, that the bus was stationary at a red signal, and that the claimant’s version was inconsistent. Respondent (claimant) maintained that the bus was moving at high speed, rashly entered the round‑about, and hit his bike, causing the injuries. The tribunal highlighted contradictions in the bus driver’s testimony, the fabricated joint statement, and the mechanical evidence supporting the claimant’s version.
judgment_reasoning: The court examined the cross‑examinations, noting contradictions in the bus driver’s statements and the joint written statement, which appeared fabricated. The mechanical inspection report showed fresh damage on the claimant’s bike consistent with impact from the bus, not merely a skid. The nature of the injuries (fractures) indicated blunt‑force impact rather than abrasions typical of a slip. Applying the pre‑ponderance of probabilities test, the tribunal’s findings were upheld. No infirmity was found in the award; therefore, the appeal lacked merit and was dismissed.
key_legal_points: Contradictory testimonies of the bus driver were fatal to the appellant’s case
Mechanical inspection report corroborated impact by the bus
Nature of injuries indicated blunt‑force impact, not a skid
Pre‑ponderance of probabilities test applied to factual dispute
Tribunal’s award upheld due to lack of merit in appeal
legal_issues: Liability of UPSRTC for the accident
Whether the claimant’s injuries were caused by the bus or by his own driving
Standard of proof required to overturn a compensation award

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner’s mental disorder is attributable to or aggravated by military service for the purpose of granting a disability pension
summary: The petition filed by Rajesh Kumar challenged the Armed Forces Tribunal’s order rejecting his claim for a disability pension. The petitioner argued that his mental disorder, which manifested within three months of enrolment, was either caused by or aggravated by military service, invoking Supreme Court precedents that presume service‑related disability when no prior record exists. The High Court examined the medical board’s findings, the timing of symptom onset (12 December 2012), and the short nine‑month service period. It noted that the disability arose shortly after enrolment, making a causal link to service tenuous. The Court relied on Dharmavir Singh’s principles that the burden of proof lies on the employer and on Narsingh Yadav, which cautioned against a mechanical presumption of service‑related disability. Concluding that the petitioner’s service duration was insufficient to cause the disorder and that the medical board’s opinion was not rebutted by strong evidence, the Court upheld the Tribunal’s decision and dismissed the writ petition.
facts: Petitioner Rajesh Kumar enlisted on 24 September 2012. Within three months (by 12 December 2012) he exhibited psychotic symptoms during basic training. He was admitted to Base Hospital, Delhi Cantt., and later declared medically unfit. The Armed Forces Tribunal, relying on the Invaliding Medical Board (IMB), rejected his claim for a disability pension, holding the disorder not attributable to service. The petitioner sought a pension from 26 June 2013 at 60% (rounded to 75%) with interest.
arguments: Petitioner contended that the disorder manifested during training, thus attributable to service, and that the medical board made no note of any disability at enrolment, invoking Dharmavir Singh (2013) which presumes service‑related disability in such cases. He argued that the burden of proof lies on the employer and that reasonable doubt should favor the claimant. Respondents relied on the IMB’s assessment, the short service period, and the principle that each case must be examined individually, citing Narsingh Yadav (2019) against a blanket presumption.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the three‑month interval between enrolment and symptom onset was insufficient to establish a causal link between military service and the mental disorder. It affirmed the IMB’s finding that the disability was neither attributable nor aggravated by service, emphasizing that the burden of proof rests on the employer and that the medical board’s opinion stands unless contradicted by strong evidence. The Court also reiterated that mental disorders may escape detection at enrolment, but this does not automatically render them service‑related. Consequently, the Tribunal’s order was upheld and the petition dismissed.
key_legal_points: Short service duration (nine months) insufficient to attribute mental disorder to military service
Burden of proof lies on employer/defence to show non‑attributability
Medical Board’s opinion is conclusive absent strong contrary evidence
Each case must be examined on its facts; no mechanical presumption of service‑related disability

CORAM:  
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE MANMOHAN 
HON'BLE MS. JUSTICE ASHA MENON 
J U D G M E N T  
MANMOHAN, J (Oral) :  
1. Present writ petition has been filed challenging the order d ated 
26th February, 2020 passed by the Armed Forces Tribunal – Principal Bench, 
New Delhi in OA No. 470/2015, whereby petitioner’s claim for disability 
pension has been rejected.  Petitioner also prays for a direction to the 
respondents to grant disability pension to the petitioner w.e.f. 26th June, 
2013 @ 60% (rounding off 75%) along with interest @18% th ereon.  The 
relevant portion of the impugned order is reproduced hereinbelow:-  
“6. On careful perusal of the medical documents, it has been 
observed that the applicant was enrolled on 24.09.2012 a nd the 
disease had first started on 12.12.2012 i.e. within three  months of 
joining the service. He was administered treatment at Base 
Hospital, Delhi Cantt. On admission in the Hospital the case 
history of the applicant was endorsed by Lt Col Siddharth  Dixit, 
W.P. (C) 46/2021                                                                          Page 2 of 6 
 Classified Specialist (Psy) as under:- 
 
History of present illness . This recruit ·was apparently well 
about till last wk of Nov 12 while undergoing recruitment 
training at Raj Rif (wef 24 Sep 2012 till 12 Dec 12), He was 
noted to remain aloof, socially withdrawn and crying 
intermittently. He felt people around him are plott ing against 
him and trying to harm him. He became anxious, fearful, and 
kept to himself. He was heard claiming "gaon walon nai jaal 
bichaya hai woh chalnai main rukawat dalate hain tab main 
theek say chal nahin paata." He was seen by his colleagues to 
muttering and gesticulating also. He has complained  of 
hearing voices of person commenting in derogatory manner 
and threatening him (maar doonga bahar aa sonai nahin 
doonga). He was worried and tried intermittently. He 
neglected personal hygiene and food intake. Over another 
week he stopped attending to routine duties at training centre 
and remained awake at the night. Noticing his behavioural 
abnormalities he was admitted along with escorts for further 
management by psychiatrist at BHDC. He h/o fever he ad 
injury or substance abuse. 
 
xxxx xxxx xxx 
 
Management Recommended . In view of genetic loading first 
degree relative, poor response to treatment modality and 
onset of psychotic breakdown during recruit phase of training 
he is unlikely to withstand stress and strain of soldiers life. 
Hence recommended to be invalided out of service.xx xxxx 
 
7. In the above scenario, we are of the option that since the 
disease has started in less than three months of his e nrolment, 
hence by no stretch of imagination, it can be concluded th at it has 
been caused by stress and strains of military service. Addi tionally, 
it is well known that mental disorders can escape detectio n at the 
time of enrolment hence benefit of doubt cannot be given to  the 
applicant merely on the ground that the disease could n ot be 
detected at the time of enrolment. Since there is no casual 
connection between this disease and military service, hence we 
are in agreement with the opinion of the IMB that the disea se is 
W.P. (C) 46/2021                                                                          Page 3 of 6 
 NANA. Additionally, a recruit is akin to a probationer and hence 
prima facie the respondents as an employer have every right to  
discharge a recruit who is not meeting the medical requi rement of 
military service and is not likely to become a good soldier. In view 
of the foregoing and the fact that the disease manifested in less 
than three months, of enrolment, we are in agreement with the 
opinion of IMB that the disease is NANA.”  
 
2. Learned counsel for the petitioner states that the petitioner  was not 
suffering from any disability at the time of enrollment and was fo und to be 
medically fit at that time by the medical board. He points out that the 
petitioner developed the disability during basic training and  therefore, the 
petitioner is entitled to the disability pension.  He emphasizes that the disease 
of the petitioner is either attributable to or aggravated due to stress and strain 
of military service as the Medical Board made no note of the disease at t he 
time of enrolment. In support of his submission, he relies up on the judgment 
of the Supreme Court in Dharmavir Singh Vs. Union of India & Ors., 
(2013)7 SCC 316 , wherein it has been held as under:-  
“29. A conjoint reading of various provisions, reprodu ced above, 
makes it clear that: 
29.1 Disability pension to be granted to an individua l who is 
invalidated from service on account of a disability whic h is 
attributable to or aggravated by military service in non-b attle 
casualty and is assessed at 20% or over. The question wheth er a 
disability is attributable or aggravated by military s ervice to be 
determined under “Entitlement Rules for Casualty Pensio nary 
Awards, 1982" of Appendix-II (Regulation 173). 
 
29.2 A member is to be presumed in sound physical and m ental 
condition upon entering service if there is no note or rec ord at the 
time of entrance. In the event of his subsequently being discha rged 
W.P. (C) 46/2021                                                                          Page 4 of 6 
 from service on medical grounds any deterioration in hi s health is 
to be presumed due to service. [Rule 5 r/w Rule 14(b)]. 
 
29.3 Onus of proof is not on the claimant (employee), the 
corollary is that onus of proof that the condition for  non-
entitlement is with the employer. A claimant has a right to  derive 
benefit of any reasonable doubt and is entitled for pe nsionary 
benefit more liberally. (Rule 9). 
 
29.4 If a disease is accepted to have been as having arisen in 
service, it must also be established that the conditions of  military 
service determined or contributed to the onset of the disea se and 
that the conditions were due to the circumstances of duty in 
military service. [Rule 14(c)]. 
 
29.5 If no note of any disability or disease was made at  the time 
of individual's acceptance for military service, a disease which ha s 
led to an individual's discharge or death will be deemed t o have 
arisen in service. [14(b)]. 
 
29.6 If medical opinion holds that the disease could n ot have 
been detected on medical examination prior to the acceptan ce for 
service and that disease will not be deemed to have arisen duri ng 
service, the Medical Board is required to state the reasons.  
[14(b)]; and 
 
29.7 It is mandatory for the Medical Board to follow the 
guidelines laid down in Chapter-II of the "Guide to Medical  
(Military Pension), 2002 – "Entitledment : General Principles", 
including paragraph 7,8 and 9 as referred to above. ” 
 
3. Having heard the learned counsel for the petitioner, this Court  finds 
that the petitioner was enrolled on 24th September, 2012 and as noted in the 
impugned order, he started developing symptoms attributable to the 
disease/disability within three months and had to be treated at Bas e Hospital, 
Delhi Cantt. The date of origin of the disability is noted as 12th December, 
2012 in the medical board proceedings, which is annexed to the present 
W.P. (C) 46/2021                                                                          Page 5 of 6 
 petition. The total period of service is only nine months as the peti tioner was 
boarded out on 25th June, 2013.  
4. Consequently, this Court is of the view that the Invalidin g Medical 
Board [IMB] as well as the tribunal were correct in holding that t he 
disability was neither attributable nor aggravated by milit ary service as the 
time spent in service was too short to cause stress or strain th at might lead to 
such a disability.  
5. Further, this Court is also in agreement with the Tribunal that  certain 
mental disorders might escape detection at the time of enrollment  by the 
Medical Board. The Supreme Court in Narsingh Yadav v. Union of India, 
(2019) 9 SCC 667  has held that there cannot be a mechanical application of 
the principle that “any disorder not mentioned at the time of enrollment is 
presumed to be attributed to or aggravated by milit ary service”.  Every case 
has to be examined and it has to be ascertained whether the duti es assigned 
to the individual might have lead to the disorder. The Supreme Co urt while 
confirming the findings of the IMB in the said case, wherein the a ppellant 
had been in service for more than three years, held as under:-  
“18. Therefore, each case has to be examined whether the duties 
assigned to the individual may have led to stress and st rain leading 
to psychosis and psychoneurosis. Relapsing forms of ment al 
disorders which have intervals of normality and epilepsy  are 
undetectable diseases while carrying out physical examina tion on 
enrolment, unless adequate history is given at the time by  the 
member. 
 
19. The appellant was a young boy of 18 years at the time o f 
enrolment and had been boarded within 3½ years of his serv ice. 
Even if he was suffering from any mental disorder prior t o 
enrolment, the same could not be detected as there were intervals  
of normality. The appellant was posted in peace station as a 
Vehicle Mechanic. Neither the nature of job nor the place o f 
W.P. (C) 46/2021                                                                          Page 6 of 6 
 posting was such which could have caused stress and strain leading 
to disability as attributed to or aggravated by military servi ce. 
 
20. In the present case, Rule 14(d), as amended in the year 1 996 
and reproduced above, would be applicable as entitlement to 
disability pension shall not be considered unless it i s clearly 
established that the cause of such disease was adversely aff ected 
due to factors related to conditions of military serv ice. Though, the 
provision of grant of disability pension is a beneficia l provision 
but, mental disorder at the time of recruitment cannot no rmally be 
detected when a person behaves normally. Since there is a 
possibility of non-detection of mental disorder, therefo re, it cannot 
be said that schizophrenia is presumed to be attribut ed to or 
aggravated by military service. 
21. Though, the opinion of the Medical Board is subject to judicial 
review but the courts are not possessed of expertise to dispu te such 
report unless there is strong medical evidence on record to d ispute 
the opinion of the Medical Board which may warrant the  
constitution of the Review Medical Board. The invaliding M edical 
Board has categorically held that the appellant is no t fit for further 
service and there is no material on record to doubt the co rrectness 
of the report of the invaliding Medical Board.”  
 
6. In view of the aforesaid as well as the report of the IMB, this Court is 
not inclined to interfere with the impugned order.  
7. Consequently, the present petition is dismissed.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioners are entitled to pro‑rata pension on the same basis as granted in Brijlal Kumar and Govind Kumar Srivastava cases.
summary: The Delhi High Court heard three civil writ petitions (WP(C) 33, 43 and 49 of 2021) filed by former armed forces personnel seeking pro‑rata pension similar to that awarded in earlier judgments (Brijlal Kumar v. Union of India, 2020 SCC OnLine Del 1477 and Govind Kumar Srivastava v. Union of India, 2019 SCC OnLine Del 6425). The petitioners, represented by Ms. Pallavi Awasthi, claimed they were similarly situated to the earlier petitioners and had filed the requisite No‑Objection Certificates. The respondents, Union of India, argued that verification and the right to appeal to the Supreme Court should be preserved. The Court, after video‑conferenced hearing, directed the Indian Air Force to verify the petitioners' eligibility within twelve weeks and, if found eligible, to pay arrears of pro‑rata pension from the date of discharge, with interest at 7% per annum on delayed payments. If any petitioner is found ineligible, the respondents must provide written reasons. The order was to be uploaded online and communicated to counsel. The judgment essentially extends the relief granted in the earlier cases, subject to verification, thereby allowing the petitioners to claim pro‑rata pension.
facts: Three former armed forces personnel—Shivashish Shubham, Pradeep Chandra Nahak and Vipin Kumar Yadav—filed writ petitions claiming entitlement to pro‑rata pension. They asserted that they were in the same position as petitioners in the Brijlal Kumar and Govind Kumar Srivastava cases, for which the Court had ordered payment of pro‑rata pension. The petitioners submitted No‑Objection Certificates and sought the same relief. The Union of India, as respondent, contested the claim, emphasizing the need for verification and preserving the right to appeal any adverse decision to the Supreme Court.
arguments: Petitioners argued that the earlier judgments set a precedent granting pro‑rata pension to similarly placed former service members and that they satisfied all procedural requirements, including filing NOCs. Respondents contended that each case must be individually verified, that the right to appeal to the Supreme Court should remain intact, and that the Court should not grant relief without confirming eligibility.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the petitioners' situation mirrors that of the earlier cases and that the relief granted therein was based on the principle of equity for similarly situated former service members. However, it emphasized the necessity of verification to ensure that the petitioners meet the criteria established in the precedent cases. The Court therefore ordered verification within twelve weeks and directed payment of arrears and future pro‑rata pension if eligibility is confirmed, with interest on delayed payments. It also preserved the respondents' right to appeal to the Supreme Court.
key_legal_points: Pro‑rata pension entitlement is extended to similarly placed former service members.
Verification of eligibility is mandatory before granting relief.
Interest at 7% per annum applies to delayed pension payments.
The right to appeal to the Supreme Court is preserved.
legal_issues: Entitlement to pro‑rata pension for former armed forces personnel.
Applicability of earlier judgments to new petitioners.
Procedural requirement of verification before granting pension relief.

acts_referred: National Capital Territory of Delhi Laws (Special Provisions) Second (Amendment) Act, 2017
primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner is entitled to continuation of interim protection against demolition while the appeal before the AT‑MCD is pending.
summary: The petitioner, V.M. Singh, filed W.P.(C) 50/2021 challenging an order dated 25.11.2020 that dismissed his appeal against a demolition order dated 06.10.2017. The petitioner claimed that his property is protected under the National Capital Territory of Delhi Laws (Special Provisions) Second (Amendment) Act, 2017, and that no statement was made to apply for regularisation of the unauthorised construction. The High Court noted that the appeal before the AT‑MCD was still pending and that an interim protection order dated 05.01.2021 barred coercive action against the petitioner. The Court directed that the interim protection continue until the AT‑MCD decides the appeal, but the petitioner must not carry out any further construction. The Court also instructed the AT‑MCD to dispose of the appeal in accordance with law without any special equity. All rights and contentions of the parties were reserved. The petition was therefore disposed with the continuation of interim protection.
facts: The petitioner owned a property for which a demolition order was issued on 06.10.2017 by the municipal authority. He appealed the demolition order, and the appeal was pending before the AT‑MCD. On 25.11.2020 the High Court dismissed his petition, noting a statement that the petitioner would apply for regularisation. The petitioner contended that no such statement was made and that the property is protected under the 2017 amendment Act. An interim protection order dated 05.01.2021 prevented coercive action against him.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the property is covered by the National Capital Territory of Delhi Laws (Special Provisions) Second (Amendment) Act, 2017, and that no admission was made to seek regularisation, thus entitling him to interim protection. Respondents relied on the earlier demolition order and the alleged statement by the petitioner indicating intent to regularise, seeking enforcement of demolition.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the appeal before the AT‑MCD remained pending and that an interim protection order already barred coercive action. Since the appeal had not been decided, the Court could not grant any further relief beyond preserving the status quo. Consequently, the Court ordered that the interim protection continue until the AT‑MCD decides the appeal, while prohibiting any new construction by the petitioner. The Court emphasized that the AT‑MCD must decide the appeal according to law without any special equity.
key_legal_points: Interim protection orders remain effective until the substantive appeal is decided.
Pending appeals before administrative tribunals cannot be overridden by the High Court.
The petitioner must refrain from further construction pending final determination.
legal_issues: Continuation of interim protection pending appeal.
Effect of alleged statement to regularise unauthorised construction.
Application of the 2017 amendment Act to the property.

acts_referred: Delhi High Court (Public Interest Litigation) Rules, 2010
primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner can seek mandamus to compel a tax investigation under the Informants Rewards Scheme when the petition does not qualify as a public interest litigation and is driven by personal interest.
summary: Anil Singhal filed W.P.(C) 54/2021 seeking a mandamus directing the Directorate of Income Tax Investigation and the Member Investigation, CBDT, to conduct a time-bound investigation against M/s Jagdish Prasad Agarwal and M/s Vijay Automobiles under two Tax Evasion Petitions (TEPs) dated 20 June 2020 and 18 March 2020, and to treat these TEPs under the Income Tax Informants Rewards Scheme, 2018. The petitioner claimed to act as a public‑spirited individual but failed to comply with the Delhi High Court (Public Interest Litigation) Rules, 2010, which require a declaration of no personal interest. The court observed that the petitioner’s father‑in‑law was a partner in the entities against which the complaints were lodged, and the petitioner’s wife stood to benefit from any settlement, indicating a personal motive. Consequently, the petition was deemed an abuse of process and not a bona‑fide public interest litigation. The counsel for the petitioner withdrew the petition, and the court dismissed it with liberty to approach the Income Tax Department under the Informants Scheme, if appropriate.
facts: The petitioner filed two Tax Evasion Petitions against M/s Jagdish Prasad Agarwal and M/s Vijay Automobiles, alleging tax evasion and seeking investigation under the Informants Rewards Scheme. He then filed a writ petition for mandamus to compel the tax authorities to act, claiming public‑spirited motives, though his father‑in‑law was a partner in the accused firms and his wife was a legal heir seeking settlement.
arguments: Petitioner argued that he was a public‑spirited citizen seeking enforcement of tax laws and that the Informants Rewards Scheme gave him a right to compel investigation. The respondents contended that the petition did not meet the criteria for a public interest litigation, that the petitioner had a personal interest, and that no statutory provision empowered the court to issue mandamus in these circumstances.
judgment_reasoning: The court held that the petition failed to satisfy the Public Interest Litigation Rules, 2010, as the petitioner had a direct personal interest. It emphasized that mandamus cannot be issued to direct a tax investigation absent a clear statutory right. The petition was characterized as an abuse of process, leading to its dismissal, though the petitioner was allowed to approach the tax department under the Informants Scheme.
key_legal_points: A petition must comply with the Delhi High Court (Public Interest Litigation) Rules, 2010 to be treated as a PIL.
Mandamus cannot be issued to compel a tax investigation unless expressly provided by statute.
Petitions driven by personal interest constitute an abuse of court process.
legal_issues: Whether the petition qualifies as a public interest litigation.
Whether the petitioner has locus standi to seek mandamus for tax investigation.
Whether the court can direct the tax authorities to act under the Informants Rewards Scheme.

1. The petitioner seeks mandamus to the respondents  (i) Directorate of 
Income Tax Investigation; and, (ii) Member Investig ation, Central Board of 
Direct Taxes, to conduct an investigation in a time  bound manner in 
pursuance to the Tax Evasion Petition (TEP) dated 2 0th June, 2020 and 
Benami Transaction Tax Evasion Petition dated 18th March, 2020 lodged by  
the petitioner with the respondents against M/s Jag dish Prasad Agarwal 
(JPA) & M/s Vijay Automobiles and to treat the said  TEPs under the Income 
Tax Informants Rewards Scheme, 2018. 
2. The petitioner had not impleaded the aforesaid M /s JPA or M/s Vijay 
Automobiles as respondents to this petition. 
3. The petitioner, in the petition has pleaded that  the petition is filed by 
him as a public spirited person. However, in spite of the said averment, the 
same has not been labelled as a Public Interest Lit igation and is not in 
W.P.(C) 54/2021     Page 2 of 3 
 compliance with the Delhi High Court (Public Intere st Litigation) Rules, 
2010 for filing Public Interest Litigation and whic h Rules inter alia require 
the petitioner to make a declaration that there is no personal interest in the 
litigation and that the petition is not guided by s elf-gain or for gain of any 
other person/institution/body and that there is no motive other than of public 
interest. Rather, the petitioner in the petition ha s expressly pleaded that his 
father-in-law, Late Shri Jagdish Prasad Agarwal, wa s a partner in M/s JPA 
and M/s Vijay Automobiles against whom complaints o f tax evasion have 
been made and that the other partners of the said M /s JPA and M/s Vijay 
Automobiles have not settled the accounts with the legal heirs of Late Shri 
Jagdish Prasad Agarwal, being the father-in-law of the petitioner and one of 
which legal heirs, Smt. Usha Singhal, is the wife o f the petitioner. Thus 
prima facie  it appears that TEPs filed by the petitioner or by  any of the other 
legal heirs or at their instance as well as this pe tition, are to coerce the said 
M/s JPA and M/s Vijay Automobiles to settle the cla ims, inter alia of the 
petitioner’s wife. 
4. The same cannot be permitted and is an abuse of the process of the 
Court.  The Court cannot allow its machinery and pr ocess to be used and 
invoked by such unscrupulous petitioners, to settle  their own scores. 
5. Though certain schemes brought out by the Income  Tax Department 
encourage the filing of complaints of income tax ev asion to be made and 
which can obviously be made only by insiders who ha ve fallen apart from 
the entity/person earlier indulging in tax evasion,  but the petitioner, though 
referring to the same, has not filed any copy of th e said scheme and has not 
shown any provision under which the petitioner, bes ides lodging a complaint 
or furnishing information, has a right to activate the Court machinery to 
W.P.(C) 54/2021     Page 3 of 3 
 issue mandamus to the respondent to take further ac tion against  the person/s 
complained against. 
6. Be that as it may, such abuse of process of this  Court cannot be 
permitted. 
7. The counsel for the petitioner, who is young wit h only three years of 
experience at the Bar as informed, states that he r ealises his mistake and 
withdraws the petition, without any liberty to purs ue the misconceived 
action any further but with liberty to take steps u nder the Informants 
Scheme, if any, of the Income Tax Department. 
8. Dismissed as withdrawn with liberty aforesaid.

case_type: Appeal under Section 82 of Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Employees' Insurance Court proceeding is maintainable when the workers, who are the real beneficiaries of the Employees' State Insurance Act, are not impleaded as parties.
summary: The appellant, M/S Trehun Sons, challenged a series of orders issued by the Employees' State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) demanding payment of employee contributions for the period June 2006 to June 2011. The dispute originated from a Show Cause Notice dated 25 July 2011 under Sections 85(a) and 85(e) of the Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948. The appellant appealed the notice and subsequent orders before the Senior Civil Judge (Rent Controller) and the Employees' Insurance Court, which dismissed the appeals. The appellant then filed an appeal before the Delhi High Court under Section 82 of the Act, contending that the Employees' Insurance Court erred by not impleading the workers, who are the statutory beneficiaries, as parties. The Court examined Supreme Court precedents emphasizing that labour statutes are beneficial legislation and that non‑joinder of necessary parties defeats natural justice. Citing cases such as Fertilizers & Chemicals Travancore Ltd., ESIC v. Bhakra Beas Management Board, and ESIC v. Key Dee Cold Storage, the High Court held that the absence of the workers as parties rendered the earlier proceedings infirm. Consequently, the appeal was allowed, the matter remanded to the Senior Civil Judge for fresh adjudication, and the pending applications were disposed of.
facts: ESIC issued a Show Cause Notice on 25 July 2011 demanding Rs.4,79,050 as employee contributions for the period 01‑06‑2006 to June 2011. The appellant, employing at least 20 workers, contested the notice, leading to a speaking order on 17 January 2012 under Section 45‑A, which was appealed under Section 45‑AA and dismissed on 5 July 2012. The appellant further appealed before the Employees' Insurance Court under Sections 75, 76 and 77, but the appeal was dismissed on 3 November 2020. The appellant argued that the workers were not impleaded as parties, violating the principles of natural justice and the protective purpose of the Act.
arguments: The appellant argued that the Employees' Insurance Court failed to implead the workers, who are the real beneficiaries under the Act, thereby breaching the requirement of natural justice and rendering the proceedings void. The respondent ESIC contended that the procedural aspects were regular and that the contribution demand was enforceable irrespective of worker participation.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the Employees' State Insurance Act is a beneficial legislation intended primarily for workers. Supreme Court jurisprudence mandates that workers (or their representatives) be impleaded in any proceeding under the Act. Non‑joinder of a necessary party goes to the root of the matter and makes the order a nullity. Since the Employees' Insurance Court did not include the workers, its decision was infirm. Accordingly, the appeal was allowed and the matter remanded for fresh adjudication with proper joinder of the workers.
key_legal_points: The ESI Act is beneficial legislation for workers; workers must be parties in proceedings under the Act.
Non‑joinder of a necessary party defeats natural justice and renders orders void.
Supreme Court precedents require impleading workers or their representatives in ESI matters.
legal_issues: Whether the Employees' Insurance Court can proceed without joinder of workers under the ESI Act.
Effect of non‑joinder of necessary parties on the validity of the order.

IN THE MATTER OF: 
 
M/S TREHUN SONS      ..... Appellant 
    Through: Mr. Maneesh Gumber, Advocate  
 
    versus 
 
EMPLOYEE STATE INSURANCE CORPORATION  ..... Respondent 
    Through: Mr. V.K. Singh, Ms. Prachi Singh,  
    Ms. Yakshi Rawal and Mr. Sourav Singh,  
    Advocates with Mr. Arvind Bansal SSO, ESIC

HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE MANOJ KUMAR OHRI 
 
     JUDGMENT 
 
MANOJ KUMAR OHRI, J. (ORAL) 
1. By way of the present appeal filed under Section 82 of the 
Employees ’ State Insurance Act, 1948 (hereinafter, referred to as the 'Act'), 
the appellant has sought setting aside of the judgment d ated 03.11.2020 
passed by the learned Senior Civil Judge/Rent Controller (West), Tis Hazari 
Courts, Delhi in ESIC No. 16/2016. In addition, the appellant h as assailed 
orders dated 17.01.2012 & 05.07.2012 passed by the Deputy Di rector , SRO, 
(North) and the Appellate Authority, SRO, Rohini, Delhi respect ively.  
2. A perusal of the paper book would show that the present proceedings 
originate from a Show Cause Notice dated 25.07.2011 issued by ESIC under 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/003290
FAO 2/2021                                                        Page 2 of 6  Sections 85(a) and 85(e) of the Act, whereby the appellant was asked  to 
deposit employees' contribution of Rs.4,79,050/- for the peri od from 
01.06.2006 to June, 2011. The aforesaid notice culminated into passing of a 
speaking order dated 17.01.2012 under Section 45-A of the Ac t, which was 
challenged by the appellant by way of an appeal under Section  45-AA of the 
Act. The same came to be dismissed vide order dated 05.07.2012, wh ich in 
turn was challenged before the learned SCJ by way of an appeal fi led under 
Section 75 read with Sections 76 & 77 of the Act. The said appeal  came to 
be dismissed by way of the order impugned herein. 
3. It is worthwhile to note that the entire case revolves aroun d the 
allegation that despite having employed atleast 20 employees an d thus being 
covered under the Act, the appellant has not paid the requisite contrib ution. 
4. There is no gainsaying that labour statutes, such as th e Act, constitute 
‘beneficial legislation ’, enacted for the welfare of employees/workmen. 
Besides ESIC, such workmen/employees, are also to be necessarily 
impleaded in petitions filed under Section 75 of the Act thro ugh self or in 
representative capacity. In this regard, this Court deems it exp edient to 
advert to the following observations made by the Supreme Court in 
Fertilizers and Chemicals Travancore Limited v. Regional Director, 
Employees’ State Insurance Corporation and Others reported as (2009) 9 
SCC 485:-  
"8. In our opinion, wherever any petition is filed by an employer 
under Section 75 of the Act, the employer has not only to 
implead the ESIC but has also to implead at least some of the 
workers concerned (in a representative capacity if there are a 
large number of workers) or the trade union representing t he 
said workers. If that is not done, and a decision is giv en in 
favour of the employer, the same will be in violation o f the rules 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/003290
FAO 2/2021                                                        Page 3 of 6  of natural justice. After all, the real parties concerned i n labour 
matters are the employer and the workers. ESI Corporation wi ll 
not be in any way affected if the demand notice sent by it under 
Section 45-A/45-B is quashed. 
 
9.  It must be remembered that the Act has been enacted for th e 
benefit of the workers to give them medical benefits, which h ave 
been mentioned in Section 46 of the Act. Hence, the princi pal 
beneficiary of the Act is the workmen and not ESI Corporatio n. 
ESI Corporation is only the agency to implement and carry out 
the object of the Act and it has nothing to lose if th e decision of 
the Employees' Insurance Court is given in favour of the 
employer. It is only the workmen who have to lose if a decisi on 
is given in favour of the employer. Hence, the workmen (or at  
least some of them in a representative capacity, or their tr ade 
union) have to be necessarily made a party/parties because the 
Act is a labour legislation made for the benefit of the workmen . 
 
10. In the present case the workmen concerned were not made 
parties before the Employees ’ Insurance Court, nor was notice 
issued to them by the said court. Also, the order of the  
Employees' Insurance Court dated 4-2-1993, relevant portion  of 
which we have quoted, is not a very happy one as no proper 
determination has been made therein as to whether the 
workmen concerned are the employees of the appellant and 
whether they are entitled to the benefit of the Act. 
 
11. No doubt some observations have been made that some 
labourers come on one day but they may not come on the next 
day. Having said so, a direction has been given that ESI 
Corporation will after making inquiries about the identi ties of 
the said workers will register them and then extend the benefi t 
of the Act. 
 
12. In our opinion, the Employees' Insurance Court should have 
itself made a proper investigation of the facts after g etting 
evidence from the parties, including the workmen concerned, 
and after impleading them as party in the petition, it  should 
This is a digitally signed Judgement.NEUTRAL CITATION NO: 2022/DHC/003290
FAO 2/2021                                                        Page 4 of 6  have determined the question as to whether the persons 
concerned were the employees of the appellant or not. ” 
 
5. Subsequently, the above observations have been reiterated by  the 
Supreme Court in Employees ’ State Insurance Corporation v. Bhakra Beas 
Management Board and Another reported as (2009) 10 SCC 671  and 
Employees State Insurance Corporation and Others v. Key Dee Cold Storage 
Pvt. Ltd. reported as 2022 SCC OnLine SC 650 . 
6. In Employees State Insurance Corporation and Others v. Key Dee 
Cold Storage Pvt. Ltd. (Supra), the respondent had raised a challenge b efore 
the ESI Court against a show cause notice for remittance of contribu tion,

case_type: Arbitration reference under Section 11 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996
primary_legal_issue: Whether multiple disputes arising under three separate arbitration agreements can be referred to a single arbitrator for expeditious resolution
summary: The petitions filed by Amardeep Builders under Section 11 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 sought reference of three related disputes to arbitration. The GNCT of Delhi, while agreeing to arbitration in two petitions, sought a caveat in the third that the arbitrability and all defences, including limitation, remain open before the arbitral tribunal. The Court, relying on the Supreme Court’s decision in Duro Felguera S.A. v. Gangavaram Port Ltd., held that although three separate arbitration agreements exist, the disputes are similar and involve the same parties, warranting referral to a single arbitrator to ensure speedy resolution. The Court clarified that this does not violate the Fifth Schedule of the 1996 Act as the arbitrator has not previously acted in the matter. Accordingly, the disputes were referred to retired Justice Rajiv Sahai Endlaw as arbitrator, with directions for disclosure under Section 12(2). No merits were decided; all factual and legal issues remain for the arbitrator. The petitions were disposed of.
facts: Amardeep Builders entered into three separate arbitration agreements with the GNCT of Delhi. The builder filed three petitions (ARB.P.22/2021, ARB.P.23/2021, ARB.P.24/2021) under Section 11 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, seeking court‑appointed arbitration. The GNCT of Delhi consented to arbitration in the first two petitions but, in the third, requested that the arbitrability and all defences, including limitation, be kept open for argument before the arbitrator.
arguments: The petitioner argued for appointment of arbitrators for each agreement, emphasizing the distinct nature of each contract. The respondent, in the third petition, contended that the arbitrability and statutory defences should not be waived by the reference and sought a caveat to preserve these rights before the arbitral tribunal.
judgment_reasoning: The Court noted the Supreme Court’s guidance in Duro Felguera, which allows multiple agreements to be dealt with by a single arbitrator where the disputes are between the same parties and are similar. It held that appointing one arbitrator would not contravene the Fifth Schedule because the arbitrator had not previously acted in the matter. The Court therefore directed referral to a single arbitrator, emphasizing that no merits were decided and all issues remain open for arbitration.
key_legal_points: Three separate arbitration agreements do not preclude a single arbitrator if disputes are similar and parties are the same
Referral to a single arbitrator does not violate the Fifth Schedule of the 1996 Act
Section 12(2) requires the arbitrator to disclose interests within a week of reference
legal_issues: Whether multiple arbitration agreements necessitate separate arbitrators
Whether the Fifth Schedule of the Arbitration Act bars appointment of the same arbitrator in related matters
Whether the court can refer disputes without deciding merits

case_type: Arbitration reference under Section 11 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996
primary_legal_issue: Whether three separate disputes arising from three arbitration agreements between Amardeep Builders and GNCT of Delhi may be referred to a single arbitrator for expeditious resolution.
summary: The Delhi High Court entertained three petitions (ARB.P.22/2021, ARB.P.23/2021, ARB.P.24/2021) filed by Amardeep Builders under Section 11 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, seeking reference of their disputes with the Government of NCT of Delhi to arbitration. While the respondent’s counsel in the first two petitions consented to appointment of an arbitrator, the counsel in the third petition sought a caveat that arbitrability and all defences, including limitation, remain open before the arbitral tribunal. Relying on the Supreme Court’s decision in Duro Felguera S.A. v. Gangavaram Port Ltd. (2017) 9 SCC 729, the Court held that three separate arbitrations would ordinarily be required, each attracting separate fees under the Fourth Schedule. However, noting the identity of parties and similarity of the disputes, the Court deemed it appropriate to refer all three matters to a single arbitrator, retired Judge Rajiv Sahai Endlaw, without violating the Fifth Schedule. The arbitrator was directed to disclose interests under Section 12(2) within a week of taking reference. No merits were decided; all factual and legal issues remain for the arbitrator. The petitions were ordered disposed.
facts: Amardeep Builders entered into three separate agreements with the GNCT of Delhi that contain arbitration clauses. Disputes arose under each agreement, prompting the builder to file three separate petitions under Section 11 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, seeking court‑ordered reference to arbitration. The GNCT of Delhi’s counsel in the first two petitions agreed to arbitration, but in the third petition sought to keep arbitrability and defences, such as limitation, open for argument before the arbitral tribunal.
arguments: The petitioner argued that each dispute, arising from distinct agreements, should be referred to arbitration and that a single arbitrator could ensure consistency and speed. The respondent, in the third petition, contended that the arbitrability of the dispute and all statutory defences should remain open for determination by the arbitral tribunal, effectively seeking a safeguard against premature dismissal of claims.
judgment_reasoning: The Court applied the principle from Duro Felguera S.A. v. Gangavaram Port Ltd., which requires separate arbitrations for separate agreements, each attracting separate fees. However, recognizing the commonality of parties and the similarity of the disputes, the Court concluded that referring all three matters to a single arbitrator would not contravene the Fifth Schedule of the 1996 Act, as the arbitrator had not previously acted in the same matters. This approach promotes expeditious resolution without compromising procedural safeguards. The Court therefore appointed retired Judge Rajiv Sahai Endlaw as the sole arbitrator, directing compliance with Section 12(2) for disclosure and leaving all factual and legal issues to be decided by the arbitral tribunal.
key_legal_points: Separate arbitration agreements ordinarily require separate arbitrations
The Fifth Schedule bars re‑appointment of an arbitrator who has previously acted in a similar case
A single arbitrator may be appointed where parties and issues are identical without violating the Act
Section 12(2) mandates disclosure of interests by the arbitrator
legal_issues: Whether three distinct arbitration agreements necessitate three separate arbitrations
Whether appointing a single arbitrator violates the Fifth Schedule of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act
Whether the arbitrability and statutory defences can be left open for the arbitral tribunal
