case_type: Civil suit for injunction under Copyright Act
primary_legal_issue: Whether the defendants infringed the copyright of the plaintiffs by publishing selected volumes of "Sales Tax Cases" online and whether a permanent injunction is warranted.
summary: The plaintiffs, legal heirs of the deceased Lakshmi Venkatachalam, own the copyright in the multi‑volume publication "Sales Tax Cases" (STC). They filed four civil suits (C.S. Nos. 158, 159, 160 and 161 of 1998) against M/s. Commercial Laws of India Pvt. Ltd., V. Subramanian, Sekhar and M/s. Company Law Institute of India Pvt. Ltd., seeking a permanent injunction to restrain the defendants from releasing, selling, marketing or otherwise disposing of the online version "STC on line" containing material from STC volumes 15, 16, 25, 26, 29, 30, 43, 44 and 45. The suits were filed under Order IV Rule 1 of the O.S. Rules and Sections 55 and 62 of the Copyright Act. The defendants filed written statements undertaking not to use the specified volumes in any future GST law publications or CD‑ROMs. The plaintiffs raised no objection to the undertaking. The Court, after recording the defendants' undertaking, decreed the suits accordingly, granting the injunction as per the undertaking and awarding no costs. The judgment underscores the enforceability of copyright undertakings and the Court's willingness to settle disputes through consent without protracted litigation.
facts: The plaintiffs own copyright in the printed series "Sales Tax Cases". The defendants allegedly reproduced selected volumes of this series in an online publication titled "STC on line". The plaintiffs claimed this constituted infringement and sought a permanent injunction to stop further distribution. The defendants submitted written statements undertaking not to use the contested volumes in any future publications or electronic media.
arguments: Plaintiffs argued that the defendants' online use of the STC volumes violated their exclusive rights under Sections 55 and 62 of the Copyright Act and sought an injunction. Defendants contended that they would cease any further use and offered an undertaking to that effect, requesting the Court to record the undertaking and close the suits.
judgment_reasoning: The Court noted that the defendants had expressly undertaken not to use the disputed material in the future and that the plaintiffs raised no objection to this undertaking. Under the Copyright Act, such an undertaking is sufficient to prevent further infringement. Consequently, the Court recorded the undertaking, decreed the suits in accordance with it, and awarded no costs, emphasizing the parties' consent and the adequacy of the undertaking to protect the plaintiffs' rights.
key_legal_points: A written undertaking by a defendant not to use copyrighted material can be recorded as a decree.
Sections 55 and 62 of the Copyright Act provide the basis for injunctions against infringement.
Consent of parties to settle the dispute obviates the need for a detailed evidentiary hearing.
legal_issues: Whether the defendants' online publication infringed the plaintiffs' copyright.
Whether a permanent injunction is appropriate under the Copyright Act.
Whether a defendant's undertaking can be treated as a decree.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the impugned order denying immunity from prosecution and imposing a redemption fine can be set aside.
summary: The appellant, M/s. Anshuai Electronics, filed writ appeals (Nos.402 and 404 of 2021) under Clause 15 of the Letters Patent and Article 226 of the Constitution challenging Order No.21/2012‑Customs dated 08‑08‑2012 and its corrigendum dated 13‑08‑2012, which denied immunity and imposed a redemption fine. The respondents, the Settlement Commission and the Commissioner of Customs & Central Excise, defended the order. While the court was about to deliver its judgment, counsel for the appellant sought to withdraw the appeals to pursue other legal avenues and lodged an endorsement to that effect. The court recorded the withdrawal, dismissed the writ appeals as withdrawn, ordered no costs, and closed the connected miscellaneous petitions. No substantive examination of the merits or legal precedents was undertaken because the proceedings were terminated by the appellant’s voluntary withdrawal.
facts: Anshuai Electronics challenged a Customs order (No.21/2012‑Customs) and its corrigendum that denied it immunity from prosecution and imposed a redemption fine. The challenge was made through writ petitions filed in 2012 under Article 226, later converted into writ appeals (Nos.402 and 404 of 2021). The appellant sought quashing of the order, while the respondents defended its validity.
arguments: The appellant argued that the order denying immunity and imposing the fine was unlawful and sought its quashing. The respondents contended that the order was within the statutory powers of the Customs authorities and that the fine was justified.
judgment_reasoning: The court recorded the appellant’s endorsement to withdraw the appeals. In accordance with procedural law, a withdrawn appeal is dismissed without costs, and any ancillary petitions are closed. No substantive merits were addressed.
key_legal_points: Withdrawal of an appeal results in dismissal of the appeal
No costs are awarded when an appeal is withdrawn
Connected miscellaneous petitions are closed upon withdrawal
legal_issues: Whether the impugned Customs order can be quashed
Effect of voluntary withdrawal of writ appeals

primary_legal_issue: Whether the Court has jurisdiction to entertain the suit and, in the absence of prosecution, the suit must be dismissed.
summary: The plaintiff, M/s. Overseas Sanmar Financial Limited, instituted a civil suit (C.S.No.465 of 1996) on 15 March 2022 seeking a decree directing defendants 2,3,5 and 6 to pay Rs.1,35,50,288 with interest and to compel the fourth defendant to pay assets of the deceased Anand M. Pillai. The suit was filed under Order IV Rule 1 of the O.S. Rules, read with Order VII Rule 1 of the CPC and Section 26 of the CPC. No parties appeared in person or through counsel for the plaintiff, and only counsel for defendants 1‑3 were present; defendants 4‑6 were absent. The matter was initially listed under the caption “Determine Jurisdiction” and, after a hearing on 8 March 2022, the Court found no jurisdictional dispute and ordered the case to be posted for dismissal. On 15 March 2022, the Court, after confirming the lack of prosecution, dismissed the suit for non‑prosecution and ordered no costs. The judgment reflects procedural compliance with CPC provisions concerning dismissal for non‑prosecution and underscores the Court’s authority to dismiss suits where parties fail to prosecute. No substantive merits were addressed. The order was signed by Mrs. Justice V. Bhavani Subbaroyan and later approved by the Chief Justice.
facts: The plaintiff sought a monetary decree against six defendants, alleging unpaid dues and claiming assets of a deceased heir. The suit was filed under specific CPC provisions. No appearance was made by the plaintiff; only counsel for defendants 1‑3 appeared. Defendants 4‑6 were absent. The case was initially listed to determine jurisdiction, which the Court found to be clear, and then scheduled for dismissal due to non‑prosecution.
arguments: No substantive arguments were presented as the plaintiff did not appear. Counsel for defendants 1‑3 made no objections to dismissal, and the Court proceeded on procedural grounds.
judgment_reasoning: The Court first examined jurisdiction, finding none in dispute, and then applied Section 26 of the CPC, which empowers dismissal of a suit for non‑prosecution. Since the plaintiff failed to prosecute and no parties appeared, the suit was dismissed without costs.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the 3rd respondent can enforce locking, sealing, demolition and de‑occupation notices on a residential building pending the disposal of a special revision petition filed under Section 80‑A of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1971.
summary: The petitioners, owners of residential units in a building constructed in 2001 with approved plans, sought a writ of mandamus to restrain the Greater Chennai Corporation (3rd respondent) from locking, sealing, demolishing or de‑occupying their premises. The 3rd respondent issued a stop‑work notice in September 2020, followed by locking, sealing and demolition notices in November 2020, and a de‑occupation notice on 28 December 2020, alleging unauthorized deviations. The petitioners filed a special revision/appeal under Section 80‑A of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1971, which remained pending. The High Court, after hearing the government pleaders, declined to entertain the merits of the petitioners’ claim but directed the 1st respondent (Government of Tamil Nadu) to entertain the pending special revision/appeal and to consider interim relief within three weeks. It ordered the 3rd respondent to defer any further action under the de‑occupation notice until the revision is disposed of. The writ petition was therefore disposed of without costs, and the connected miscellaneous petition was closed.
facts: The building at Plot Nos.10 and 11, Rajendra Colony, Saligramam, Chennai, was constructed in 2001 by M/s Maayapuri Constructions after obtaining planning permission (PPA Nos.480 and 481). The petitioners purchased the units and land shares via registered sale deeds. After nearly two decades, the Greater Chennai Corporation issued a stop‑work notice (07‑09‑2020), ignored the petitioners’ reply, and served locking, sealing (11‑11‑2020) and demolition notices (12‑11‑2020) alleging deviations. The petitioners filed a special revision/appeal under Section 80‑A of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1971, seeking interim relief. The 3rd respondent later issued a de‑occupation notice (28‑12‑2020).
arguments: Petitioners argued that the building was lawfully constructed with approved plans, that the notices were issued without due consideration of their reply, and that the pending special revision under Section 80‑A barred any further action, especially given the age and health of many owners. Respondents contended that alleged deviations justified the notices and that the special revision was a procedural matter not precluding enforcement actions.
judgment_reasoning: The Court noted that the writ petition raised procedural and substantive issues but chose not to delve into the merits. It emphasized the pendency of the special revision/appeal under Section 80‑A and the statutory requirement that the authority entertain such revisions before taking coercive action. Accordingly, the Court directed the 1st respondent to process the revision and consider interim relief within three weeks, and ordered the 3rd respondent to defer any further action, including the de‑occupation notice, until the revision is disposed of.
key_legal_points: Pending revision under Section 80‑A bars further coercive action
Authority must entertain special revision before enforcement
Court can stay administrative notices pending adjudication
legal_issues: Validity of locking, sealing and demolition notices issued after a special revision is filed
Effect of Section 80‑A of the Town and Country Planning Act on administrative actions
Whether the 3rd respondent must defer de‑occupation pending the outcome of the revision

case_type: Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution of India
primary_legal_issue: Whether the limitation provisions of the Indian Registration Act (Sections 23 and 25) apply to the registration of a civil court decree.
summary: In W.P. No. 553 of 2022, petitioners Kaliyamurthy and Sundaravalli sought a writ of mandamus under Article 226 directing the Sub‑Registrar to register a decree dated 24 July 2015 in O.S. No.3 of 2011, issued by the II Additional District Court, Chidambaram. The decree arose from a suit for specific performance of a sale agreement and ordered the petitioners to pay Rs.1,00,000 with interest. After paying the amount and obtaining a certified copy of the decree, the petitioners presented it for registration, but the Sub‑Registrar refused, citing the four‑month limitation period under Sections 23 and 25 of the Indian Registration Act. The petitioners contended that such limitation should not apply to court decrees. The Court, relying on its earlier pronouncements, held that the limitation provisions of the Registration Act are inapplicable to the registration of civil court decrees because a decree is not a compulsorily registrable document. Consequently, the Sub‑Registrar was directed to register the decree forthwith. The writ petition was disposed of with no costs, effectively granting the relief sought.
facts: The petitioners owned land covered by Survey No.116/2 and New Survey No.484/1 (40 cents). The fourth respondent, Mohammed Ghoose, filed a suit (O.S. No.3 of 2011) for specific performance of a sale agreement dated 04‑04‑2008 and for a refund of Rs.18,00,000 with interest. The suit was dismissed on 24‑07‑2015, with the petitioners ordered to pay Rs.1,00,000 with interest. No appeal was filed. The petitioners paid the amount, obtained a certified copy of the judgment and decree, and approached the Sub‑Registrar for registration. The Sub‑Registrar refused, invoking a four‑month limitation under the Registration Act.
arguments: Petitioners argued that the decree, being a civil court order, should be registrable irrespective of the limitation period and that the Registration Act's Sections 23 and 25 do not apply to such decrees. Respondents (registrars) contended that the four‑month limitation under the Registration Act barred registration after that period.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that earlier decisions have consistently held that Sections 23 and 25 of the Indian Registration Act, which prescribe limitation periods, are not applicable to the registration of civil court decrees. Since a decree is not a document that must be compulsorily registered, the statutory limitation cannot be invoked to deny registration. Accordingly, the Sub‑Registrar was ordered to register the decree immediately.
key_legal_points: Limitation provisions of the Indian Registration Act do not apply to registration of civil court decrees.
A decree is not a compulsorily registrable document under the Registration Act.
Writ of mandamus can be issued to compel a registrar to register a decree when law permits.
legal_issues: Applicability of Sections 23 and 25 of the Indian Registration Act to court decrees.
Whether a civil court decree can be refused registration on the ground of limitation.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petition to withdraw and transfer the pending civil miscellaneous petitions can be disposed on the basis of a compromise deed between the parties
summary: The petitioner, Divya, filed a Transfer Civil Miscellaneous Petition (Tr.CMP No.9 of 2023) seeking withdrawal of H.M.O.P. No.922 of 2022 pending before the Sub Court, Poonamallee, and its transfer to the Sub Court, Tambaram. The respondent, J. Badrinath, opposed the petition. During the hearing, the petitioner’s counsel produced a memo of compromise indicating that both parties had agreed to settle their disputes by filing a mutual‑consent divorce petition before the Sub Court, Tambaram. The compromise deed, dated 27‑Nov‑2023, stipulated that each party would withdraw their respective petitions (H.M.O.P. No.308 of 2023 and H.M.O.P. No.180 of 2023) and cooperate in filing the divorce petition, with provisions for video‑link appearances and notarized documents from New Jersey, USA. The Court, after reviewing the compromise deed, ordered the transfer petition to be disposed of in terms of the agreement, incorporated the deed’s terms into the order, and closed the connected miscellaneous petition without awarding costs. The judgment reflects the Court’s willingness to honor a mutually agreed compromise that satisfies procedural requirements under Section 24 of the Civil Procedure Code, thereby avoiding further litigation.
facts: Divya filed a petition to withdraw a pending civil miscellaneous petition (H.M.O.P. No.922 of 2022) from the Sub Court, Poonamallee and to transfer the matter to the Sub Court, Tambaram. Both parties later reached a compromise, agreeing to settle their dispute through a mutual‑consent divorce petition and to withdraw related petitions in other courts. The compromise deed was signed, notarized, and presented to the Court.
arguments: Petitioner’s counsel submitted a memo of compromise stating that both parties consented to withdraw their respective petitions and to file a mutual‑consent divorce petition. The respondent did not contest the compromise, and both parties agreed to comply with procedural directions, including video‑link appearances and notarized documents from the USA.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the civil suit should be dismissed for non‑prosecution due to lack of interest by the parties.
summary: In C.S. No. 47 of 1996, the plaintiffs K. Sivagnanam and T. S. Pathy filed a civil suit seeking a scheme for the preservation, administration and functioning of a trust created by the first defendant, Tamil Nadu Karuneegar Sangam, and the appointment of trustees from the Karuneegar caste. The suit was filed under Section 92 of the Civil Procedure Code. Despite multiple directions by the court for the plaintiffs' counsel to serve notice and for both sides to appear, neither the plaintiffs nor the defendants presented any representation on the scheduled dates. The court observed that both parties failed to demonstrate any interest in pursuing the matter, rendering further proceedings futile. Consequently, the Madras High Court, presided over by Mrs. Justice V. Bhavani Subbaroyan, dismissed the suit for non‑prosecution, noting that the lack of active participation justified termination of the proceedings. The order was certified as a true copy and entered on 29 April 2022.
facts: The plaintiffs filed a suit to frame a scheme for a trust and to appoint trustees from the Karuneegar caste. The suit was filed under Section 92 CPC. The court issued several directions for notice and appearance, but the plaintiffs' counsel failed to act, and the defendants reported no instructions from their clients. On the hearing date, no party appeared, indicating a lack of interest in pursuing the case.
arguments: No substantive arguments were presented by either side. The court noted the plaintiffs' counsel's failure to comply with directions and the defendants' lack of instructions, leading to an inference of no interest in the litigation.
judgment_reasoning: The court reasoned that when both parties show no interest in pursuing a suit and fail to appear despite court directions, the suit serves no purpose and may be dismissed for non‑prosecution under the provisions of the Civil Procedure Code.
key_legal_points: A suit may be dismissed for non‑prosecution when parties do not appear or act on court directions.
Active participation by parties is essential for the continuation of civil proceedings.
The court has inherent power to dismiss frivolous or abandoned suits to prevent unnecessary burden on the judiciary.
legal_issues: Dismissal of a civil suit for non‑prosecution.
Requirement of parties' interest and participation in civil litigation.

primary_legal_issue: Whether a writ of certiorari under Article 226 lies against a cooperative society that is not an instrumentality of the State within the meaning of Article 12.
summary: The petitioner, A. Gnanasekaran, a clerk in a cooperative bank, challenged a surcharge order imposed under Section 87 of the Tamil Nadu Cooperative Societies Act. He alleged that the first respondent, the Deputy Registrar, had violated Section 81(4) by not furnishing the enquiry report and denying him a fair hearing. The petitioner sought a writ of certiorari to quash the order and to obtain the complete records. The respondents contended that the enquiry was conducted per statutory procedure, the report was eventually supplied, and the society is not a State instrumentality, rendering the writ inapplicable. The bench examined a Full Bench decision (Writ Appeal No.1573 of 1998) which held that cooperative societies engaged in banking are not State entities under Article 12, and therefore, writ jurisdiction is limited unless a statutory public duty is breached. Applying this precedent, the court concluded that the society could not be treated as a State authority and that the alternative statutory remedy (appeal before the Cooperative Tribunal) was available. Consequently, the writ petition was converted into a civil revision petition and dismissed, with no costs awarded.
facts: The petitioner worked as a clerk in the Melolakkur Primary Agricultural Co‑op Bank. The Deputy Registrar filed a report against him without providing a copy to the petitioner. Six months later, surcharge proceedings under Section 87 were initiated, imposing a liability of Rs.4.77 lakhs. The petitioner filed a writ petition (W.P. No.41290 of 2004) to obtain the enquiry report, which was later ordered to be furnished. He subsequently filed the present writ petition (W.P. No.9282 of 2009) challenging the surcharge order and alleging procedural violations under Section 81(4).
arguments: Petitioner argued that the first respondent violated Section 81(4) by not furnishing the enquiry report and denying a fair hearing, rendering the surcharge order illegal. He also claimed that the cooperative society, being a public body, should be amenable to writ jurisdiction. Respondents asserted that the enquiry was conducted in accordance with the Act and Rules, the report was eventually provided, and that the society is not an instrumentality of the State; therefore, the writ petition is not maintainable and the statutory appeal before the Cooperative Tribunal is the appropriate remedy.
judgment_reasoning: The court relied on the Full Bench judgment in Writ Appeal No.1573 of 1998, which held that cooperative societies engaged in banking are not State entities under Article 12 and thus not subject to writ jurisdiction unless a specific statutory public duty is breached. It noted that the Tamil Nadu Cooperative Societies Act provides an alternative remedy (statutory appeal) and that the bye‑laws of such societies do not have the force of law. Consequently, the writ petition could not lie against the society, and the matter was converted to a civil revision petition.
key_legal_points: Cooperative societies engaged in banking are not State instrumentality under Article 12
Writ jurisdiction under Article 226 is limited where alternative statutory remedies exist
Bye‑laws of cooperative societies do not have the force of law
Statutory public duty must be breached for a writ to lie against a private body
The writ petition was converted to a civil revision petition and dismissed
legal_issues: Whether the cooperative society is an instrumentality of the State for purposes of Article 12
Whether the petitioner was denied a fair hearing under Section 81(4)
Whether the alternative statutory remedy bars the writ jurisdiction
Whether the surcharge order can be quashed by certiorari

21.  From  the  above  discussion,  the  following

“(i) If  a  particular  co-operative  society  can  be 
characterised as a  State  within the meaning of Articl e  
12 of the Constitution (applying the tests evolved by the 
Supreme  Court  in  that  behalf),  it  would  also  be   an 
authority  within the meaning and for the purpose of 
Article 226 of the Constitution. In such a situation, an  
order passed by a society in violation of the bye-laws  
can be corrected by way of writ petition. 
(ii) Applying the tests in Ajay Hasia it is held that the 
respondent society carrying on banking business cannot 
be termed as an instrumentality of the State within the 
meaning of Article 12 of the Constitution.
(iii) Even if a society cannot be characterised as a 
State   within  the  meaning  of  Article  12  of  the 
Constitution,  even  so  a  writ  would  lie  against  it  to 
enforce a statutory public duty cast upon the society.  In  
such a case, it is unnecessary to go into the question 
whether the society is being treated as a  person  or  an 
authority   within  the  meaning  of  Article  226  of  the 
Constitution and what is material is the nature of the  
statutory duty placed upon it and the Court will enforce

such statutory public duty. Although it is not easy to 
define what a public function or public duty is, it can 
reasonably  said  that  such  functions  are similar  to or 
closely related to those performable by the State in it s 
sovereign capacity. 
(iv) A  society,  which  is  not  a   State   would  not  
normally  be  amenable  to  the  writ  jurisdiction  under 
Article  226  of  the  Constitution,  but  in  certain 
circumstances, a writ may issue to such private bodies 
or persons as there may be statutory provisions which 
need to  be complied  with  by all  concerned  including 
societies. If they violate such statutory provisions a writ 
would be issued for compliance of those provisions. 
(v) Where a Special Officer is appointed in respect of a 
co-operative society which cannot be characterised as a 
State  a writ would lie when the case falls under Claus es 
(iii) and (iv) above.
(vi) The  bye-laws  made  by  a  co-operative  society 
registered under the Tamil Nadu Co-operative Societies 
Act, 1983 do not have the force of law. Hence, where a  
society cannot be characterised as a  State , the ser vice 
conditions  of  its  employees  governed  by  its  bye-laws 
cannot be enforced through a writ petition.

primary_legal_issue: Whether a government employee dismissed on disciplinary grounds is entitled to statutory retirement benefits such as gratuity, EPF, and leave encashment despite the dismissal and pending criminal proceedings.
summary: The petition, filed by the legal representatives of the deceased S. Vetrivel, sought a writ of mandamus directing the Cooperative Society and its registrars to pay the petitioner’s retirement benefits—gratuity, EPF, earned and unearned leave encashment, six months’ salary and subsistence allowance. The petitioner had been appointed Secretary of the Muthandikuppam Primary Agricultural Co‑operative Credit Society in 1975 and was terminated on 26‑06‑2009 following disciplinary proceedings under Section 81 of the Tamil Nadu Cooperative Societies Act, which also resulted in a surcharge of Rs 5,57,050. The petitioner contended that dismissal does not extinguish his right to statutory benefits, and that any loss could be adjusted against those benefits. The respondents argued that the termination and criminal proceedings barred payment. The Court, relying on earlier Madras High Court decisions (WP(MD) Nos. 979, 980 of 2016 and WP(MD) No. 10329 of 2019), held that dismissal does not preclude entitlement to gratuity, EPF, and leave encashment, though the society may deduct any proven loss. Accordingly, the Court directed the respondents to disburse the benefits within eight weeks, allowing deductions for loss, and disposed of the petition without costs.
facts: The first petitioner was appointed Secretary of the Muthandikuppam Primary Agricultural Co‑operative Credit Society on 01‑09‑1975. In 2007 an inquiry under Section 81 of the Tamil Nadu Cooperative Societies Act was initiated for alleged irregularities in granting jewel loans. A surcharge of Rs 5,57,050 was imposed on 02‑04‑2009. The disciplinary proceedings concluded with the petitioner’s termination on 26‑06‑2009. No retirement benefits were paid thereafter. A criminal case (C.C.No.46 of 2009) was later disposed, and the petitioner was placed under probation. The petitioner’s family filed a writ petition seeking gratuity, EPF, leave encashment, six months’ salary and subsistence allowance.
arguments: Petitioners argued that statutory retirement benefits accrue irrespective of dismissal and that the society may only adjust amounts against any proven loss. They cited earlier Madras High Court orders directing payment of such benefits even to dismissed employees. Respondents contended that the termination and pending criminal liability justified withholding benefits and that the loss amount should be recovered from the petitioner’s dues.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the statutory scheme governing cooperative societies and noted that the entitlement to gratuity, EPF and leave encashment is based on service rendered, not on the manner of termination. It relied on WP(MD) Nos. 979 and 980 (2016) and WP(MD) No. 10329 (2019), which held that dismissal does not extinguish benefit rights, though societies may deduct amounts proven to be losses. The Court therefore ordered payment of all benefits within eight weeks, permitting deduction of the Rs 5,57,050 loss if already accounted for during criminal proceedings.
key_legal_points: Dismissal does not extinguish statutory retirement benefits
Co‑operative societies may deduct proven losses from terminal benefits
Madras High Court precedents mandate payment of gratuity, EPF and leave encashment to dismissed employees

primary_legal_issue: Whether the respondents are bound to waive the lease dues for the 15th year and the extended period under the lease agreements with the petitioner.
summary: The petitioners, MGM Entertainments Private Limited, filed two writ petitions (W.P. Nos.40 & 41 of 2022) under Article 226 of the Constitution seeking a mandamus directing the State of Tamil Nadu and the Tamil Nadu Tourism Development Corporation Ltd. to waive lease payments of Rs.12,22,346 and Rs.20,48,208 respectively, arising from the 15th year and extended period of lease agreements for "Hotel Tamilnadu" at Coonoor and Ranipet. The petitioner argued that the COVID‑19 lockdown prevented payment of the lease/franchise fees and that representations dated 18‑Nov‑2021 and 10‑Nov‑2021 requesting waiver had not been acted upon. The respondents conceded that the representations would be considered in accordance with law and that appropriate orders would be passed. The Court, without delving into the merits, directed the respondents to consider the petitioner’s representations and to pass orders within twelve weeks of receipt of the order. Consequently, both writ petitions were disposed of without costs. The judgment reflects the Court’s procedural intervention to ensure administrative consideration of the petitioner’s request, rather than adjudicating the substantive claim for waiver.
facts: MGM Entertainments entered into 15‑year lease agreements with the Tamil Nadu Tourism Development Corporation Ltd. for operating "Hotel Tamilnadu" at Coonoor and Ranipet. Due to the COVID‑19 lockdown, the petitioner could not pay the lease/franchise fees for the 15th year and the extended period. The petitioner sent representations on 18‑Nov‑2021 and 10‑Nov‑2021 requesting a waiver of the outstanding amounts, but no order was issued by the respondents.
arguments: Petitioner: The lockdown constituted a force majeure event preventing payment; the petitioner had timely represented for a waiver and sought judicial direction to compel the respondents to consider and grant the waiver. Respondents: Acknowledged receipt of the representations and agreed to consider them in accordance with law, without contesting the substantive merit of the waiver request.
judgment_reasoning: The Court refrained from examining the substantive merits of the waiver claim, noting that the respondents had already indicated they would consider the petitioner’s representations as per law. Accordingly, the Court issued a procedural direction for the respondents to act on the representations within twelve weeks, thereby disposing of the writ petitions.
key_legal_points: The Court can issue procedural directions without deciding substantive issues when the opposite party has agreed to consider the matter.
Article 226 empowers the High Court to issue mandamus to compel public authorities to perform a statutory duty.
A writ petition may be disposed of on procedural grounds if the matter is pending before the respondent authority.
The Court can set a time‑frame for the respondent to act on representations.
legal_issues: Whether the respondents are legally bound to waive the lease dues upon the petitioner’s representations.
Whether a mandamus can be issued to compel consideration of a waiver request.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the plaintiffs are entitled to a one‑seventh share in the two schedule properties and the corresponding rental income despite the existence of a Will (1992) and a Settlement Deed (1994) executed by the deceased P. Ganesan.
summary: The appeal (Appeal Suit No.312 of 2011) challenges a decree dated 17‑12‑2009 of the City Civil Court, Chennai, which granted partition of two adjoining properties (Schedule A – 954 sq ft and Schedule B – 500 sq ft) and ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiffs a one‑seventh share of rental receipts. The plaintiffs, heirs of Lakshmi (second daughter of the deceased P. Ganesan), claim a one‑seventh interest in both properties and the corresponding mesne profits. The defendants rely on a 1992 Will in favour of the first defendant (G. Murugesan) and the mother, and a 1996 Settlement Deed in favour of the second defendant, asserting that these instruments vest full ownership in them, rendering the partition suit untenable. The trial court, after evaluating oral testimony and documentary evidence (sale deeds, settlement deeds, Will, rent ledgers), held that the settlement deed transferred only half of Schedule A to the plaintiffs, leaving the remaining half to the first defendant, and that the plaintiffs were entitled to their one‑seventh share and rental proceeds. The appellant contends the trial court mis‑appreciated the documents and facts. The High Court, after hearing counsel, examined the validity of the Will versus the settlement deed, the extent of the transferred interests, and the right to mesne profits, ultimately dismissing the appeal and upholding the lower court’s decree.
facts: P. Ganesan purchased two properties (Schedule A: 954 sq ft; Schedule B: 500 sq ft). He executed a settlement deed (16‑06‑1994) granting half of Schedule A (475.25 sq ft) to his second daughter Lakshmi. He also executed a Will (27‑08‑1992) bequeathing the entire Schedule A to G. Murugesan and Lakshmi jointly. After Lakshmi’s death (20‑04‑2007) and P. Ganesan’s death (26‑12‑2007), the plaintiffs (Lakshmi’s heirs) claimed a one‑seventh share in both properties and the corresponding rental income. Defendants collected rents from tenants since 01‑01‑2008. The trial court decreed partition and rental share in favour of the plaintiffs.
arguments: Plaintiffs argued that the settlement deed transferred only a half‑share to their mother, leaving the remaining half to be shared with the first defendant under the Will, thus entitling them to a one‑seventh interest and mesne profits. First defendant relied on the Will, asserting full ownership of the entire Schedule A, and sought dismissal. Second defendant relied on a separate settlement deed (23‑02‑1996) for Schedule B, claiming exclusive possession and right to collect rent.
judgment_reasoning: The court examined the chronology of the Will (1992) and the settlement deed (1994). It held that the settlement deed superseded the Will to the extent of the half‑share expressly conveyed to Lakshmi, making that portion exclusive property of the plaintiffs. The balance of Schedule A remained with the first defendant by virtue of the Will. Consequently, the plaintiffs were entitled to a one‑seventh share of the whole property and the corresponding rental income. The second defendant’s claim over Schedule B was similarly limited, and the plaintiffs’ entitlement to mesne profits was affirmed.
key_legal_points: A settlement deed executed after a Will can carve out a specific portion of property, limiting the Will’s operation over that portion
Heirs are entitled to a proportional share of rental income from undivided property
A Will does not automatically extinguish rights created by a later settlement deed
Partition suits may be decreed where co‑heirs hold undivided interests
legal_issues: Entitlement of heirs to a one‑seventh share in undivided property
Effect of a later settlement deed on a prior Will
Right to mesne profits from jointly owned property

primary_legal_issue: Whether the review application filed under Order 47 Rule 1 CPC is maintainable on the grounds raised by the petitioners.
summary: The petitioners—Lakshmi and two minors, Akash and Harish—filed a review application (Rev. Aplc. No.41 of 2022) before the Madras High Court, seeking to set aside the judgment dated 09 July 2021 in S.A. No.50 of 2009. The review was sought on four grounds: alleged adverse possession by respondents, non‑challenge to cancellation of a settlement deed, the majority of the second appellant at the time of the original decree, and alleged non‑appreciation of evidence of P.W.2 and non‑joinder of a witness. The Court examined the applicability of Order XLVII Rule 1 of the CPC, which permits review only on the basis of an error apparent on the face of the record, discovery of new and important matter, or evidence that could not have been known despite due diligence. The Court held that the petitioners' grounds were essentially matters that should have been raised during the second appeal and did not fall within the limited scope of a review. Consequently, the review application was dismissed without costs. The judgment underscores the restrictive nature of review proceedings and the necessity for parties to raise substantive objections at the appropriate stage of appeal.
facts: Petitioners filed a review application against the High Court's judgment in S.A. No.50 of 2009, which stemmed from a second appeal (section 100 CPC) against a decree in A.S. No.19 of 2006, itself reversing an earlier decree in O.S. No.292 of 2003. The review sought to overturn the earlier judgment on grounds relating to adverse possession, settlement deed cancellation, majority of a minor appellant, and alleged evidentiary oversights.
arguments: Petitioners argued that (a) respondents had adverse possession and thus could not seek declaration, (b) the settlement deed cancellation was unchallenged making the suit untenable, (c) the second appellant had attained majority at the time of the original decree, and (d) the court failed to properly consider P.W.2's evidence and omitted a crucial witness, Muthu. The respondents contended that these issues were either already decided or should have been raised during the second appeal, not in a review.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the grounds raised do not satisfy the criteria for review under Order XLVII Rule 1 CPC. No error apparent on the face of the record, no new and important matter, and no evidence undiscovered despite due diligence were demonstrated. The matters raised are essentially grounds for a fresh appeal, not for review. Hence, the review application was dismissed.
key_legal_points: Review under Order 47 Rule 1 CPC is limited to specific grounds.
Grounds must show error apparent on the face of the record, new evidence, or undiscovered facts.
Issues not raised in the original appeal cannot be resurrected in a review.
Dismissal of review does not prejudice the right to file a fresh appeal on substantive grounds.
legal_issues: Maintainability of the review application under Order 47 Rule 1.
Whether the petitioners' grounds qualify as errors or new evidence.
Effect of non‑joinder of a witness on the original decree.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner is entitled to suspension of his imprisonment pending disposal of the revision petition.
summary: The petition under Cr.P.C. s.397 r/w s.439 seeks suspension of a six‑month simple imprisonment imposed on K. Pradeep in STC No.46 of 2016 for conviction under NI Act s.138 and a compensation order under Cr.P.C. s.357(3). The conviction and sentence were affirmed by the Fast‑Track Judicial Magistrate, Coonoor (20‑04‑2018) and later by the Sessions Judge, Nilgiris (31‑03‑2022). The petitioner filed a Criminal Revision Petition challenging both conviction and sentence, contending substantial grounds for relief. The learned counsel argued that the revision raises serious questions warranting suspension of the sentence. The High Court, after reviewing the material, found merit in the revision and ordered suspension of the substantive imprisonment, directing the petitioner to surrender to the trial court, execute a bail bond of Rs.10,000, and comply with identification requirements. The order also permits the petitioner’s release on bail pending final disposal of the revision. The judgment underscores the court’s discretion under s.397 r/w s.439 Cr.P.C. to stay imprisonment when the appeal raises substantial issues, balancing the interests of justice with the petitioner’s liberty.
facts: K. Pradeep was convicted in STC No.46 of 2016 for issuing a cheque dishonoured under NI Act s.138. He was sentenced to six months’ simple imprisonment and ordered to pay Rs.1,00,000 as compensation under Cr.P.C. s.357(3). The conviction and sentence were affirmed by the Fast‑Track Judicial Magistrate, Coonoor and later by the Sessions Judge, Nilgiris. The petitioner filed a Criminal Revision Petition challenging the conviction and sentence, seeking suspension of the imprisonment and bail pending disposal of the revision.
arguments: The petitioner’s counsel submitted that the revision raises substantial questions of law and fact, justifying suspension of the sentence under s.397 r/w s.439 Cr.P.C. The prosecution did not oppose the suspension, and the court noted the need to protect the petitioner’s liberty while the revision is pending.
judgment_reasoning: The Court exercised its discretion under s.397 r/w s.439 Cr.P.C., observing that the revision petition contains substantial grounds warranting detailed appraisal. Accordingly, it granted suspension of the imprisonment, conditioned on surrender to the trial court, execution of a bail bond, and compliance with identification formalities, thereby balancing the interests of justice and the petitioner’s right to liberty.
key_legal_points: Suspension of sentence is permissible under s.397 r/w s.439 Cr.P.C. when the appeal raises substantial issues
The court may impose conditions such as bail bond and surrender to the trial court
The conviction under NI Act s.138 and compensation under s.357(3) Cr.P.C. remain unaffected pending final disposal
legal_issues: Whether the revision petition raises substantial grounds justifying suspension of imprisonment
Whether bail can be granted pending disposal of the revision

primary_legal_issue: Whether the settlement reached in Lok Adalat is in the best interest of the minor petitioner and complies with the Legal Services Authorities Act.
summary: The case (CMA No.51 of 2023) involves a minor petitioner, S. Manoj, represented by his father and natural guardian, Guru, who appealed a Motor Accidents Claims Tribunal award of Rs.2,60,000 with interest. The appellant sought a higher compensation for the minor's education and future medical expenses. The respondents, Kuppan and United India Insurance Co. Ltd., contested the award but agreed to settle the matter through a National Lok Adalat held on 9 September 2023, presided over by Justice V. Lakshminarayanan and two members. After mediation, the parties settled on an additional payment of Rs.3,00,000 over and above the tribunal award, totaling Rs.5,60,000. The appellant’s counsel certified that the settlement serves the minor’s interests and causes no prejudice. The court directed the respondent to deposit the agreed sum within eight weeks, ordered the transfer of funds via RTGS/NEFT, and directed the refund of court fees under the Court Fees Act. The award was modified accordingly, and the appeal was disposed of. The judgment underscores the permissibility of settlements in Lok Adalat under the Legal Services Authorities Act and the court’s role in ensuring that such settlements protect the interests of vulnerable parties.
facts: A motor accident resulted in injury to minor S. Manoj. A claim was filed before the Motor Accidents Claims Tribunal, which awarded Rs.2,60,000 with interest. The appellant (minor’s father) appealed the award, alleging that the amount was insufficient for the minor’s education and future medical needs. The respondents, Kuppan and United India Insurance Co., contested the award but participated in a National Lok Adalat for settlement.
arguments: Appellant’s counsel argued that the minor required additional funds for education and medical expenses and that the settlement amount of Rs.3,00,000 above the tribunal award was necessary and in the minor’s best interest. Respondent’s counsel agreed to the settlement, emphasizing the benefit of a swift resolution and avoidance of prolonged litigation.
judgment_reasoning: The court, after confirming that the settlement was mutually agreed upon and beneficial to the minor, accepted the parties’ compromise. It invoked Chapter VI and Section 21 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987, allowing Lok Adalat awards to be modified by agreement. The court also ordered the refund of court fees per the Court Fees Act, 1870, and directed the respondent to deposit the agreed sum within the stipulated time, thereby disposing of the appeal.
key_legal_points: Lok Adalat settlements are permissible under Chapter VI and Section 21 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987.
A settlement must be in the best interest of a minor and cause no prejudice.
Court fees paid for the appeal are refundable under the Court Fees Act, 1870.
The award can be modified by mutual agreement without further petition.
Payment must be made through RTGS/NEFT as directed by the court.
legal_issues: Whether the settlement amount adequately protects the minor’s interests.
Validity of modifying a tribunal award through Lok Adalat settlement.
Compliance with the Legal Services Authorities Act and Court Fees Act.

case_type: Appeal under Section 54 of the Land Acquisition Act
primary_legal_issue: Whether the referral court’s enhancement of compensation for acquired land, based on market value, was lawful and the decree of the District Judge should be upheld.
summary: The appeal (AS No.100 of 2012) filed by the Revenue Divisional Officer, Tiruvannamalai, under Section 54 of the Land Acquisition Act seeks to set aside the decree dated 28‑04‑2006 (LAOP No.82 of 1995) that enhanced compensation to claimants for land acquired under Section 4(1) of the Act. The claimants, seven persons, owned parcels in survey Nos.84/3D1 and 86/2B,A1 totaling about 1.15 hectares. The acquisition officer initially fixed a market value of Rs.21,500 per acre, but the referral court, applying Section 18(1), re‑fixed compensation at Rs.2,000 per cent after examining evidence (Ex.C1, Ex.C2, CW1, CW2, RW1, Ex.R1‑Ex.R11). The court noted that the acquisition officer failed to consider prevailing market values and relied on prior judgments (LAOP No.7 of 1986) and comparable sales (Rs.6 per sq.ft.). The High Court held that the referral court correctly applied legal principles, found no infirmity in the decree, and dismissed the appeal, confirming the enhanced compensation. No costs were awarded.
facts: The government acquired land in Tiruvannamalai for a market committee. The acquisition officer fixed a market value of Rs.21,500 per acre. Claimants filed petitions for enhanced compensation. The referral court, under Section 18(1), re‑evaluated the market value, considering prior award (LAOP No.7 of 1986) and a comparable sale (Rs.6 per sq.ft.), and fixed compensation at Rs.2,000 per cent. The appellant challenged this enhanced award.
arguments: Appellant argued that the acquisition officer’s original valuation was correct and that the referral court erred in re‑fixing compensation. Respondents contended that the acquisition officer ignored prevailing market values and that the referral court rightly enhanced compensation based on comparable transactions and established case law.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the acquisition officer failed to consider the prevailing market value at the time of acquisition, contrary to established jurisprudence of this Court and the Supreme Court. The referral court’s reliance on comparable sales and prior judgments was proper. No infirmity or illegality was found in the decree, leading to its confirmation and dismissal of the appeal.
key_legal_points: Acquisition officer must fix market value based on prevailing rates
Referral court may enhance compensation under Section 18(1) when original valuation is deficient
Comparable sales and prior awards are valid aids in determining market value
Decree of lower court stands if no infirmity is shown
legal_issues: Whether the acquisition officer’s valuation complied with the Land Acquisition Act
Whether the referral court correctly exercised its power to enhance compensation
Whether the decree enhancing compensation is legally sustainable
precedents_cited: LAOP No.7 of 1986 dated 01‑10‑1986 (market value determination)

primary_legal_issue: Whether the writ petition seeking certiorari and quashing of the order can be withdrawn by the legal heirs of the deceased petitioner.
summary: In W.P. No.1 of 2020, C. Kalidoss filed a writ petition before the Madras High Court seeking a writ of certiorari to obtain the entire record of an order passed by the Revenue Divisional Officer, Thiruvannamalai, and to have that order quashed. During the hearing, counsel for the petitioner informed the Court that the petitioner had died and that the legal heirs, through their counsel, did not wish to pursue the matter further. An endorsement to this effect was placed in the court bundle. The Court recorded the submission and, considering the endorsement, dismissed the petition as withdrawn, granting liberty to reopen the matter if necessary, and ordered no costs. All connected miscellaneous petitions were also closed.
facts: The petitioner filed a writ petition for certiorari to obtain records and quash an order dated 21.11.2019. The petitioner subsequently died. The petitioner's counsel, on instructions from the legal heirs, sought to withdraw the petition.
arguments: Counsel for the petitioner argued that the legal heirs did not wish to continue the litigation and requested permission to withdraw the writ petition.
judgment_reasoning: The Court accepted the withdrawal request, noting the endorsement in the court bundle and the lack of any objection from the respondent. It dismissed the petition as withdrawn, allowing the possibility of reopening if circumstances change, and ordered no costs.
key_legal_points: A writ petition may be withdrawn by the petitioner or legal heirs with the Court's permission.
The Court can dismiss a petition as withdrawn without imposing costs.
Liberty to reopen the matter may be granted if needed.
legal_issues: Withdrawal of a writ petition after the petitioner's death.
Procedural propriety in dismissing a petition as withdrawn.

primary_legal_issue: Whether a second appeal under Section 100 CPC can be entertained when neither party appears before the court.
summary: The Madras High Court heard S.A.No.914 of 1996, an appeal filed by C. Thailappa Varma (appellant) against a decree dated 29 July 1991 passed by the District Munsiff Court, Dharmapuri, and affirmed by the Subordinate Judge, Dharmapuri, on 25 July 1995. The appeal was filed under Section 100 of the Code of Civil Procedure. On the scheduled hearing date of 18 February 2021, no counsel or parties appeared for either side. The matter was consequently listed for dismissal. By 26 February 2021, the date of the judgment, there was still no representation from either the appellant or the respondents. The court, adhering to procedural rules that require parties to be present or represented for the hearing of an appeal, dismissed the second appeal for default, ordering no costs. The judgment was signed by the Assistant Registrar (CS VI) and a true copy was sent to the Subordinate Judge and the District Munsiff Court, Dhramapuri. No substantive legal arguments were advanced, and no precedents were cited. The decision underscores the court's strict adherence to procedural compliance in appellate matters, emphasizing that failure to appear results in dismissal irrespective of the merits of the underlying dispute.
facts: The appellant sought to overturn a decree confirming a judgment of the District Munsiff Court, Dharmapuri, dated 29 July 1991. The appeal was filed under Section 100 CPC. The Subordinate Judge had earlier affirmed the decree on 25 July 1995. No parties or counsel appeared for the hearing scheduled on 18 February 2021, and the same situation persisted on 26 February 2021 when the judgment was delivered.
arguments: No arguments were presented as neither the appellant nor the respondents appeared before the court.
judgment_reasoning: The court applied the procedural rule that an appeal cannot proceed without representation. Since both sides failed to appear, the appeal was deemed abandoned and dismissed for default, with no costs awarded.
key_legal_points: An appeal under Section 100 CPC requires representation of at least one party.
Failure to appear before the court results in dismissal for default.
The court may dismiss an appeal without hearing substantive merits when procedural defaults occur.
legal_issues: Procedural default in appellate proceedings
Effect of non‑appearance on the continuance of a Section 100 appeal

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner is entitled to a writ of mandamus directing the respondents to refrain from constructing a public toilet adjacent to his agricultural land.
summary: The petitioner, A. Sivasami, filed a writ petition under Article 226 of the Constitution seeking a mandamus directing the District Collector, the Commissioner of Panchayat Union, and the Block Development Officer to stop the construction of a public toilet adjacent to his 83‑cent agricultural plot (S.No.170/2A, Thirumannur Village, Salem). The petitioner alleged that the toilet blocked access to his land and that the authorities had ignored his representation dated 15‑06‑2020 and a pre‑contempt notice dated 20‑08‑2020. The respondents contended that the petitioner had not clarified the nature of the adjoining land and that the petition was an improper exercise of contempt jurisdiction, rendering it non‑maintainable. The Court noted that the respondents had failed to respond to a communication from the Divisional Engineer, Highways, dated 28‑07‑2020, which indicated no permission was granted for the toilet. However, the Court held that the petitioner had already initiated contempt proceedings for wilful disobedience of the earlier order dated 24‑07‑2020 in WP‑No.9604/2020, making the present writ petition an unnecessary duplication. Consequently, the writ petition was dismissed, the petitioner was directed to pursue remedies under the Contempt of Courts Act, and no costs were awarded.
facts: The petitioner owns agricultural land (S.No.170/2A) in Thirumannur Village. A public toilet was being constructed on the road margin adjacent to his plot, allegedly obstructing access. He submitted a representation on 15‑06‑2020 requesting the authorities to consider his objection. The Single Bench ordered the first respondent to act on the representation within two weeks (order dated 24‑07‑2020). The respondents failed to comply, and the petitioner issued a pre‑contempt notice on 20‑08‑2020. He also cited a communication from the Divisional Engineer, Highways, dated 28‑07‑2020, stating that no permission was granted for the toilet near KM25/2. The petitioner filed the present writ petition seeking a mandamus to stop the construction.
arguments: Petitioner: Asserted that the construction infringed his property rights, blocked agricultural access, and that the authorities had wilfully ignored his representation and the pre‑contempt notice. He relied on the earlier order and the Highways Engineer’s communication to argue that the toilet was unauthorized. Respondents: Argued that the petitioner had not clarified the exact nature of the adjoining land, that the contempt jurisdiction was being misused, and that the writ petition was therefore non‑maintainable.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the petitioner had already initiated contempt proceedings for the wilful disobedience of the 24‑07‑2020 order in WP‑No.9604/2020. Since the contempt remedy was pending, the Court deemed the present writ petition an unnecessary and duplicative exercise. While noting the respondents' failure to respond to the Highways Engineer’s communication, the Court held that the appropriate avenue for redress was the contempt petition, not a fresh writ. Accordingly, the writ petition was closed without costs.
key_legal_points: A writ petition cannot be used to duplicate relief already sought through contempt proceedings.
Non‑compliance with a prior order may be addressed under the Contempt of Courts Act.
The Court may dismiss a writ petition as unnecessary if the relief sought is already being pursued in another proceeding.
legal_issues: Maintainability of a writ petition when contempt proceedings are pending.
Whether the construction of a public toilet adjacent to private land can be restrained by mandamus.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the Executive Magistrate has the jurisdiction to impose imprisonment and fine and whether the sentence imposed in M.P.No.18 of 2022 can be suspended pending the revision proceedings.
summary: The petition (Crl.M.P.No.20 of 2023) filed by Kabilan under Section 397(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code seeks suspension of a sentence imposed by the Executive Magistrate and Deputy Commissioner of Police, Adyar, in M.P.No.18 of 2022 dated 11‑11‑2022, and release on bail pending the disposal of the revision case. The petitioner had earlier executed a bond which the first respondent later cancelled, alleging breach of its terms and ordering detention. Both sides were heard. The bench noted that numerous similar orders have been referred to it, raising a larger question on the statutory power of Executive Magistrates to impose imprisonment and fine. Relying on the limited jurisdiction conferred by the CrPC, the court inclined to suspend the order of detention and release the petitioner on bail, subject to conditions: execution of a fresh bond of Rs.10,000 before the Superintendent of Central Jail, Puzhal, regular appearance before the second respondent police officer every Friday, and release if no further detention is required in other proceedings. The order reflects the court’s view that the Executive Magistrate exceeded its authority in imposing custodial punishment and that the petitioner is entitled to bail pending the outcome of the revision. The judgment thus grants the relief sought, suspending the sentence and directing release on bail.
facts: Kabilan was sentenced by the Executive Magistrate and Deputy Commissioner of Police, Adyar, in M.P.No.18 of 2022 on 11‑11‑2022. He executed a bond as part of the sentence. The first respondent later cancelled the bond, alleging its breach, and ordered Kabilan’s detention. Kabilan filed a petition under Section 397(1) CrPC seeking suspension of the sentence and bail pending the revision of the case.
arguments: The petitioner argued that the Executive Magistrate exceeded its jurisdiction by imposing imprisonment and that the cancellation of the bond was unlawful. The respondents contended that the petitioner violated bond conditions, justifying detention. Both sides presented statutory interpretations of the powers of Executive Magistrates under the CrPC.
judgment_reasoning: The bench observed that Executive Magistrates have limited powers under the CrPC, primarily to impose fines and short-term imprisonment, not extended custodial sentences. The cancellation of the bond without proper authority was deemed beyond the magistrate’s jurisdiction. Consequently, the court found merit in suspending the detention and granting bail, subject to conditions ensuring compliance and safeguarding public interest.
key_legal_points: Executive Magistrates possess limited sentencing powers under the CrPC
Cancellation of a bond by an Executive Magistrate must be within statutory authority
Petitioner is entitled to bail pending revision of the sentence
Court can suspend an order that exceeds jurisdiction
legal_issues: Jurisdiction of Executive Magistrates to impose imprisonment
Validity of bond cancellation by the Executive Magistrate
Eligibility of bail pending revision proceedings

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner may withdraw the pending criminal petition.
summary: In Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 381 of 2023, the petitioner, through counsel, sought permission to withdraw the petition. The counsel submitted an endorsement in the court bundle indicating the petitioner's desire to withdraw. The learned judge, V. Sivagnanam, considered the endorsement and dismissed the petition as withdrawn on 11 January 2023. No substantive issues on merits were addressed, and no statutes or precedents were cited.
facts: The petitioner filed Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 381 of 2023. Subsequently, the petitioner's counsel filed an endorsement expressing the petitioner's wish to withdraw the petition.
arguments: No arguments on the merits were presented; the sole argument pertained to the petitioner's request for withdrawal.
judgment_reasoning: The court accepted the endorsement submitted by the petitioner's counsel as a valid indication of the petitioner's intention to withdraw. Accordingly, the petition was dismissed as withdrawn.
key_legal_points: A petition can be withdrawn by the petitioner through a clear endorsement by counsel.
The court may dismiss a petition as withdrawn upon acceptance of such endorsement.
legal_issues: Withdrawal of a criminal petition.

case_type: Civil suit (Trademark infringement and passing off)
primary_legal_issue: Whether the plaintiff can obtain a permanent injunction against the defendants for alleged infringement and passing off of the ‘BROOKE BOND 3 ROSES’ trademark.
summary: The plaintiff, Brooke Bond India Ltd., filed a civil suit (C.S.No. 946 of 1991) in the Madras High Court seeking a permanent injunction against twelve defendants alleging infringement of its registered trademark ‘BROOKE BOND 3 ROSES’ and passing off of tea sold under that mark. The reliefs sought included restraining the defendants from using the mark or any deceptively similar mark, surrendering and destroying infringing labels, accounting for profits, and payment of damages and costs. The suit was filed under Order IV Rule 1 of the Original Side Rules and Sections 105 and 106 of the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958. During the hearing, the plaintiff’s counsel, Mr. Madhan Babu, informed the court that the plaintiff had instructed him to withdraw the suit. The court recorded the withdrawal, dismissed the suit as withdrawn, and granted the plaintiff liberty to sue again if a subsequent cause of action arises. No costs were awarded. The judgment contains no substantive analysis of trademark law, as the matter was disposed of on procedural grounds. The order was signed by Justice R. Subramanian on 22 October 2021 and later approved in January 2022.
facts: Brooke Bond India Ltd. claimed ownership of the registered trademark ‘BROOKE BOND 3 ROSES’ for tea. It alleged that the twelve defendants were using the same or deceptively similar marks on tea products, thereby infringing the trademark and committing passing off. The plaintiff sought injunctions, destruction of infringing labels, an account of profits, damages, and costs. The suit was filed under the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958. No evidence or witness testimony was presented because the plaintiff’s counsel later announced a withdrawal of the suit.
arguments: The plaintiff’s counsel argued for a permanent injunction, destruction of infringing material, an accounting of profits, and damages based on alleged trademark infringement and passing off. No defense was presented as the defendants did not appear. Subsequently, the plaintiff’s counsel informed the court that the plaintiff wished to withdraw the suit, leading to the dismissal.
judgment_reasoning: The court recorded the plaintiff’s instruction to withdraw the suit. In the absence of any pending claim, the suit was dismissed as withdrawn, with liberty granted to the plaintiff to institute fresh proceedings if a new cause of action arises. No costs were awarded.
key_legal_points: Suit filed under Sections 105 and 106 of the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958
Relief sought included injunction, destruction of infringing labels, accounting of profits, and damages
Court dismissed the suit on procedural ground of withdrawal
Plaintiff retained right to sue again if a subsequent cause of action arises
legal_issues: Trademark infringement of ‘BROOKE BOND 3 ROSES’
Passing off of tea under the plaintiff’s mark
Procedural propriety of suit withdrawal

primary_legal_issue: Whether the civil suit for administration, partition and accounting of the deceased's estate can proceed when the plaintiff fails to appear or be represented.
summary: In C.S.No.1364 of 1995, S. Visalakshi Ammal filed a civil suit under Order IV Rule 1 read with Order VII Rule 1 of the Civil Procedure Code seeking administration, partition, and accounting of the estates of the deceased Devasenambal Ammal and T.M.P. Devasenambal Ammal. The plaintiff sought a decree directing the division of properties into six shares, appointment of an administrator, rendering of true accounts by several defendants, and various ancillary reliefs including the appointment of a receiver and commissioner. The suit listed 29 respondents, many of whom were deceased heirs or trustees of various temples and charitable institutions. On 18 October 2023, the matter was listed for hearing, but no counsel appeared on behalf of the plaintiff. The court, after noting the absence of any representation, ordered the suit to be posted for dismissal on 19 October 2023. The judgment affirmed dismissal for non‑prosecution, with no costs awarded. No substantive arguments or evidentiary material were considered, and the court relied solely on procedural rules governing abandonment of a suit due to the plaintiff's failure to prosecute.
facts: The plaintiff, S. Visalakshi Ammal, claimed entitlement to a share of the estates left by the deceased Devasenambal Ammal and T.M.P. Devasenambal Ammal. She sought a decree directing the administration, valuation, partition into six equal shares, and delivery of one share to herself, along with orders for accounting, payment of dues, joint possession of certain charitable properties, and appointment of a receiver and commissioner. The suit named 29 respondents, including deceased heirs, temple trustees, and executive officers, many of whom were added through subsequent orders. The plaintiff did not appear in court on the scheduled hearing date.
arguments: No arguments were presented as the plaintiff failed to appear or be represented at the hearing. Consequently, the court could not consider any substantive contentions from either side.
judgment_reasoning: The court applied Order IV Rule 1 of the Civil Procedure Code, which permits dismissal of a suit for non‑prosecution when the plaintiff does not appear or present any evidence. Since there was no representation for the plaintiff on 18 October 2023 and none appeared subsequently, the suit was dismissed for non‑prosecution. No costs were awarded as the dismissal was procedural.
key_legal_points: A civil suit may be dismissed for non‑prosecution under Order IV Rule 1 of the CPC.
Absence of the plaintiff or his counsel at a scheduled hearing constitutes abandonment of the suit.
No costs are awarded when dismissal is solely on procedural grounds of non‑appearance.
legal_issues: Whether the suit can proceed in the absence of the plaintiff's representation.
Whether the court may dismiss a suit for non‑prosecution under CPC provisions.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the preventive detention order under Tamil Nadu Act No.14 of 1982 is invalid due to unexplained delay and lack of a live and proximate link between the grounds and purpose of detention.
summary: The petition, filed under Article 226, seeks a writ of habeas corpus for the release of Thimmaiyya @ Ravi, detained in Central Prison, Salem under a preventive detention order dated 24‑09‑2022 (S.C.No.35/2022). The order was issued under Tamil Nadu Act No.14 of 1982 on the ground that the detainee was a ‘goonda’ (Section 2(f)). The ground case originated as Crime No.210 of 2022, initially involving IPC Section 302 and later amended to include Sections 143, 294(b), 341, 52(A), 120(B), 302, 201 and the SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act. The petitioner argued that there was no live and proximate link between the grounds of detention and its purpose because the remand in the ground case occurred on 03‑08‑2022, yet the detention order was passed over a month later, constituting an unexplained delay. The respondents contended that the delay was necessary for material collection. Relying on the Supreme Court’s Banik judgment, which distinguishes unreasonable from unexplained delay, and on several Madras High Court precedents, the bench held that the delay was unexplained and the detention order invalid. Consequently, the writ was allowed, the detention order set aside, and the detainee ordered to be released forthwith.
facts: Thimmaiyya @ Ravi, aged 38, was detained in Central Prison, Salem under a preventive detention order dated 24‑09‑2022 issued by the District Collector (second respondent) under Tamil Nadu Act No.14 of 1982, labeling him a ‘goonda’. The ground case (Crime No.210 of 2022) stemmed from alleged murder (IPC 302) and related offences, later amended to include several IPC sections and the SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act. The petitioner, Hemavathi, his wife, filed a habeas corpus petition under Article 226 seeking his release, alleging that the detention order was passed after an unexplained delay and lacked a live and proximate link between the grounds and purpose of detention.
arguments: Petitioner’s counsel argued that the detention order was issued on 24‑09‑2022 despite the remand in the ground case occurring on 03‑08‑2022, creating an unexplained delay and breaking the required live and proximate link between grounds and purpose of detention. Respondents’ counsel contended that the delay was justified for collection of material and that procedural requirements were met.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the principle laid down in Sushanta Kumar Banik’s case, distinguishing between unreasonable and unexplained delay. It held that the delay here was unexplained, as no satisfactory explanation was provided by the State. The Court also noted that preventive detention is not punitive and must strictly adhere to procedural safeguards, including a demonstrable link between grounds and purpose. Citing Madras High Court precedents that followed Banik, the Court found the detention order defective and set it aside, ordering the detainee’s release.
key_legal_points: Preventive detention orders must have a live and proximate link between grounds and purpose
Unexplained delay invalidates a detention order
Procedural safeguards under Article 226 are stringent for habeas corpus
Supreme Court’s Banik judgment is controlling on delay analysis
Madras High Court has consistently applied Banik principles in HCP matters

primary_legal_issue: Whether the plaintiff's claim to ownership of copyright and telecasting rights in the film "Sivantha Mann" can be enforced, given the lack of prosecution of the suit.
summary: The plaintiff, J. Karunakaran, filed a civil suit (C.S. No. 686 of 1995) seeking a declaration of absolute ownership of limited copyrights and telecasting rights in the 16mm film "Sivantha Mann" (released 1 January 1995) and a permanent injunction against four defendants: M/s. R.R.C. Pictures, M/s. Gemini Colour Laboratory, the Station Director of Doordarshan Madras, and the Controller of Programmes of Doordarshan New Delhi. The suit invoked Sections 55 and 62 of the Copyright Act, 1957, and procedural provisions of the Civil Procedure Code. The first defendant had previously been dismissed for non‑prosecution on 31 January 1998, and defendants three and four were set ex parte on 26 June 2007. On 22 April 2022, the matter was listed for hearing, but the plaintiff did not appear. The court, noting the continued absence of the plaintiff, ordered the suit dismissed for non‑prosecution and awarded no costs. The judgment underscores the procedural requirement that a plaintiff must actively prosecute a suit; failure to do so results in dismissal irrespective of the substantive copyright claims.
facts: The plaintiff claimed ownership of limited copyrights and 99‑year telecasting rights in the Tamil film "Sivantha Mann" (16 mm) from 1 January 1995. He sought a declaration of ownership and a permanent injunction against the defendants to prevent interference with exploitation, exhibition, and distribution of the film. The first defendant had earlier been dismissed for non‑prosecution in 1998, and the remaining defendants were set ex parte in 2007. No parties appeared for the hearing on 22 April 2022.
arguments: The plaintiff asserted that he was the absolute owner of the copyrights and telecasting rights and therefore entitled to a declaration and injunction. No substantive arguments were presented by the defendants, and the plaintiff failed to appear or present counsel at the hearing.
judgment_reasoning: The court observed that the plaintiff did not appear for the hearing and there was no representation for the suit. Under procedural law, a suit that is not actively prosecuted must be dismissed. Consequently, the court dismissed the suit for non‑prosecution and ordered that no costs be awarded.
key_legal_points: A civil suit must be actively prosecuted; failure to appear leads to dismissal.
Non‑prosecution of a claim results in dismissal irrespective of the substantive merits.
No costs are awarded when a suit is dismissed for non‑prosecution.
legal_issues: Ownership and enforceability of copyright in a film.
Procedural requirement of prosecution of a civil suit.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the appellants have acquired title by adverse possession to the land acquired for a railway over‑bridge and are therefore entitled to the compensation award, or whether the 1st claimant retains the right to the award.
summary: The appeal (A.S. No.201 of 2016) challenges a decree dated 06‑08‑2015 of the VI Assistant Judge, City Civil Court, Chennai, which awarded compensation for land acquired under Award No.1/2011 to the 1st claimant, C.S. Premkumar (deceased). The appellants – four siblings (P.T. Chandrasekaran, P.T. Vijayalakshmi, P.T. Vivekanandan, P.T. Sethumadhavan) – claim that they have been in exclusive possession of the land since 1982, have mortgaged it, and thus acquired title by adverse possession. They argue the trial court ignored documentary evidence (Ex.C8‑C18) supporting their claim. The respondents, led by the Special Deputy Collector, rely on a settlement deed dated 28‑08‑1980 (Ex.C1) showing the land was settled in favour of the 1st claimant, and contend the appellants never possessed the land without the true owner's knowledge. The High Court examined the settlement deed, the lack of proof of continuous, hostile possession, and the absence of tax receipts or other evidence of adverse possession. Citing Supreme Court precedents on adverse possession, the Court held that the 1st claimant’s title was valid and the trial court’s award was correct. Consequently, the appeal was dismissed and the connected miscellaneous petition closed.
facts: The land was acquired for a railway over‑bridge under Award No.1/2011 (15‑07‑2011). A settlement deed dated 28‑08‑1980 transferred the land to C.S. Premkumar, the 1st claimant. The appellants, his nephews, occupied the land from 1982, mortgaged it in 1995 and 2001, and claimed ownership by adverse possession. The 1st claimant died; his heirs were impleaded as respondents R3‑R7. The trial court awarded compensation only to the 1st claimant, rejecting the appellants' claim. The appellants appealed, asserting adverse possession and challenging the trial court’s omission of their documentary evidence.
arguments: Appellants argued that continuous possession since 1982, mortgage transactions, and lack of any objection by the true owner established adverse possession, and that the trial court erred by not considering Ex.C8‑C18. Respondents argued that the settlement deed unequivocally vested title in the 1st claimant, that the appellants’ possession was with the claimant’s knowledge, and that the appellants failed to prove hostile, exclusive possession or the right to mortgage the land, citing Supreme Court decisions on adverse possession.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the settlement deed confirming the 1st claimant’s ownership and noted that the appellants admitted this deed. It found the appellants failed to demonstrate possession without the true owner’s knowledge, lacked tax receipts, and did not establish the right to mortgage the land. Relying on SC precedents that require clear, uninterrupted, hostile possession for adverse possession, the Court concluded the trial judge’s finding that the 1st claimant was entitled to compensation was legally sound and required no interference.
key_legal_points: A settlement deed establishing title supersedes unproven adverse possession claims
Adverse possession requires continuous, exclusive, hostile possession without owner’s knowledge
Mortgage of land presupposes ownership or a valid title
Higher courts will not disturb lower court findings absent clear error
legal_issues: Validity of the settlement deed as proof of title
Whether the appellants satisfied the legal criteria for adverse possession
Whether the trial court erred in rejecting the appellants’ documentary evidence
