     This appeal has been filed challenging the fair and 
decreetal order dated 06.08.2015 made in L.A.O.P No.90 of 2013, 
by the VI Assistant Judge, City Civil Court, Chennai.
      2.A reference has been filed by the 1st respondent/Special 
Deputy  Collector  (Land  Acquisition),  Tamil  Nadu  Ubran 
Development Project III,  Poonamalee, Chennai, under Section 
22(3)  of  the  Tamilnadu  Highways  Act  2001,  to  decide  the 
apportionment of compensation amount with regard to the land 
acquired for construction of Railways over bridge in GNT Road, 
in Award No.1 of 2011 dated 15.07.2011. The appellants are the 
claimants 2 to 5 and the 2nd respondent is the 1st claimant in 
the said LAOP.  
     3.After perusing the oral and documentary evidence, the 
learned VI Assistant Judge, City Civil Court, Chennai, held that 
only the 2nd respondent/1st claimant is entitled to receive the 
compensation amount as per the norms passed by the Referring 
Officer  in  Award  No.1/2011,  dated  15.07.2011  and  the 
appellants / claimants 2 to 5 are not entitled to claim the 
award amount. Challenging the above fair and decreetal order, 
the present appeal has been filed by the appellants / claimants 
2 to 5.
4.The case of the appellants/claimants 2 to 5 is that the 
property under reference is originally belonged to the uncle of 
the claimants 2 to 5 namely, P.C.T.Sambandham, who is none other 
than the elder brother of the claimants' father Thayumanavan. 
The claimants 2 to 5 are in exclusive possession and enjoyment 
of the property from the year 1982, while their father was alive 
and even after the demise of their father, they have been 
continuing their occupation in the acquired land and in the 
remaining property.  The 1st respondent / 1st claimant had never 
been in possession of the acquired land. The claimants 2 to 5 
have mortgaged the property twice in 1995 and again in 2001 and 
exercised their right over the acquired land.  Hence, the 1st 
https://hcservices.ecourts.gov.in/hcservices/
claimant is not entitled to receive the compensation.  The Court 
below, without considering the documents filed by the appellants 
to show that they have prescribed the title by way of adverse 
possession, has passed a fair and decreetal order in favour of 
the 2nd respondent/1st claimant.  Challenging the same, the 
appellants are before this Court.
5. Pending this appeal, since the 2nd respondent/1st 
claimant died, his legal heirs were impleaded as the respondents 
3 to 7.
6.  This  Court  heard  the  learned  counsel  for  the 
appellants as well as the learned counsel for the respondents 3 
to 7.
7. The learned counsel for the appellants would submit 
that the appellants have prescribed their title by way of 
adverse possession since 1982 and to prove the said contention, 
the appellants have filed the documents in Ex.C8 to Ex.C18, but 
the same has not been considered by the Court below. Eventhough 
it is alleged by the 2nd respondent/1st claimant that he has 
given permission to the appellants to reside in the property, 
the same has not been proved by him.  The onus is on the 1st 
claimant to prove that he has given permission to reside.  The 
1st claimant had never been in possession of the suit property. 
Further, he would submit that  the appellants have mortgaged the 
property after they became the absolute owners of the property. 
Therefore, the findings of the Court below that  the 1st 
claimant had perfected his title over the acquired land and is 
entitled to receive the compensation amount are erroneous in law 
and therefore, the fair and decreetal order passed by the Court 
below needs interference by this Court and hence, he  prays to 
allow this appeal.  
8. The learned counsel for the respondents 3 to 7 would 
submit  that  as  per  the  settlement  deed  Ex.C1,  the  2nd 
respondent/1st claimant is the owner of the property and his 
title was also admitted by the appellants/claimants 2 to 5. 
But, the appellants are in possession of the suit property 
without the knowledge of the true owner and therefore, they are 
not entitled to claim title by way of adverse possession. He 
would rely on the decisions reported in (i) (2017) 13 Supreme 
Court Cases 705 [Dagadabai (dead) by Legal Representatives vs. 
Abbas Alias Gulab Rustum Pinjari]  and (ii) (2019) 15 Supreme 
Court Cases 756 [Mallikarjunaiah vs. Nanjaiah and others)  and 
hence, the award passed by the trial Court is in accordance with 
law.
https://hcservices.ecourts.gov.in/hcservices/
9. This Court considered the submissions made on either 
side and also perused the materials placed on record.  For the 
sake of convenience, the parties herein after are referred to as 
they were arrayed in the suit.
10. The point for consideration is, as to whether the 
impugned fair and decreetal order  of the Court below is 
sustainable or not?
11.  On  a  perusal  of  Ex.C1,  settlement  deed  dated 
28.08.1980, it reveals that the acquired land was settled in 
favour of the 1st claimant, namely, C.S.Premkumar, by one 
P.C.Thirugnana Sambanda Muadaliar, who is his uncle.  The said 
fact has also been admitted by the claimants 2 to 5. To prove 
the contention raised by the claimants 2 to 5 that they had 
perfected their title by adverse possession, they have filed 
Ex.C8 to Ex.C18. Even though the claimants 2 to 5 have marked 
the aforesaid documents, they have failed to prove that they are 
in possession and enjoyment of the acquired land  without the 
knowledge of the true owner.  Further, with regard to the 
contention of the claimants 2 to 5 that they have mortgaged the 
acquired land,  they ought to have been proved  under what right 
they have mortgaged the said property. But, they have miserably 
failed to do so. Moreover, the claimants 2 to 5 have not filed 
any documents viz., tax receipts and water tax receipts to prove 
their claim that they had perfected their title by adverse 
possession.   
     12.  At the same time, the 1st claimant has marked Ex.C1, 
settlement deed and Ex.C2, patta and other documents to prove 
his claim that he is the owner of the acquired land.  Though the 
1st claimant is the owner of the property and it was also 
admitted by the claimants 2 to 5, but claiming right over the 
property without proving their title by adverse possession, is 
not correct.
  
     13. In view of the above, this Court finds that the learned 
VI Assistant Judge, City Civil Court, Chennai,  after a careful 
perusal of the oral and documentary evidence adduced by both 
sides, has rightly come to a conclusion that the 1st claimant is 
entitled for the compensation  of award amount and hence, the 
order  passed  by  the  Court  below  does  not  warrants  any 
interference by this Court and the present appeal is liable to 
be dismissed.

costs. Consequently, connected Miscellaneous Petition is closed.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the IDOP No.703 of 2022 pending in the Family Court at Tiruchirappalli can be transferred to the Family Court at Chennai under Section 24 of the CPC.
summary: The petition filed by E. Jenifer seeks transfer of IDOP No.703 of 2022, a restitution of conjugal rights case pending before the Family Court at Tiruchirappalli, to the Family Court at Chennai. The marriage between the parties was solemnised on 27.01.2021 under Christian rites; they now live separately. The respondent, A. Franco, initiated the IDOP. The petitioner, employed as a temporary lecturer in Chennai, argued that attending proceedings in Tiruchirappalli would cause hardship and that the wife’s residence (Chennai) should be the preferred forum for matrimonial disputes. The Hon'ble Justice S. M. Subramaniam, after considering the circumstances, exercised the power under Section 24 of the Civil Procedure Code to order the transfer of the case to Chennai and directed the Tiruchirappalli court to transmit the records within two weeks. The transfer petition was allowed, the connected miscellaneous petition was closed, and no costs were awarded.
facts: The parties were married on 27.01.2021 under Christian rites. They are now living separately. Respondent filed IDOP No.703 of 2022 for restitution of conjugal rights in the Family Court, Tiruchirappalli. Petitioner works as a temporary lecturer in Chennai and claims difficulty in traveling to Tiruchirappalli for the proceedings.
arguments: Petitioner’s counsel argued that the petitioner’s place of residence is Chennai, making it inconvenient to attend hearings in Tiruchirappalli, and that matrimonial disputes should be heard at the wife’s residence. No substantive argument from the respondent was recorded in the order.
judgment_reasoning: The court considered the petitioner’s residence and the inconvenience of travel, finding merit in transferring the case to the jurisdiction where the petitioner resides. Under Section 24 of the CPC, the court has discretion to transfer proceedings for the convenience of parties and efficient administration of justice. Accordingly, the IDOP was ordered to be transferred to the Family Court at Chennai.
key_legal_points: Section 24 of the Civil Procedure Code empowers the High Court to transfer cases for convenience of parties.
Residence of the wife can be a relevant factor in determining the appropriate forum for matrimonial disputes.
Transfer orders must be accompanied by directions for the originating court to transmit records within a reasonable time.
legal_issues: Appropriateness of transferring a family court matter under Section 24 of the CPC.
Whether the petitioner’s residence justifies a change of jurisdiction.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the testamentary suit and the connected application can proceed in the absence of any representation by the plaintiff.
summary: The Madras High Court, sitting on 15 June 2023, heard a testamentary civil suit (TOS No.3 of 1971) and a connected application (A.No.2079 of 2023) concerning the approval of a trust created under the terms of the will of the deceased Smt. T.K. Kannamma, dated 9 July 1965 and probated on 29 June 1973. The plaintiff, Srinivasiah, sought confirmation of the trust and permission to implement the will's provisions under Order XIV Rule 8 of the Madras High Court O.S. Rules, Section 259 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925, and Section 151 of the CPC. On 6 June 2023, the matter was listed but no counsel appeared for the plaintiff. The court again listed the matter on 15 June 2023, and still no representation was made. Consequently, Justice R.N. Manjula dismissed the testamentary suit for default and closed the connected application. The judgment underscores the procedural requirement of representation for a suit to proceed and illustrates that default leads to dismissal irrespective of the substantive issues involved.
facts: The will of Smt. T.K. Kannamma, dated 9 July 1965, was probated under TOS No.3 of 1971 on 29 June 1973. A trust was created pursuant to a prior court order (A.No.4237 of 2013 dated 13 August 2021). The plaintiff, Srinivasiah, filed a testamentary civil suit and a related application seeking approval of the trust and permission to carry out activities under the will's terms. No appearance was made by the plaintiff's counsel on the scheduled dates.
arguments: No arguments were presented as the plaintiff's counsel did not appear on either of the listed dates.
judgment_reasoning: The court observed that the plaintiff failed to appear for the hearing on both occasions. Under the procedural rules, a suit cannot proceed without representation. Accordingly, the testamentary suit was dismissed for default, and the connected application was closed.
key_legal_points: A suit cannot proceed without representation by the plaintiff.
Default in appearance leads to dismissal under Order XIV Rule 8.
Connected applications are closed when the primary suit is dismissed.
legal_issues: Procedural default due to lack of representation.
Approval of a trust under the Indian Succession Act.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the order of acquittal under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act can be set aside on the ground that the trial court failed to appreciate the repayment of part of the cheque amount.
summary: The petitioner filed a private complaint under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act alleging that the respondent failed to honour a cheque of Rs.3,60,000 dated 11‑08‑2018. The respondent repaid Rs.1,62,840 on 30‑08‑2018, leaving a balance that remained unpaid. The learned Judicial Magistrate, Fast Track, Magisterial Level, Poonamallee acquitted the respondent on 26‑10‑2022, holding that the transaction was unsustainable. The petitioner challenged the acquittal, contending that the trial court erred by not giving due weight to the partial repayment and by misapplying the law. The High Court, after perusing the record, observed that the trial court had indeed overlooked the admission of repayment and that a prima facie case existed for re‑appreciation of evidence. Consequently, the Court granted leave to the petitioner to file a criminal appeal against the acquittal order, directing the registry to number the appeal if otherwise in order. The judgment underscores the necessity for trial courts to consider all material facts, especially partial payments, when adjudicating offences under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act.
facts: The petitioner lodged a complaint under Section 138 NI Act for non‑payment of a Rs.3,60,000 cheque (No.872786) dated 11‑08‑2018. The respondent repaid Rs.1,62,840 on 30‑08‑2018; the remaining amount remained unpaid. The trial court acquitted the respondent on 26‑10‑2022, concluding that the transaction was unsustainable.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the trial court failed to appreciate the evidence of partial repayment and incorrectly applied the law, thereby warranting a re‑appreciation of facts and granting leave to appeal. The respondent made no submissions in the petition.
judgment_reasoning: The High Court found that the trial court had not considered the admission of repayment and had misapplied legal principles relating to Section 138 NI Act. A prima facie case existed for re‑appreciation, justifying the grant of leave to appeal.
key_legal_points: Partial repayment under Section 138 NI Act is a material fact
Trial courts must consider all evidence before acquitting
Leave to appeal may be granted if trial court erred in law or fact
legal_issues: Whether the trial court erred in not considering partial repayment
Whether the acquittal order can be challenged under Section 138 NI Act

primary_legal_issue: Whether the applicants are entitled to leave to file a suit against Blue Dart Aviation Limited.
summary: On 5 October 2021, the Madras High Court heard two applications (Nos. 172 and 173 of 2007) filed by Dhruv Pradeep Dave and Sanjeev Chopra seeking leave to sue Blue Dart Aviation Limited. Both applicants sought permission to initiate civil suits against the respondent company, which is incorporated under the Companies Act 1956. During the hearing, counsel for the applicants requested permission to withdraw the applications. The Court, after considering the withdrawal request, dismissed the applications as withdrawn, without addressing the substantive question of leave to sue. The order was signed by Justice V. Parthiban on the same day. No substantive legal arguments, precedents, or statutory sections beyond the Companies Act were discussed, and the matter concluded with the dismissal of the applications.
facts: The petitioners filed separate applications requesting the Court's permission to sue Blue Dart Aviation Limited. The applications were filed under the civil jurisdiction of the Madras High Court. During the hearing, the petitioners' counsel sought to withdraw the applications.
arguments: The only argument presented was the petitioners' counsel's request to withdraw the applications; no substantive arguments on the merits of granting leave to sue were made.
judgment_reasoning: The Court accepted the counsel's request to withdraw the applications and consequently dismissed them as withdrawn. No further examination of the merits of the leave to sue request was undertaken.
key_legal_points: Withdrawal of an application results in its dismissal.
The Court did not need to consider the substantive issue of granting leave to sue.
legal_issues: Whether leave to sue should be granted to the applicants.
Effect of withdrawal of applications on pending proceedings.

petitioners: M/s. Aurosimon Division of M/s. Auro Food Limited
respondents: M/s. Aurosimon Division of M/s. Auro Food Limited
primary_legal_issue: Whether the trial court correctly awarded interest and had jurisdiction to entertain the suit for recovery of machinery supply price.
summary: The Madras High Court heard two civil appeals (A.S.No.963/2015 and A.S.No.4/2015) arising from a common judgment of the II Additional District Court, Tindivanam, concerning a dispute between M/s. Aurosimon (Auro Food Ltd.) and M/s. R.T. Exports Ltd. over supply and erection of rice‑mill machinery at the defendant’s Haryana plant. The plaintiff claimed Rs 25,13,296.72, alleging non‑payment despite delivery and installation, and sought interest at 9% p.a. The trial court awarded the balance of Rs 12,97,373.72, a “C” form of Rs 3,50,723, and interest at 12% from installation to filing, later reducing it to 6% from decree to realization, rejecting any interest from filing to decree. The defendants appealed, challenging the award of interest, the trial court’s jurisdiction (arguing cause of action arose in Haryana, not Tindivanam), and alleging defective machinery and limitation. The High Court examined the jurisdictional objection, the applicability of Section 61(2) Sale of Goods Act for interest, and the defect claims. It upheld the trial court’s jurisdiction, affirmed the interest award at 6% post‑decree, and dismissed the appeals, finding no substantive proof of machinery defects or limitation bars. The judgment thus reinstated the trial court’s decree and interest award.
facts: M/s. Aurosimon supplied and erected three rice‑mill plants for M/s. R.T. Exports at Kundli, Haryana, under work orders dated 21‑02‑1994, 22‑09‑1995 and 26‑02‑1996. The total contract value was Rs 25,13,296.72. The defendant paid only Rs 1,50,000 and failed to settle the balance of Rs 12,97,373.72 despite repeated notices. The plaintiff alleged no defect in the machinery and that the installations were accepted. The defendant contended that the machinery was defective, that the cause of action arose in Haryana (thus challenging jurisdiction), and that the suit was barred by limitation.
arguments: The plaintiff argued that the defendant was liable for the full contract price, that interest was payable under Section 61(2) Sale of Goods Act, and that the trial court had jurisdiction as the cause of action arose where the contract was executed. The defendant argued lack of jurisdiction of the Tindivanam court, alleged defects in the machinery, claimed substantial loss and expenses, and raised a limitation defence, asserting the suit was filed three years after the cause of action arose.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the contract and performance occurred in Haryana but the cause of action—demand for payment—arose in Tindivanam where the plaintiff filed suit, establishing jurisdiction. Applying Section 61(2) Sale of Goods Act, the Court affirmed the trial court’s discretion to award interest, accepting the 6% post‑decree rate and rejecting any pre‑decree interest due to the parties’ delay. The defect allegations were unsupported by evidence; the defendant failed to produce documents or expert testimony. The limitation defence was dismissed as the suit was filed within the statutory period for a money claim. Consequently, the appeals were dismissed and the trial court’s decree upheld.
key_legal_points: Jurisdiction is determined by the location where the cause of action arises, not merely where performance occurred.
Section 61(2) Sale of Goods Act empowers courts to award interest at a reasonable rate when no agreement exists.
Defects must be substantiated with concrete evidence; mere allegations are insufficient.
Limitation periods apply to money claims; the suit was timely filed.
legal_issues: Jurisdiction of the trial court to entertain the suit
Appropriate rate of interest under Sale of Goods Act when no contract stipulates interest
Whether the machinery supplied was defective
Applicability of limitation defence

case_type: Civil Suit (Trademark Infringement, Copyright Infringement, Passing Off)
primary_legal_issue: Whether the defendant infringed the plaintiffs' registered trademark ‘SABENA’ and artistic work, amounting to trademark infringement, copyright infringement and passing off.
summary: The plaintiffs, Scientific Compounds and Processes Private Ltd. and ECOF Detergents Private Ltd., filed a civil suit (C.S.No.833 of 2000) in the Madras High Court seeking permanent injunctions against Hanuman Cottage Industry for alleged infringement of their registered trademark ‘SABENA’, use of the similar mark ‘SUBEENA’, and copying of their artistic work on polythene pouches. The reliefs included injunctions to restrain use of the infringing marks, destruction of infringing goods, an account of profits, and damages of Rs.10,05,000. The suit invoked Sections 27, 28, 29, 105 and 106 of the Trade Marks Act, 1958 and Sections 51, 55, 62 and 63 of the Copyright Act, 1957. During the hearing, counsel for the plaintiffs informed the court that the defendant’s products were no longer in the market and the plaintiffs wished to withdraw the suit. The court recorded the withdrawal, dismissed the suit as withdrawn, ordered no costs, and reserved liberty for the plaintiffs to approach the court in the future if a cause of action arises. The judgment reflects procedural disposal rather than substantive adjudication on the trademark and copyright claims.
facts: The plaintiffs own the registered trademark ‘SABENA’ for cleaning powder and an artistic design on polythene pouches. The defendant was allegedly marketing cleaning powder and pouches bearing the mark ‘SUBEENA’ and a design substantially similar to the plaintiffs’ work, constituting infringement and passing off. The plaintiffs sought injunctions, destruction of infringing goods, account of profits, and damages. The defendant’s products were later removed from the market.
arguments: Plaintiffs argued that the defendant’s use of ‘SUBEENA’ and similar pouch design violated the Trade Marks Act and Copyright Act, causing confusion and loss of goodwill. They sought comprehensive injunctive relief and monetary compensation. During the hearing, plaintiffs’ counsel indicated a withdrawal of the suit as the infringing products were no longer available.
judgment_reasoning: The court noted the plaintiffs’ instruction to withdraw the suit. In accordance with procedural law, the suit was dismissed as withdrawn. No substantive examination of the trademark or copyright infringement issues was undertaken. The court ordered no costs and allowed the plaintiffs to approach the court in the future if a new cause of action arises.
key_legal_points: Withdrawal of a suit leads to dismissal without merits being examined
Injunctions can be granted under the Trade Marks Act and Copyright Act for infringement and passing off
Destruction of infringing goods and account of profits are statutory remedies
No costs were awarded as the suit was withdrawn
legal_issues: Whether the defendant infringed the plaintiffs' trademark ‘SABENA’
Whether the defendant copied the plaintiffs' artistic work on polythene pouches
Whether the plaintiffs are entitled to injunction, damages, and account of profits
citations: Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958 Sections 27,28,29,105,106

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner can be exempted from producing a certified copy of the order impugned in the writ petition
summary: In C.M.P.No.539 of 2021, filed as W.A.No. SR 11 of 2021, the petitioner sought relief from the procedural requirement of producing a certified copy of the order that was the subject of the challenge. The petition argued that the certified copy was either unavailable or that its production would cause undue hardship and that the substantive issues could be decided on the basis of the original order and the material on record. The respondents contended that the certified copy was essential for verifying the authenticity of the impugned order and that the procedural rule could not be waived. The Bench comprising the Chief Justice and Justice Senthilkumaar Ramamoorthy examined the statutory provisions governing writ proceedings and held that the High Court has inherent powers to dispense with procedural formalities where strict compliance would defeat the ends of justice. Consequently, the petition was allowed, and the requirement to produce the certified copy was waived. The judgment underscores the court's discretion to relax procedural mandates in the interest of substantive justice.
facts: The petitioner filed a writ petition challenging an order and was directed to produce a certified copy of that order. The petitioner claimed inability to obtain the certified copy and requested exemption from this requirement.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the certified copy was unavailable and that the order’s contents were already evident from the record, making the requirement unnecessary. Respondent argued that a certified copy is essential to establish authenticity and prevent tampering.
judgment_reasoning: The Bench relied on the inherent powers of the High Court to relax procedural requirements when strict compliance would cause injustice. It noted that the purpose of the certified copy rule is to ensure authenticity, which could be satisfied by other means in the present case. Hence, the requirement was dispensed with.
key_legal_points: High Court may dispense with procedural formalities in the interest of justice
Certified copy requirement is not absolute if authenticity can be otherwise established
legal_issues: Whether the requirement to produce a certified copy can be waived

case_type: Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution of India
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Regional Transport Officer is duty-bound to accept and process the petitioner’s application for an autorickshaw permit.
summary: The petitioner, J. Sankar, filed W.P. No. 932 of 2021 seeking a writ of mandamus directing the Regional Transport Officer (RTO) of Salem West to receive his application dated 7 December 2020 for an autorickshaw permit and to consider it on merits. The petitioner alleged that despite submitting the application, the RTO had not received it. The respondent, represented by Government Advocate Mr. Annai Ezhil, produced a written instruction indicating that the RTO had not received any such application and that there existed an objection from the Salem Bus Owners Association, which had filed a separate writ petition (W.P. No. 30613 of 2019) pending before the same court. The court examined the respondent’s claim and, finding no evidence that the application had been received in the prescribed format, declined to issue a mandamus. Instead, the court directed the petitioner to re‑file the application in the correct format within two weeks and the RTO to consider it within three weeks of receipt, without any costs. The order effectively dismissed the petition while ensuring procedural compliance for future filing.
facts: The petitioner submitted an application on 7‑12‑2020 for an autorickshaw permit to operate within a 30 km radius of Salem Town Old Bus Stand. He claimed the Regional Transport Officer (RTO) had not received the application. The respondent RTO asserted that no application had been received and cited an objection from the Salem Bus Owners Association, which had a pending writ petition concerning new autorickshaw permits.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the RTO’s refusal to accept his application violated his right to obtain a permit and sought a writ of mandamus compelling acceptance. Respondent argued that no application had been received in the prescribed format, that there was an objection from the bus owners’ association, and that any pending writ did not preclude consideration of a new application.
judgment_reasoning: The court found that the respondent had not produced any evidence of receipt of the petitioner’s application in the required format. It noted that procedural compliance is a prerequisite for the RTO to consider any permit application. The objection by the bus owners’ association, while noted, did not automatically bar the acceptance of a properly filed application. Consequently, the court declined to grant mandamus and instead directed the petitioner to re‑file the application correctly, after which the RTO must consider it on merits.
key_legal_points: The RTO must receive an application in the prescribed format before it can be considered.
Procedural compliance supersedes pending objections for the purpose of filing.
A writ of mandamus is not appropriate where the petitioner has not complied with statutory filing requirements.
legal_issues: Whether the RTO is obligated to accept an application not filed in the prescribed format.
Whether a writ of mandamus can be issued to compel acceptance of an improperly filed application.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the High Court has jurisdiction to grant leave to sue for alleged hacking and threatened disclosure of confidential data.
summary: In Application No.10 of 2023, the petitioner, SENTHILKUMAR RAMAMOORTHY,J, sought leave to institute a suit for injunctive relief and damages against unnamed respondents alleged to have hacked the petitioner’s IT systems and threatened to disclose confidential customer data. The petitioner argued that the cause of action arose within the jurisdiction of the Madras High Court because the petitioner’s registered office and the servers storing the data are located in Chennai. Senior counsel emphasized the urgency of the matter, citing potential irreparable harm from the threatened data release. The Court examined the draft plaint and found that at least a part of the cause of action indeed arose within its territorial jurisdiction. Consequently, the Court granted leave to sue, directed the Registry to number the suit, and ordered that the interim application accompanying the suit be listed for admission on 03.01.2023. No specific statutes or precedents were cited. The order reflects the Court’s discretionary power to allow a suit when jurisdictional criteria are satisfied and the matter is of urgent nature.
facts: The petitioner runs a business whose registered office and data servers are situated in Chennai. The petitioner alleges that the respondents illegally accessed the petitioner’s computer systems and are threatening to publish confidential customer information. The petitioner filed an application seeking permission to sue for injunction and damages, asserting that the cause of action arose within the jurisdiction of the Madras High Court.
arguments: Petitioner’s counsel argued that the alleged hacking and the location of the data constitute a cause of action arising in Chennai, giving the High Court jurisdiction. The counsel also stressed the urgency due to the risk of data leakage, requesting immediate leave to sue. No substantive defense or counter‑argument from respondents was presented in the order.
judgment_reasoning: The Court reviewed the draft plaint and determined that the essential elements of the cause of action—namely the location of the petitioner’s registered office and the servers—are within its territorial jurisdiction. Recognizing the urgency and potential irreparable harm, the Court exercised its inherent power to grant leave to sue, directing procedural steps for the suit’s registration and admission of the interim application.
key_legal_points: Jurisdiction is established where the plaintiff’s registered office and the subject matter (servers) are located.
The High Court may grant leave to sue when a cause of action arises within its territorial limits.
Urgent matters involving potential data breach justify expedited procedural orders.
legal_issues: Jurisdiction of the High Court over cyber‑related causes of action.
Procedural requirement of obtaining leave to sue in civil suits.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the High Court can exercise its extraordinary powers under Section 482 CrPC to set aside a maintenance order passed by a Judicial Magistrate based on evidence.
summary: On 25 April 2022, the Madras High Court, headed by Justice Sathi Kumar Sukumara Kurup, heard Criminal Original Petition No.84 of 2019 (and Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No.104 of 2019) filed by E. M. Saravanan seeking to set aside an order dated 5 January 2018, passed by Judicial Magistrate No.II, Pollachi, granting maintenance to his wife. The petitioner argued that the wife had left the matrimonial home alleging an illegal affair, a claim he said was unproven, and therefore she was not entitled to maintenance. The respondents (Lalitha, Selvi, Minor S. Ajith) contended that the minor children had attained majority, so maintenance against them was irrelevant, and the petition sought relief only against the wife. The Court examined the scope of Section 482 CrPC, citing the Supreme Court's guidelines in State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal, which restrict the use of extraordinary powers to cases lacking evidentiary material. It held that the maintenance order was based on a factual enquiry by the Judicial Magistrate, and the High Court could not interfere merely because the petitioner disputed the wife’s conduct. Consequently, the petition was dismissed, and the Magistrate was directed to consider any future applications for arrears of maintenance within three months. The connected Criminal Miscellaneous Petition was also closed.
facts: E. M. Saravanan (petitioner) was married to the wife who claimed maintenance. The Judicial Magistrate No.II, Pollachi, on 5 January 2018, granted maintenance to the wife after evaluating evidence. The petitioner challenged this order, alleging the wife left the marital home due to an alleged illegal affair, which he claimed was not proved. The petition also referenced a prior order dated 24 September 2018 from the First Additional District and Sessions Court, Coimbatore, confirming the Magistrate's order. The respondents included Lalitha, Selvi, and Minor S. Ajith, who were minor children at the time of the original maintenance claim.
arguments: Petitioner: Asserted that the wife’s alleged adultery was unproven, thus she was not entitled to maintenance; sought to set aside the Magistrate’s order under Section 482 CrPC; relied on the case of Vijayakumar v. Shanmuga Vadivu for maintenance claims. Respondents: Stated that the minor children had attained majority, so maintenance against them was irrelevant; sought relief only against the wife; argued that the Magistrate’s factual findings were sound and could not be disturbed by the High Court.
judgment_reasoning: The Court emphasized that Section 482 CrPC is an extraordinary power to prevent abuse of the judicial process, not a tool to re‑evaluate evidence. Citing State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal, it held that the High Court may intervene only where there is a clear absence of material or a patent error. Here, the maintenance order was based on a detailed evidentiary enquiry by the Judicial Magistrate, which the High Court could not substitute. The petitioner's contention about the wife's alleged affair was a factual dispute already considered by the lower court. Therefore, the High Court could not set aside the order and dismissed the petition.
key_legal_points: Section 482 CrPC is an extraordinary jurisdiction to quash proceedings, not to re‑appraise evidence.
The High Court must follow the Supreme Court's guidelines in State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal when exercising Section 482.
Maintenance orders passed after evidentiary enquiry by a Judicial Magistrate cannot be set aside by the High Court absent a clear procedural flaw.
Allegations of adultery, if unproven, do not automatically negate a maintenance claim once the lower court has ruled otherwise.
legal_issues: Scope of Section 482 CrPC in interfering with lower court orders.
Whether unproven allegations of adultery can invalidate a maintenance order.
Applicability of Supreme Court guidelines on the exercise of extraordinary powers.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the plaintiffs are entitled to a partition share in the property claimed to belong to the deceased Chinnammal.
summary: The appeal (Suit No.1022 of 1993) filed by Palaniammal and Marimuthu challenges the decree of the Subordinate Judge, Ariyalur, in O.S.No.111 of 1986 concerning partition of family property. The original suit arose after the intestate death of Chinnammal, whose daughter Palaniammal and husband Natesan Servai claimed two‑thirds share of 23 immovable properties. The defendant, Jambulingam Servai (deceased), asserted exclusive possession for over twelve years, invoking a 1936 gift deed (Ex.A1) from his grandfather Karuppanna Servai to Chinnammal, and denied any right of the plaintiffs. The trial court partially allowed the partition suit and the appellants now seek relief on the disallowed portions. The High Court examined documentary evidence, including the 1936 gift deed, a contested 1986 will favoring the third plaintiff, and the custom of male inheritance. It applied Section 92 of the Indian Evidence Act to give primacy to the written deed over oral statements. The Court held that the gift deed conclusively transferred ownership to Chinnammal’s line, that the plaintiffs had no exclusive possession, and that the will was not genuine. Consequently, the appeal was dismissed, upholding the lower court’s partial allowance and confirming the defendant’s exclusive right to the property.
facts: Chinnammal owned extensive immovable property. Palaniammal (her daughter) and Natesan Servai (her husband) claimed two‑thirds share after Chinnammal’s intestate death. Jambulingam Servai, Chinnammal’s elder son, occupied the property for over twelve years, asserting ownership based on a 1936 gift deed from his grandfather Karuppanna Servai. Natesan Servai executed a will in 1986 favoring Marimuthu, which was contested. The trial court partially allowed the partition suit; the appeal concerns the disallowed portion.
arguments: Petitioners argued that they were legal heirs of Chinnammal and entitled to two‑thirds share, that the will of Natesan Servai was valid, and that the defendant’s possession was unlawful. Respondents contended that the 1936 gift deed transferred ownership to Chinnammal’s line, that they had exclusive possession for over twelve years, that the will was forged, and that customary law denied female inheritance.
judgment_reasoning: The Court gave primacy to the 1936 gift deed (Ex.A1) under Section 92 of the Indian Evidence Act, finding it authentic and establishing ownership in the male line. It held that the plaintiffs never enjoyed joint possession and that the defendant’s uninterrupted possession for more than twelve years vested a presumption of ownership. The contested 1986 will was deemed not genuine. Accordingly, the appeal was dismissed, confirming the lower court’s partial decree.
key_legal_points: A written gift deed supersedes oral claims under Section 92 IEA
Uninterrupted possession for 12 years creates a presumption of ownership
A will executed by a person of unsound mind is invalid
Customary male inheritance does not automatically grant share to female members
legal_issues: Entitlement of plaintiffs to partition share
Validity of the 1936 gift deed
Validity of the 1986 will
Effect of long‑term exclusive possession
Applicability of customary inheritance rules

primary_legal_issue: Whether the preventive detention order dated 24.09.2022 under Tamil Nadu Act No.14 of 1982 is invalid due to an unexplained delay and lack of a live and proximate link between the grounds of detention and its purpose.
summary: The petition, filed by Sikkamma under Article 226, sought a writ of habeas corpus for her son Mallesh (also known as Battli), who was detained in Central Prison, Salem under a preventive detention order dated 24 September 2022, issued by the District Collector and Magistrate of Krishnagiri. The order was based on the Tamil Nadu Prevention of Dangerous Activities Act, 1982, classifying the detainee as a "goonda" under Section 2(f). The ground case involved IPC Section 302 and related offences arising from a crime registered on 4 August 2022. The petitioner argued that there was no live and proximate link between the grounds and the purpose of detention, highlighting an unexplained delay of over a month between the remand date and the detention order. The State contended that the delay was necessary for material collection. The Court, relying on the Supreme Court’s Banik judgment, distinguished between unreasonable and unexplained delay, finding the present case fell within the latter. It also noted that the High Court had previously applied Banik in several HCP orders. Concluding that the detention order was vitiated by unexplained delay, the Court set aside the order and directed the immediate release of the detainee, without costs. The order was signed by Justices M. Sundar and M. Nirmal Kumar on 17 April 2023.
facts: Mallesh @ Battli, a 25‑year‑old son of Mallappa, was detained in Central Prison, Salem under a preventive detention order dated 24‑09‑2022 (S.C. No.37/2022) issued by the District Collector and Magistrate of Krishnagiri. The order was made under Tamil Nadu Act No.14 of 1982, classifying him as a "goonda". The underlying criminal case (Crime No.210 of 2022) originated from an FIR lodged on 04‑08‑2022 at Thally Police Station, alleging murder (IPC Sec.302) and several other offences. The petitioner, Sikkamma, mother of the detainee, filed a habeas corpus petition under Article 226 seeking the detainee’s release, alleging that the detention order was issued without a live and proximate link to the ground case and after an unexplained delay.
arguments: Petitioner’s counsel argued that the detention order was issued on 24‑09‑2022, more than a month after the remand date (04‑08‑2022), breaking the required live and proximate link between the grounds of detention and its purpose, and that the delay was unexplained. The State’s counsel contended that the delay was necessary to collect material evidence and that the order was therefore justified.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the principle laid down in Sushanta Kumar Banik v. State of Tripura, distinguishing between unreasonable and unexplained delay. It held that the present case fell within the "unexplained delay" category, as the State failed to justify the month‑long gap between the remand and the detention order. The Court also noted that the High Court had previously applied Banik in similar HCP matters, reinforcing the view that preventive detention must be contemporaneous with the grounds. Since preventive detention is not punitive, any procedural lapse invalidates the order. Consequently, the detention order was set aside and the detainee was ordered to be released.
key_legal_points: Preventive detention must have a live and proximate link between grounds and purpose
Unexplained delay in issuing a detention order vitiates its validity
The Banik judgment provides a two‑facet test: unreasonable delay vs unexplained delay
High Court precedent requires strict adherence to procedural timelines in HCP cases
Preventive detention is not a punishment; procedural safeguards are paramount

primary_legal_issue: Whether the respondent is duty-bound to accept and process the petitioner’s autorickshaw permit application despite procedural objections and pending litigation.
summary: The petitioner, J. Ramesh, filed W.P. No.936 of 2021 under Article 226 seeking a writ of mandamus directing the Regional Transport Officer, Salem West, to receive his autorickshaw permit application dated 7 December 2020 and the requisite fee. The petitioner alleged that the respondent had not received his application. The respondent, through Government Advocate Mr. Annai Ezhil, produced a written instruction indicating an objection by the Salem Bus Owners Association and claimed no application had been received. The court examined the procedural posture, noting that the respondent could not be compelled to act on a non‑existent or improperly filed application. Consequently, the court declined to grant mandamus and instead directed the petitioner to re‑file the application in the prescribed format within two weeks, after which the respondent must consider it on merits within three weeks. No costs were awarded. The order emphasizes procedural compliance over substantive adjudication of the permit request.
facts: Petitioner submitted an autorickshaw permit application on 7‑Dec‑2020. The respondent claimed non‑receipt of the application and cited an objection by the Salem Bus Owners Association, which had a pending writ (W.P. No.30613 of 2019). The petitioner sought a mandamus directing acceptance of the application.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the respondent’s refusal to accept the application violated his right to obtain a permit and sought a mandamus. Respondent argued that no application had been received in the prescribed format and that an objection by the bus owners’ association existed, rendering the petition premature.
judgment_reasoning: The court held that mandamus cannot be issued where the petitioner has not complied with procedural requirements. Since the respondent had not received a properly formatted application, the court could not compel acceptance. The court therefore directed the petitioner to re‑file the application correctly and gave the respondent a timeline to consider it.
key_legal_points: Mandamus is unavailable when the petitioner fails to fulfill procedural prerequisites.
The respondent must receive a properly formatted application before it can be considered.
Objections by third parties do not automatically bar the issuance of a permit absent a substantive order.

respondents: The Regional Transport Officer, Salem West, Salem
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Regional Transport Officer is bound to accept the petitioner’s application for an autorickshaw permit and consequently be subject to a writ of mandamus.
summary: The petition, filed by S. Satheesh Kumar under Article 226 of the Constitution, sought a writ of mandamus directing the Regional Transport Officer (RTO) of Salem West to receive and consider his application dated 7‑12‑2020 for an autorickshaw permit within a 30 km radius of Salem Town Old Bus Stand. The petitioner alleged that despite submitting the application, the RTO had not received it. The respondent, through Government Advocate Mr. Annai Ezhil, produced a written instruction indicating that the Salem Bus Owners Association had objected to new permits and that a related writ (W.P.No.30613 of 2019) was pending before the court. The RTO further claimed no application had been received. The bench, after considering the submissions, directed the petitioner to re‑file the application in the prescribed format and pay the requisite fee within two weeks, after which the RTO must consider it on merits within three weeks. No costs were awarded. The order effectively dismissed the petition for mandamus, placing the onus back on the petitioner to comply with procedural requirements.
facts: The petitioner applied on 7‑12‑2020 for an autorickshaw permit in Form CCPA with the requisite fee. He claimed the Regional Transport Officer (RTO) failed to receive the application. The RTO, citing a written instruction, asserted that the Salem Bus Owners Association had objected to new permits and that a related writ petition was pending. The RTO also stated that no application had been received and that any properly formatted application would be considered on merits.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the RTO’s refusal to accept his application violated his right to obtain a permit and sought a mandamus directing acceptance. Respondent, through the Government Advocate, contended that the RTO had not received any application, that procedural objections existed due to the Bus Owners Association’s pending writ, and that any application submitted in the correct format would be processed.
judgment_reasoning: The court noted the absence of a properly filed application in the prescribed format and the existence of procedural objections raised by the Bus Owners Association. It held that the petitioner must first comply with statutory filing requirements before the RTO can be compelled to act. Consequently, the court declined to issue mandamus and instead directed the petitioner to re‑apply correctly, after which the RTO must consider the application on its merits.
key_legal_points: A writ of mandamus cannot be issued where the petitioner has not complied with procedural filing requirements.
The RTO is obligated to consider any application received in the prescribed format and fee structure.
Pending objections by a third‑party association do not, by themselves, bar the RTO from processing a correctly filed application.
legal_issues: Whether the RTO’s refusal to accept the application amounts to a jurisdictional lapse warranting mandamus.
Whether procedural non‑compliance by the petitioner precludes the issuance of a writ.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the respondents are required to reconvey the unutilized acquired lands in Survey No.107/2, Block No.21, Arumbakkam Village to the petitioner.
summary: Padmalakshmi Ammal filed a writ petition under Article 226 of the Constitution seeking a mandamus directing the Secretary of the Department of Housing Development and the Managing Director of the Tamil Nadu Housing Board to reconvey unutilized acquired lands in Survey No.107/2, Block No.21, Arumbakkam Village, Chennai. The petition was dismissed by the Division Bench on 17 August 2021. The petitioner appealed the order under Clause 15 of the Letters Patent (W.A. No.339 of 2022). During the hearing, counsel for the appellant requested withdrawal of the appeal. The High Court, comprising Chief Justice Munishwar Nath Bhandari and Justice D. Bharatha Chakravarthy, accepted the withdrawal and dismissed the appeal as withdrawn, ordering no costs. The judgment reflects procedural propriety: a withdrawn appeal cannot proceed, and the court need not entertain the substantive claim for reconveyance. No substantive legal reasoning on the merits of the land reconveyance issue was required, and no precedents were cited.
facts: The petitioner sought reconveyance of unutilized acquired lands in Arumbakkam Village, Chennai, alleging that the respondents had failed to transfer the land as per earlier orders. A Division Bench order dated 17 August 2021 dismissed the writ petition. The petitioner filed an appeal under Clause 15 of the Letters Patent (W.A. No.339 of 2022). During the appeal hearing, the appellant's counsel requested withdrawal of the appeal.
arguments: The appellant's sole argument was a prayer for withdrawal of the writ appeal. No substantive arguments on the merits of the reconveyance claim were presented.
judgment_reasoning: The Court accepted the appellant's request to withdraw the appeal. Under procedural law, a withdrawn appeal is dismissed, and the court is not required to address the substantive issues raised in the original petition. Consequently, the appeal was dismissed as withdrawn, and no order as to costs was made.
key_legal_points: A withdrawn appeal is dismissed without consideration of the merits.
No costs are awarded when an appeal is withdrawn.
The court does not need to rule on the substantive claim once the appeal is withdrawn.
legal_issues: Withdrawal of appeal under Clause 15 of the Letters Patent
Entitlement to reconvey unutilized acquired land
Issuance of mandamus under Article 226

respondents: The Regional Transport Officer, Salem West, Salem
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Regional Transport Officer is duty-bound to accept and process the petitioner’s application for an autorickshaw permit filed on 7‑12‑2020.
summary: The petitioner, Magalakshmi, filed W.P. No. 939 of 2021 under Article 226 of the Constitution seeking a writ of mandamus directing the Regional Transport Officer (RTO), Salem West, to receive her application dated 7 December 2020 for an autorickshaw permit within a 30‑km radius of Salem Town Old Bus Stand. The petitioner alleged that despite submitting the application, the RTO had not received it. The respondent, represented by Government Advocate Mr. Annai Ezhil, produced a written instruction indicating an objection raised by the Salem Bus Owners Association and referenced a pending writ (W.P. No. 30613 of 2019) but asserted that no application had been received in the prescribed format. The Court, after considering the submissions, declined to issue mandamus. Instead, it directed the petitioner to re‑file the application in the correct format and pay the requisite fee within two weeks, after which the RTO must consider the application on its merits within three weeks. No costs were awarded. The order effectively dismissed the petition’s relief while providing a procedural pathway for the petitioner to obtain the permit.
facts: Magalakshmi submitted an application on 7‑12‑2020 for an autorickshaw permit. The RTO claimed it had not received the application and cited an objection from the Salem Bus Owners Association and a pending writ (W.P. No. 30613 of 2019). The petitioner sought a mandamus directing the RTO to accept and process the application.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the RTO’s refusal to accept the application violated her right to obtain a permit and sought a mandamus. Respondent argued that no application in the prescribed format had been received and that procedural objections and a pending writ precluded immediate acceptance.
judgment_reasoning: The Court found that the petitioner had not complied with the statutory requirement of filing the application in the prescribed format and paying the fee. Consequently, the RTO was not obligated to accept the informal submission. The Court therefore declined to grant mandamus, opting instead to give the petitioner an opportunity to correct procedural deficiencies.
key_legal_points: Mandamus cannot be issued where the petitioner has not complied with statutory filing requirements.
The RTO must consider applications received in the prescribed format and fee structure.
Procedural objections and pending litigations do not automatically bar consideration of a properly filed application.
legal_issues: Compliance with statutory procedure for filing autorickshaw permit applications.
Scope of mandamus in administrative refusal to accept an application.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the 395‑day delay in filing the appeal can be condoned.
summary: The petition under CMP No. 218 of 2021 sought condonation of a 395‑day delay in filing an appeal. The petitioner filed an affidavit explaining the reasons for the delay. The respondents/claimants did not raise any substantive objection to the condonation. Justice Abdul Quddhos, after reviewing the affidavit and noting the absence of serious objections, ordered that the delay be condoned. The registry was directed to number the appeal, provided it is otherwise in order, and list it for admission on 17‑09‑2021. The judgment reflects the court's discretion to condone procedural delays where sufficient justification is provided and no opposition is raised.
facts: A petition was filed to condone a delay of 395 days in filing an appeal. The petitioner submitted an affidavit detailing the reasons for the delay. The respondents/claimants did not object to the condonation.
arguments: The petitioner argued that the delay was justified and supported by an affidavit. The respondents/claimants made no substantive objection to the condonation.
judgment_reasoning: The court found the affidavit satisfactory and noted the lack of serious objection from the respondents. Exercising its discretion under procedural law, the court condoned the delay and ordered the appeal to be numbered and listed for admission.
key_legal_points: Condonation of delay is permissible when the petitioner provides a satisfactory explanation.
Absence of objection from the opposite party strengthens the case for condonation.
The court may order the appeal to be numbered and listed for admission once delay is condoned.
legal_issues: Whether a delay of 395 days in filing an appeal can be condoned.

respondents: The Sub Registrar, Kinatthukadavu Sub Registrar Office, Kinathukadavu, Coimbatore
primary_legal_issue: Whether the Registry of the Principal District Munsif Court can return a plaint on maintainability grounds and whether the petition directing the suit to be numbered should be allowed.
summary: The petition (C.R.P. No.89 of 2021) filed by Selvi R. Vidya under Article 227 of the Constitution seeks a direction to the Principal District Munsif, Madukarai, Coimbatore, to number suit O.S.R.P. No.1045 of 2020. The petitioner contended that the lower court erred in returning the plaint on the basis of maintainability, that no appellate suit was pending, and that repeated returns were unjustified. The lower court had also held the suit non‑maintainable while a partition suit was pending. The High Court examined the material and observed that the Registry lacks statutory authority under the Civil Procedure Code or the Civil Rules of Practice to return a plaint on maintainability grounds; such questions are for the trial court. Consequently, the Court directed the Principal District Munsif to number the suit if appropriate, within a week, and disposed of the revision petition without costs. The judgment underscores the limited jurisdiction of court registries and reaffirms that maintainability issues must be decided by the trial court, not the Registry.
facts: The original suit O.S.R.P. No.1045 of 2020 was filed for partition. The Registry of the Principal District Munsif returned the plaint on alleged maintainability grounds, stating a pending appellate suit existed, which the petitioner denied. The petitioner argued the return was erroneous and sought a revision to have the suit numbered.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the Registry had no power to return the plaint on maintainability issues, that no appellate suit was pending, and that repeated returns were unjustified. The respondents (the Registry) relied on its discretion to return the plaint, citing alleged pending proceedings.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the Registry’s authority is confined to administrative functions and does not extend to substantive questions of maintainability, which are within the jurisdiction of the trial court under the Civil Procedure Code. No provision empowers the Registry to return a plaint on such grounds. Hence, the petition was allowed to the extent of directing the Munsif to number the suit, and the revision petition was disposed of.
key_legal_points: Registry cannot decide maintainability of a suit
Maintainability issues are for the trial court under CPC
No statutory provision empowers Registry to return plaints on substantive grounds
legal_issues: Authority of court Registry to return plaints on maintainability
Whether a suit pending in appellate forum affects numbering of the suit

ORDER
The limited prayer sought for in the present petition is to
direct the Principal District Munsif, Madukarai, Coimbatore to
number the suit in O.S.R.P.No.1045 of 2020.
2. The learned counsel for the petitioner would submit that
the lower Court failed to see that the return dated 05.11.2020
which relates to the jurisdiction of the Court was explained and
the suit was represented and the same was accepted by the Court
below. Further the lower Court stated that how this plaint is
not maintainable while pending suit before appellate forum,
wherein no such suit is pending in any appellate forum. The
Court below failed to note that there is no justification for
repeated returns. Further the learned counsel for the petitioner
submitted that the lower Court was in error in not taking the
suit on file when it is clearly stated that the defendants
except one are not parties in the suit for partition which
culminated into the second appeal. Hence, the learned counsel
for the petitioner prays to allow this petition.

the materials available on record.

suit was filed for partition. We are constrained to observe here
that the Registry has no authority to return plaints of this
nature,  questioning  the  maintainability  on  legal  provision,
which can be an issue before the Trial Court alone. There is no
provision contemplated either under the Civil Procedure Code or
under the Civil Rules of Practice empowering the Registry to
return the plaint on these grounds of maintainability.

Coimbatore is called upon to instruct his Registry to number the
suit in O.S.R.P.No.1045 of 2020, if it is otherwise in order,
within a period of one week from the date of receipt of copy of
this order.

of. No costs.

acts_referred: Tamil Nadu Buildings (Lease and Rent) Control Act
primary_legal_issue: Whether the rent of Rs.4,500 per month fixed by the Rent Controller is lawful and whether the eviction order based on that rent can be sustained.
summary: The petitioners, N. Sanjay Kumar Jain, filed multiple Civil Revision Petitions (CRP Nos. 114, 137, 138, 139 of 2021) and a Civil Miscellaneous Petition (CMP No. 1293 of 2021) under Section 25 of the Tamil Nadu Buildings (Lease and Rent) Control Act challenging judgments and decrees confirming earlier orders that fixed the monthly rent at Rs.4,500 and ordered eviction of the petitioner. The respondent, C. Arjunkumar Jain, claimed ownership of the premises and sought possession for personal occupation and business. The lower courts had previously determined the rent to be Rs.4,500 per month, directed payment of arrears, and ordered eviction when the petitioner failed to comply. The petitioner contended that the correct rent was Rs.1,000 per month and that the eviction order violated principles of natural justice by giving insufficient time to pay arrears. The High Court examined the procedural history, the findings of the Rent Controller, and the applicability of Sections 11(3) and 11(4) of the Act. It held that the rent determination was already adjudicated, the petitioner had been duly notified, and the short period to pay arrears was consistent with the statutory framework. Consequently, the Court dismissed the revision petitions, upheld the eviction order, and rejected the petition to set aside the earlier orders.
facts: The respondent purchased the property on 28-11-2011 and demanded the petitioner vacate. The petitioner claimed to pay Rs.1,000 per month, while the respondent asserted Rs.4,500 per month. Multiple eviction petitions and rent deposit petitions were filed in the Rent Controller and Rent Control Appellate Authority. The Rent Controller fixed rent at Rs.4,500, ordered arrears of Rs.2,88,000, and directed payment within a week. Non‑compliance led to eviction orders and dismissal of the petitioner’s deposit petitions. The petitioner challenged these orders in several CRPs and a CMP.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the rent was Rs.1,000 per month, that the eviction order was unsustainable without an independent rent determination, and that a one‑week deadline to pay arrears violated natural justice. Respondent argued that the Rent Controller’s determination of Rs.4,500 per month was final, that arrears were due, and that eviction was justified under the Act for personal occupation and demolition.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that the Rent Controller’s determination of rent was conclusive, that the petitioner had been given notice and opportunity to pay, and that the one‑week period to settle arrears was permissible under Section 11(4) of the Act. The Court found no merit in the petitioner's claim of a lower rent and concluded that the eviction order was legally sound.
key_legal_points: Rent determination by the Rent Controller under Section 11(4) is binding unless successfully challenged.
Eviction can be ordered when rent arrears are not paid within the time prescribed by the authority.
Procedural compliance with notice and opportunity to be heard satisfies principles of natural justice.
legal_issues: Validity of the rent amount fixed at Rs.4,500 per month.
Lawfulness of the eviction order based on non‑payment of arrears.
Whether the petitioner was afforded adequate opportunity to comply with the rent payment direction.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the petition for probate can proceed when the petitioner fails to appear or prosecute the suit
summary: The petition filed by R. Ranganathan under O.P. No. 371 of 1998 sought two reliefs: (a) permission to prove a will in the common form and (b) grant of probate of the will throughout Tamil Nadu. The petition was filed under Sections 222 and 276 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925. No advocate or the petitioner appeared before the Court on the hearing dates, including the last hearing on 01‑02‑2022. The Court inferred that the petitioner was not interested in prosecuting the petition. Consequently, the Court dismissed the petition for non‑prosecution, as per the order dated 04‑02‑2022 signed by Justice Abdul Quddhos. The judgment underscores the procedural requirement that a petitioner must actively prosecute a petition for probate; failure to do so results in dismissal irrespective of the substantive merits. No substantive arguments or precedents were cited. The order was certified as a true copy by the Assistant Registrar. This case illustrates the Court’s strict adherence to procedural discipline in probate matters under the Indian Succession Act.
facts: R. Ranganathan filed an original petition seeking probate of a will of the late V. Ramaswami Iyengar. The petition requested permission to prove the will in common form and grant probate throughout Tamil Nadu. The petitioner did not appear in person or through counsel on any of the scheduled hearing dates.
arguments: No arguments were presented as the petitioner failed to appear or engage counsel at any hearing.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the petitioner had not appeared or engaged counsel on any hearing, including the last hearing on 01‑02‑2022. From this, the Court inferred a lack of interest in prosecuting the petition. Under procedural law, a petition that is not actively prosecuted must be dismissed. Accordingly, the petition was dismissed for non‑prosecution.
key_legal_points: Non‑prosecution of a petition leads to dismissal
Petitioner must appear or be represented to pursue probate
Sections 222 and 276 of the Indian Succession Act govern probate petitions
legal_issues: Whether a probate petition can proceed without the petitioner's appearance
Effect of non‑prosecution on the grant of probate

primary_legal_issue: Whether the Tamil Nadu Wakf Tribunal should be directed to dispose of the interim injunction application (IA No. 621/2021) pending in OS No. 37/2021 within a specified time frame.
summary: On 21 January 2022, the Madras High Court, sitting as a single judge, heard Civil Revision Petition No. 73 of 2022 filed by M/s. Hazrath Baquer‑E‑Agha Dargah & Endowment (Hazrath Baqar Aga Dargah Wakf) represented by its President/Muthavalli, Dr. G.S.M.P. Khadri, under Article 227 of the Constitution. The petitioner sought a direction to the Tamil Nadu Wakf Tribunal, Chennai, to dispose of an interim injunction application (IA No. 621/2021) pending in OS No. 37/2021 at the earliest possible date. The respondents, the Tamil Nadu Wakf Board (through its CEO) and Mrs. M. Shenbagavalli, were not required to be served notice due to the limited scope of the prayer. The Court examined the note‑papers, observed that the first respondent had already been heard and the matter was posted for enquiry by the second respondent. Considering the nature of the application as an injunction, the Court directed the Wakf Tribunal to dispose of IA No. 621/2021 within four weeks of receipt of the order. Consequently, the Civil Revision Petition was allowed without costs. The judgment underscores the High Court’s supervisory jurisdiction under Article 227 to ensure expeditious disposal of pending applications before subordinate tribunals.
facts: The petitioner, a Wakf institution, filed a civil revision petition under Article 227 seeking the High Court’s intervention to compel the Tamil Nadu Wakf Tribunal to dispose of an interim injunction application (IA No. 621/2021) pending in OS No. 37/2021. The petitioner argued that the delay in disposal was prejudicial to its interests. The respondents, the Wakf Board and Mrs. Shenbagavalli, were parties to the underlying dispute but were not required to be served notice for this limited prayer.
arguments: The petitioner contended that the Wakf Tribunal had unduly delayed the hearing of IA No. 621/2021 and that a direction from the High Court was necessary to ensure timely justice. The respondents did not file any substantive objection to the prayer, and the record indicated that the first respondent had already been heard while the second respondent’s matter was pending enquiry.
judgment_reasoning: The Court noted the limited scope of the prayer and deemed notice to the respondents unnecessary. It observed from the note‑papers that the first respondent had been heard and the second respondent’s matter was under enquiry. Since IA No. 621/2021 was an injunction application, the Court exercised its supervisory jurisdiction under Article 227 to direct the Wakf Tribunal to dispose of the application within four weeks of receipt of the order. The petition was therefore allowed without costs.
key_legal_points: The High Court can issue interim directions to subordinate tribunals under Article 227.
Notice may be dispensed with when the prayer is limited and does not affect substantive rights.
Timely disposal of injunction applications is essential to prevent prejudice.
legal_issues: Whether the High Court can direct a tribunal to dispose of a pending application within a fixed period.
Whether notice to respondents is required for a limited prayer under Article 227.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the review application under Article 226 can be entertained when the Division Bench order contains no apparent error on the face of the record.
summary: The petitioners E. Mani, E. Raghupathy and E. Ashokan filed a review application (Writ No. 137 of 2021) challenging the Division Bench order dated 16 August 2021 in W.P. No. 16814 of 2021. The original writ sought a mandamus directing various revenue officials to remove encroachments on temple land in Nallur village, Kanchipuram district, and to re‑classify the land and issue a patta. The Division Bench allowed the temple to erect a compound wall and directed the authorities to consider re‑classification after giving parties an opportunity, but it did not dispose of the petitioners’ substantive relief. The petitioners argued that the Division Bench had not issued notice to the review applicants and that the order was erroneous. The respondents contended that the order was clear, contained no adverse finding against them, and that no error was apparent on the face of the record. The High Court, after examining the order, found no adverse language toward the review applicants and observed that the Division Bench had acted within its jurisdiction. Since no error was evident, the Court held that a review could not be entertained and dismissed the review application without costs, closing the connected writ petitions.
facts: Petitioners sought a writ of mandamus to compel removal of encroachments on temple land (S.No. 1C/1, Nallur village) and to obtain re‑classification and patta. The Division Bench, on 16 August 2021, permitted construction of a compound wall for protection and directed revenue authorities to consider re‑classification after hearing all parties. No specific adverse finding against the review applicants (respondents 6‑8) was made.
arguments: Petitioners (via counsel J. Sathiyamoorthy) argued that the Division Bench order was passed without notice to the review applicants, constituting a procedural flaw warranting review. Respondents (via Government Advocate C.D. Modhi) contended that the order contained no error, was procedurally sound, and that the review petition could not be entertained absent a clear mistake.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the Division Bench order and found no adverse or erroneous statement against the review applicants. It held that the order was clear, complied with procedural requirements, and that no error was apparent on the face of the record. Under the principles governing review under Article 226, a review cannot be entertained unless a patent error exists. Consequently, the review application was dismissed.
key_legal_points: A review under Article 226 requires a patent error on the face of the record.
Absence of notice to a party does not automatically render an order reviewable if no substantive error is shown.
The Division Bench’s direction to construct a compound wall and to consider re‑classification was within its jurisdiction.
legal_issues: Whether lack of notice to review applicants amounts to a reviewable error.
Whether the Division Bench order contained any error apparent on the face of the record.

acts_referred: Supreme Court judgment 2006(4) CTC 89 (Maharashtra State Financial Corporation vs. Ashok K. Agarwal)
primary_legal_issue: Whether the invocation of a personal guarantee under Section 31(1)(aa) of the State Financial Corporation Act is barred by the three‑year limitation period prescribed under the Limitation Act.
summary: The application (A.No.27 of 2022) was filed by the 2nd respondent, who is the personal guarantor of a loan taken by the 1st respondent company, seeking to reject O.P.No.486 of 2016 filed by the State Financial Corporation. The corporation claimed that a foreclosure notice was issued on 30‑Oct‑1996, the mortgaged property was taken over on 9‑Jun‑1999, and the property was sold by M/s TIIC, releasing Rs.1,06,80,388 on 24‑Nov‑2011. The guarantor argued that the personal guarantee could be invoked only within three years of the sale proceeds, making the 2016 petition time‑barred. The corporation contended that the limitation for invoking a personal guarantee is three years, but the limitation for actions against the company is twelve years, and thus the petition should not be dismissed. The court examined the statutory provisions, noted that the guarantee was invoked five years after the sale, and relied on Supreme Court precedent that the three‑year period is mandatory. Consequently, the application was allowed and the original petition was rejected as barred by limitation.
facts: 1. The State Financial Corporation (first respondent) issued a foreclosure notice on 30‑Oct‑1996 and took over mortgaged assets on 9‑Jun‑1999. 2. The assets were handed to M/s TIIC, which sold the properties and released Rs.1,06,80,388 on 24‑Nov‑2011 to the corporation. 3. The 2nd respondent, a personal guarantor for the loan, filed an application in 2022 under Sections 31(1)(aa) and 32(11) of the State Financial Corporation Act seeking to reject O.P.No.486 of 2016, arguing that the guarantee could not be invoked after the three‑year limitation period. 4. The corporation filed O.P.No.486 of 2016 to invoke the personal guarantee five years after the 2011 sale.
arguments: Applicant/2nd respondent: The personal guarantee must be invoked within three years of the event (sale proceeds on 24‑Nov‑2011); the 2016 petition is therefore time‑barred. Relied on Supreme Court judgment (2006(4) CTC 89) affirming the three‑year limitation. Respondent/first respondent: No dispute on the three‑year limitation for personal guarantees, but argued that the limitation for actions against the corporation is twelve years, making the cited precedent inapplicable and the petition should not be dismissed.
judgment_reasoning: The court held that Section 31(1)(aa) of the State Financial Corporation Act is not a mode of execution of a decree but a statutory remedy subject to the Limitation Act. The personal guarantee, being a contractual right, is governed by the three‑year limitation period under Articles 136 and 137 of the Limitation Act. Since the corporation received the sale proceeds on 24‑Nov‑2011, the guarantee should have been invoked by 24‑Nov‑2014. The petition filed in 2016 exceeded this period, making it barred by limitation. The Supreme Court precedent cited by the applicant was deemed applicable, leading to the rejection of the original petition.
key_legal_points: Section 31(1)(aa) of the State Financial Corporation Act is subject to the Limitation Act.
Personal guarantees are enforceable only within three years of the cause of action.
Articles 136 and 137 of the Limitation Act prescribe the limitation period for contractual claims.
Supreme Court decision in Maharashtra State Financial Corporation vs. Ashok K. Agarwal confirms the three‑year rule.
legal_issues: Whether the three‑year limitation period applies to the invocation of a personal guarantee under the State Financial Corporation Act.
Whether the petition filed in 2016 is time‑barred.
