respondents: The District Revenue Officer, Salem, Salem District
The Inspector of Police, Civil Supplies CID, Salem, Salem District
case_type: Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution of India
primary_legal_issue: Whether the petitioner is entitled to a writ of mandamus directing the release of the seized lorry upon deposit of a stipulated sum and compliance with conditions.
summary: On 6 January 2022 the Madras High Court heard W.P. No.37 of 2022 filed by S. Uma seeking a writ of mandamus under Article 226 directing the District Revenue Officer, Salem, to release a lorry (Regn. No. TN-25-M-9696) seized by the Inspector of Police, Civil Supplies CID, on 17 December 2021 on suspicion of illegal PDS rice transport. The petitioner claimed the vehicle remained idle and offered to deposit Rs.2,00,000 to facilitate its release. The respondents raised no substantive objection. The Court noted that the seizure was premised on alleged illegal activity but, with no further evidence and the vehicle lying idle, continued detention served no purpose. Accordingly, the Court directed the release of the lorry subject to conditions: the petitioner must deposit Rs.2,00,000 within two weeks, appear in person with ownership documents, and the respondent must release the vehicle within one week of receipt of payment; the petitioner must not use the vehicle for unlawful purposes or alienate it during proceedings, and the respondent may initiate appropriate legal action thereafter. The writ petition was disposed of with these directions and no costs were awarded.
facts: The lorry bearing registration TN-25-M-9696 was seized on 17-12-2021 by the Inspector of Police, Civil Supplies CID, Salem on the allegation of illegal transportation of PDS rice. The petitioner, S. Uma, filed a representation with the District Revenue Officer seeking release of the vehicle, which remained unconsidered. Consequently, a writ petition under Article 226 was filed requesting a mandamus directing release of the lorry.
arguments: Petitioner argued that the vehicle was idle, offered to deposit Rs.2,00,000 to secure its release, and sought a mandamus directing the respondent to consider the representation. Respondents, represented by the Additional Government Pleader, raised no serious objection to the petitioner's proposal.
judgment_reasoning: The Court held that continued seizure of an idle vehicle served no public interest. While acknowledging the initial allegation of illegal transport, the lack of further evidence and the petitioner's willingness to deposit a sum justified release. The Court therefore granted the writ of mandamus with conditions to ensure ownership verification, prevent misuse, and preserve the respondent's right to pursue appropriate legal action.
key_legal_points: Seizure of a vehicle must be justified by ongoing public interest
Mandamus can be granted with conditions to protect statutory powers
Deposit of a sum can be a condition for release of seized property
legal_issues: Validity of continued seizure of the lorry
Whether a mandamus can be issued directing release subject to monetary deposit

primary_legal_issue: Whether the settlement deed dated 16.11.2020 executed by Lakshmi Ammal in favour of Senthilkumar is legally valid and should be removed from the encumbrance register.
summary: The petitioner Kalyankumar filed W.P. No.417 of 2021 and W.M.P. No.499 of 2021 under Article 226 of the Constitution seeking a writ of certiorari and mandamus to quash a settlement deed dated 16 November 2020 (document No.3561/2020) registered by the Sub‑Registrar, Vikravandi, and to direct the Registrar of Registrations to delete the encumbrance entry relating to that deed. The property in question (S.No.313/8, old S.No.187/4) originally belonged to the petitioner’s father and was adjudicated in his favour in a suit (O.S. No.230 of 1991) which culminated in a decree on 17 April 1995, affirmed by the Supreme Court in 2015 (SLA No. C.23245 of 2008). The petitioner’s mother later executed a settlement deed in 2015 (document No.2376/2015) confirming the title. The fourth respondent, Lakshmi Ammal, claimed title based on a sale deed dated 7 November 1991 (document No.462/1991) and executed a new settlement deed in 2020 in favour of the fifth respondent, Senthilkumar. The Registrar, after investigation, found the 2020 deed improperly registered and ordered its removal from the encumbrance. The High Court upheld this finding, directing the Registrar to delete the 2020 entry, thereby granting the petitioner’s relief and disposing of the writ petition.
facts: The property at Mundiyambakkam Village, Vikravandi Taluk was originally owned by the petitioner’s father. After his death, the petitioner and his mother sued the fourth respondent (Lakshmi Ammal) in O.S. No.230 of 1991 for declaration and injunction. The trial court decreed in favour of the petitioner in 1993 and the appellate court affirmed the decree in 1995. The Supreme Court upheld the decree in 2015 (SLA No. C.23245 of 2008). The petitioner’s mother executed a settlement deed in 2015 (doc No.2376/2015) and obtained a patta. Despite this, Lakshmi Ammal executed a settlement deed on 16 November 2020 (doc No.3561/2020) in favour of Senthilkumar and sought registration. The Registrar, after a detailed enquiry, found the 2020 deed inconsistent with the earlier judgments and ordered its removal from the encumbrance register.
arguments: The petitioner argued that the 2020 settlement deed was void because the fourth respondent had no title over the property, which had already been adjudicated in favour of the petitioner’s mother and recorded in the 2015 settlement deed and patta. The fourth respondent contended that she derived title from a sale deed dated 7 November 1991 and that the 2020 deed was a legitimate transfer to the fifth respondent. The Registrar’s report supported the petitioner’s claim, stating that the 2020 deed was improperly registered and contravened the circular issued by the Registrar of Registrations.
judgment_reasoning: The Court examined the chain of title, noting that the 1991 suit and subsequent decrees conclusively established the petitioner’s mother’s ownership. The 2015 settlement deed further reinforced that title. The sale deed relied upon by the fourth respondent was found to pertain to a different transaction involving S. Chockalingam and R. Chandramoorthy, not the subject property. Consequently, the fourth respondent lacked any legal right to execute a settlement deed in 2020. The Registrar’s investigation was deemed thorough and consistent with statutory provisions, and the Court affirmed the order directing the removal of the encumbrance entry.
key_legal_points: A decree and Supreme Court order confirming title supersede later unsubstantiated claims
Registration of a deed without proper title is void under the Registration Act
The Registrar’s enquiry powers are upheld when exercised in accordance with law
legal_issues: Validity of the 2020 settlement deed
Whether the fourth respondent possessed title to transfer the property
Authority of the Registrar to delete an encumbrance entry

ORDER
The Writ Petition has been filed to call for the records of
the third respondent pertaining to the impugned settlement deed
dated 16.11.2020 registered as document No.3561/2020 on the file
of the SRO, Vikravandi, executed by the fourth respondent in
favour of the fifth respondent and to quash the same and
consequently, direct the third respondent to remove the entry in
encumbrance in respect of the settlement deed dated 16.11.2020
registered as document No.3561/2020 on the file of the SRO,
Vikravandi, insofar as new natham S.No.313/8-200 sq.mtrs (old
S.No.187/4-0.05  cents)  at  Mundiyambakkam  Village,  Vikravandi
Taluk. 
2. The  case  of  the  petitioner  is  that  the  property
comprised in S.No.313/8 old S.No.187/4, ad measuring 200 sq.mtrs
situated at Mundiyambakkam Village, Vikravandi Taluk, originally
belonged to the father of the petitioner. However, the fourth
respondent claims right over the said property and attempted to
intercept there on. Therefore after demise of his father, the
petitioner and his mother filed suit in O.S.No.230 of 1991 on
the file of the Principal District Munsif, Villupuram, for
declaration and injunction in respect of the said property along
with other properties comprised in natham S.No.313/8. The fourth
respondent herein was the third defendant in the said suit and
she contested the said suit. The said suit was initially decreed
in respect of the first item of the property by the judgment
decree  dated  30.08.1993.  However,  the  entire  property  was
decreed by the judgment and decree dated 17.04.1995 by the
appellate Court in A.S.No.307 of 1994 on the file of the
Principal District Court, Villupuram and it is upheld by the
Hon'ble Supreme Court of India by an order dated 23.03.2015 in
Special Leave to Appeal (C).23245 of 2008. 
3. Thereafter, the fourth respondent herein did not allow
to implement the decree. As such the petitioner filed petition
in E.A.No.717 of 2007 in O.S.No.230 of 1991, seeking police aid
to implement the order of injunction. Though the petition was
dismissed on 06.12.2007, the said order was set aside by this
Court in C.R.P.No.1 of 2008. Thereafter, the petitioner was put
https://hcservices.ecourts.gov.in/hcservices/
in possession and he put up compound wall in and around the
subject property. Further the fourth respondent filed a review
petition in Review Application No.32 of 2008 as against the
order passed in the Civil Revision Petition and the same was
also dismissed by this Court by an order dated 04.03.2008. In
the mean time, patta was issued in favour of the petitioner's
mother in patta No.549. The said patta was challenged by the
fourth  respondent  before  the  Assistant  Settlement  Officer,
Tiruvanamalai, and the same was also dismissed on 18.09.1996.
Aggrieved by the same the fourth respondent filed revision
before the District Revenue Officer and the same was also
dismissed by an order dated 31.03.1999 and it became final. 
4. While  being  so,  the  petitioner's  mother  executed
Settlement  Deed  dated  30.06.2015  registered  vide  document
No.2376 of 2015 on the file of the third respondent in favour of
the  petitioner.  While  presenting  the  Settlement  Deed  for
registration,  to  prove  the  title  over  the  property,  the
petitioner and his mother produced all the judgments and decrees
passed in their favour and also the patta issued in the mother's
name. All the documents were part and parcel of the Settlement
Deed. After execution of the settlement deed, the petitioner was
issued patta in Patta No.549 and thereafter, the petitioner is
in possession and enjoyment of the subject property. 
5. On the other hand, the fourth respondent claimed title
over the property on the strength of the sale deed dated
07.11.1991 registered vide document No.462 of 1991. However, the
title was declared in favour of the petitioner and his mother in
the suit filed by them in O.S.No.230 of 1991. Further the fourth
respondent executed Settlement Deed in favour of the fifth
respondent on 16.11.2020 and presented the same before the third
respondent for registration and the same was also registered in
document No.3561 of 2020. Therefore, the petitioner filed this
Writ Petition, challenging the impugned Settlement Deed dated
16.11.2020 and sought for a direction to the third respondent to
remove the entry in encumbrance in respect of the subject
property. 
6. Heard Mr.N.Suresh, learned counsel appearing for the
petitioner, Mr.Yogesh Kannadasan, learned Government Advocate
appearing for the respondents 1 to 3 and Mr.V.Tamizhanban,
learned counsel appearing for the respondents 4 & 5. 
7. While pending the Writ Petition, the petitioner lodged
complaint before the second respondent and on receipt of the
same, the second respondent, conducted detailed enquiry. The
second  respondent  also  called  for  report  from  the  third
respondent. 
https://hcservices.ecourts.gov.in/hcservices/
8. On perusal of report reveals that on receipt of the
settlement deed executed by the fourth respondent in favour of
the fifth respondent, the third respondent verified the document
and it was found that the fourth respondent claimed the subject
property together with bore well, electricity service connection
and claimed that the said property was purchased from one
S.Chockalingam by the sale deed dated 07.11.1997 registered vide
document No.462 of 1991. The said document was verified and
found  that  the  said  S.Chockalingam  had  purchased  the  said
property from one R.Chandramoorthy, under the sale deed dated
28.08.1986  registered  vide  document  No.1787  of  1986.  On
verification of the said document, it was found that the said
R.Chandramoorthy  had  purchased  the  said  property  in  public
auction in O.S.No.497 of 1979 on the file of the District Munsif
Court, Villupuram in E.P.No.193 of 1984. The said sale was
confirmed, as per the sale certificate dated 13.03.1985. On the
basis of those documents, the third respondent registered the
settlement deed presented by the fourth respondent in favour of
the fifth respondent. Therefore, the third respondent has no
other reason to register the sale deed including the settlement
deed executed in favour of the petitioner by his mother in the
year, 2015 registered vide document No.2376 of 2015. 
9. On the basis of the said report, the second respondent
passed orders on 03.05.2021 and concluded that the sale deed
registered vide document No.462 of 1991 and the settlement deed
executed by the petitioner's mother vide document No.2376 of
2015 and the settlement deed executed by the fourth respondent
in favour of the fifth respondent vide document No.3561 of 2020
are wrongly registered and the same is against the circular
issued by the first respondent, and therefore, directed the
third respondent to make entry in the encumbrance in respect of
the aforesaid documents. 
10. It is also seen that the petitioner filed petition in
E.A.No.717 of 2007 in O.S.No.230 of 1991 on the file of the
District  Munsif  Court,  Vikkiravandi,  seeking  police  aid  to
implement the decree of injunction granted in O.S.No.230 of 1991
and the same was allowed. Aggrieved by the same the fifth
respondent herein preferred a Civil Revision Petition and the
same is pending in C.R.P.No.1931 of 2021. That apart, the fifth
respondent also filed suit in O.S.No.310 of 2021 on the file of
the Sub Court, Villupuram and it is pending for adjudication.
11. On perusal of the judgments and decrees passed in
favour of the petitioner's mother in O.S.No.230 of 1991 revealed
that the petitioner's mother had title over the property and on
the strength of the same, she executed settlement deed in favour
of the petitioner. Even then, the fourth respondent executed
https://hcservices.ecourts.gov.in/hcservices/
settlement  deed  in  favour  of  the  fifth  respondent  on  the
strength of the sale deed dated 07.11.1991 registered vide
document No.462 of 1991. 
12. Therefore, the fourth respondent has no right or title
over the subject property to execute the settlement deed in
favour of the fifth respondent and it is non-est in the eye of
law. Accordingly, the third respondent is directed to make entry
in encumbrance in respect of the subject property by removing
the entry of the settlement deed dated 16.11.2020 registered
vide document No.3561 of 2020. 
13. With the above directions, this Writ Petition stands
disposed of. Consequently, connected miscellaneous petition is
closed. There shall be no order as to costs.

primary_legal_issue: Whether the High Court can quash the proceedings in D.V.A. No.3 of 2015 before the Judicial Magistrate under Section 482 of the CrPC when the matter has been settled before trial.
summary: The petition, filed on 19 February 2021 before the Madras High Court, sought quashing of criminal proceedings (D.V.A. No.3 of 2015) pending before Judicial Magistrate No.5, Coimbatore, invoking the inherent powers of the Court under Section 482 of the Criminal Procedure Code. The petitioners—six individuals—asserted that the dispute had been settled before the trial court, rendering the petition infructuous. The respondent, Dr. M. Krishnaveni, was the sole opposing party. The learned counsel for the petitioners emphasized the settlement and requested dismissal of the petition and closure of the connected miscellaneous petition. The Court, after considering the submission, held that where the parties have settled the matter, the High Court’s power to interfere under Section 482 is not exercisable, and the petition stands dismissed as infructuous. Consequently, the connected miscellaneous petition was also closed. The order reflects the Court’s adherence to the principle that the inherent jurisdiction to quash proceedings is to be exercised sparingly and only when necessary to prevent abuse of process, not where the dispute has already been resolved between the parties.
facts: Petitioners filed a Criminal Original Petition under Section 482 CrPC to quash proceedings in D.V.A. No.3 of 2015 before Judicial Magistrate No.5, Coimbatore. They claimed the matter was settled before the trial court. The respondent was Dr. M. Krishnaveni. The petition also sought closure of a connected miscellaneous petition.
arguments: Petitioners argued that the settlement rendered the petition unnecessary and requested dismissal and closure of the related miscellaneous petition. No substantive argument from the respondent is recorded in the order.
judgment_reasoning: The Court observed that the parties had settled the dispute, making the petition infructuous. Since Section 482 is an inherent power to prevent abuse of process, it cannot be invoked to interfere where the matter is already resolved. Accordingly, the petition was dismissed and the connected miscellaneous petition closed.
key_legal_points: Section 482 CrPC confers inherent power to quash criminal proceedings to prevent abuse of process
A settled dispute makes a petition under Section 482 infructuous
The High Court may dismiss a petition and close related miscellaneous petitions when settlement is proven
legal_issues: Whether Section 482 can be invoked to quash proceedings that have been settled before trial
Effect of settlement on the jurisdiction of the High Court to entertain a petition under Section 482

primary_legal_issue: Whether the registration of a civil court decree is subject to the limitation period prescribed under the Indian Registration Act
summary: The petitioners filed a writ petition seeking to direct the Sub-Registrar to register a decree passed in their favor. The Sub-Registrar refused to register the decree citing the limitation period. The court held that the limitation period does not apply to the registration of civil court decrees and directed the Sub-Registrar to register the decree.
facts: The petitioners owned a property that was the subject of a suit for specific performance. The suit was dismissed, and the petitioners were directed to pay a sum of money to the fourth respondent. The petitioners deposited the amount and obtained a certified copy of the judgment and decree, which they presented for registration. The Sub-Registrar refused to register the decree citing the limitation period.
arguments: The petitioners argued that the limitation period does not apply to the registration of civil court decrees. The respondents argued that the registration of the decree is subject to the limitation period.
judgment_reasoning: The court relied on its previous judgments to hold that the limitation period does not apply to the registration of civil court decrees. The court directed the Sub-Registrar to register the decree.
key_legal_points: The limitation period does not apply to the registration of civil court decrees
The registration of a civil court decree is not a compulsorily registrable document
legal_issues: Whether the registration of a civil court decree is subject to the limitation period
Whether the Sub-Registrar has the authority to refuse registration of a decree on the ground of limitation
precedents_cited: Previous judgments of the Madras High Court

IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT MADRAS

Prayer :- Writ Petition is filed under Article 226 of the

https://hcservices.ecourts.gov.in/hcservices/

ORDER
This Writ Petition has been filed for issuance of writ of
mandamus, directing the third respondent herein to register the
decree passed in O.S.No.3 of 2011 dated 24.07.2015 on the file
of the Court of II Additional District Court, Chidambaram, on
payment of necessary charges.
2.   Heard, Mr.A.Muthukumar, learned counsel appearing
for the petitioners and Mr.Yogesh Kannadasan, learned Special
Government Pleader appearing for the respondents 1 to 3.
3.  The case of the petitioner is that the property,
comprised in survey No.116/2 and New survey No.484/1 to an
extent of 40 cents, owned by the petitioners.   The fourth
respondent instituted a suit in O.S.No.3 of 2011 on the file of
the  II  Additional  District  Court,  Chidambaram,  against  the
petitioners  for  specific  performance  on  the  basis  of  the
agreement  for  sale  dated  04.04.2008  along  with  alternative
remedy to refund a sum of Rs.18,00,000/- with interest at the
rate of 12% per annum.    The said suit was dismissed by a
Judgment and Decree dated 24.07.2015.  However, the petitioners
were directed to pay a sum of Rs.1,00,000/- with interest at the
rate of 12% per annum from 05.04.2009 till the date of payment.
There is no appeal as against the said Judgment and Decree,
either by the petitioners or by the fourth respondent herein.
4.    As directed by the Court below, the petitioners
also deposited the amount to the credit of O.S.No.3 of 2011.
Thereafter, the petitioners obtained a certified copy of the
Judgment and Decree passed in O.S.No.3 of  2011 and presented
for registration before the third respondent.  However, the
third respondent refused to register the Judgment and Decree for
the reason that the decree could not be registered after a
period of four months from the date of Decree.
5.   This Court repeatedly held that the provisions under
Sections  23  and  25  of  the  Indian  Registration  Act,  which
prescribes  limitation,  will  not  apply  in  the  case  of
registration of any Civil Court Decree.  Since, the decree is
not  a  compulsorily  registrable  document  and  the  limitation
prescribed under the Registration Act would not stand attracted
for registering any decree.   Therefore, the third respondent
cannot refuse to registration of the Court Decree on the ground
of limitation.
6.   In view of the above, the petitioners are directed
to present the Judgment and Decree passed in O.S.No.3 of 2011
dated 24.07.2015 for registration before the third respondent

and on receipt of the same, the third respondent is directed to
register and release the same forthwith.
7.  With the above direction, this writ petition is
disposed of.  No costs.

summary: The plaintiffs filed a civil suit seeking a scheme for the preservation, administration, and functioning of the first defendant trust and the appointment of trustees. However, the plaintiffs failed to appear or respond, and the court dismissed the suit for non-prosecution.

arguments: The defendants reported no instructions from their clients, and the plaintiffs' counsel failed to take steps to prosecute the case.
judgment_reasoning: The court dismissed the suit due to the plaintiffs' failure to prosecute the case and the lack of interest from both parties in pursuing the matter.
